Been coming to this bar for a few years now. Easily one of my favorites in the area. The cocktails are great and reasonably priced for manhattan at $14. Though it's often crowded, the staff are helpful and I've never had a problem finding a table. The playlist of always great, only issue is that it can get pretty loud so definitely not the place to go if you want to chat quietly with friends.

The food is delicious and comes out quickly. Overall a quality bar I will continue to take people out to when they visit me in the city!

Cool place to chill with an impressive selection of food and a variety of craft beers. Clean and warm with a relaxed lounge vibe, this is a great spot to hang out with a small group of friends. I had the French dip with au jus and ordered some "korean fries", which were freshly made fries with kimchi, bulgogi and sriracha mayo. Mmmm, so delicious. The portions were generous, though the prices matched the quality and portion size.

Lighting was slightly dimmed for a relaxed vibe, with candles to provide table lighting. Music was at just the right level to allow conversation yet eliminate dead space and provide a fun positive setting. Wait staff were always within reach (came on a Wednesday night) and were courteous and attentive.

There's also a cocktail bar located below, which was even more cozy and chill with mood lighting and more privacy. A place to check out next time :)

Very basic bar, but I think it's chill and relaxing booths play well with the happy hour crowd. It wasn't ever as packed as the other spots on this block, which I like. Overall everything was well priced and I had a great time hanging out with my co workers.

Given the rather commercial makeup of the lower Manhattan/South Street Seaport area, I've always found it surprising that there weren't more bars available for post work libations. Having found the Growler, I now know where I'll be going for happy hours when I'm downtown. The Growler has a huge selection of beers on tap, none of which seemed to be Budweiser or any of its kin. Prices were reasonable, at seven to eight dollars for a full stein of beer, which seems like a fair price especially in lower Manhattan. Even though we picked a table, a waiter made sure to come by and check if we needed anything besides drinks.

On weekends, they have live music which can make it a bit difficult to carry on a conversation over the musicians

Such a fun night life! Excellent happy hour and one of the biggest bars on stone street !  

Food is yummy! And the service is great! They have outdoor seating during the summer and the spring!
You HAVE TO COME HERE ON MONDAY'S!! For $26, you get a whole 1 1/2 pound lobster, huge baked potato, corn on the cob and a draft beer! It was the BEST meal and least expensive in NY!!

Visit Date: February 25, 2023

I came here with my friends to see Rubix Kube again because they are awesome. One of my friends and I do not drink alcohol but we had to ask multiple bartenders before we got one to honor the free drink it said we were supposed to have on the printed ticket. Our one friend that drank ended up with 3 amaretto shots.

It got super crowded, expect this place to be extremely crowded on a Saturday night. If you want any chance at getting a seat get in early. My friends and I had to stake out a space at the bar and eat our food standing.

When the show started we couldn't see anything until we managed to sneak to the front of the stage. So also be mindful you might want to try to get a spot in front of the stage area ahead of time as well.

Besides being overcrowded this was a fun night at Ulysses' with good food and a great show!

This spot is pretty cool. Came in for an office holiday party. The restaurant was very hard to find because of the scaffolding. Once I finally find it and entered there isn't a host at the entrance so it is hard to tell who works there and ask for help when I was trying to locate the party. The food was ok, regular wings, veggies and burgers bit not very flavorful. Pretty cool to visit to grab a quick meal and drink, I guess.

The worst service you could ever get. Saturday early night, live music show for $10. I was enjoining just my second beer standing next to the bar when all of a sudden the Irish bartender closed my tap, dropped my credit car in front of me and just kicked me out of the busy bar. More over he called a security guy who pushed me outside through the back door. Have never got such mean service and attitude in general in my life, especially at the place I have been many times before. Without any reason! Looks like he even added the tips closing my tap, needles to say I would not had tipped him a penny. Just on principle I will disclaim this transaction. This guy must be fired immediately for his behavior and hospitality.

My wife and I love Ulysses'. We come here often with friends and family, especially on Monday nights; a pound and  half lobster, corn on the cob and baked potato with a pint draft of Guinness, soda or juice. Our grand boys had their first lobsters here and we come back every summer!

Let me preface this by saying I've been here a couple of times over the years, but I have only gotten the Lobster Monday special, which is $25 lobster + beer/glass of wine. That does alone is AMAZING!! Lobster was very delicious and you could drench it in the butter they give you. My one qualm about this place is the service, or the lack thereof. The place seemed very understaffed - I don't know if that's the case on other days of the week, but at least the most recent Monday I went, I saw only 1 bartender for the first 10 minutes of being seated. I had to ask the bartender to get a server, and the server did not come out until a while later. However, they were pretty fast in serving our food, which was nice.

My wife was with a man at this bar that she thought she was just meeting a new friend and came back home with me eventually to Brooklyn at our home and she's hallucinating right now and panicking. She has no doubt in her mind she was roofie'd. This is not okay. I need them to check their cameras, if they are a big establishment like they say they are then we can find this man. I will  identify my wife with this man to check this.

This is NOT okay. This needs to be handled. This is terrible way to enter the new years "celebration". My wife was roofie'd at this bar.

WOMEN DO NOT COME HERE you WILL get roofie'd !!!!! She literally cannot retccolecte anything in the past hour of being there and she is thanking god that I found her when I did

I've been here twice on weekend nights, and both times have been strange. Many many young girls who were clearly beyond wasted, guys who are looking to take these girls home. Bartenders should be cutting people off but this doesn't seem like the case.

Dealt with an incident last night where a girl was barely able to stand and a guy was trying to kiss her and take her home. She wanted help so we intervened and got the guy "kicked out" only for him to come back in to try to get her to go with her again. Security did not care about this girl because "she's a regular and it happens often". She was either drugged or over served. Regardless, I hope she made it home okay and this whole experience left a horrible taste in my mouth. Too many men running this place who don't care what happens to these young girls.

This is a great place to just hang out and have a drink. It is spacious and the ambiance is cool. The bar in the middle and the decor is nice. The bartender was great and the cocktails were tasty. Will definitely come back here.

Lobster night is what this review is solely about which only occurs on Monday. A perfectly cooked lobster with delicious corn on the cob and a potato the size of a Baby bull dog and a great pint of beer for $25. The service was very friendly and attentive. A great old Irish bar that gives you incredible value on a Monday night.

First time visitor. I was seated quickly and enjoyed my meal. It wasn't very crowded at first but still quite loud due to sound system making it tough to converse with my friend. Live music kicked in near the end of our visit which we enjoyed in the next room. I would return next time I'm in the area.

Came here on St Paddy's to see the live music they advertised all over their Instagram page, but when we get there the music was only for a private event. Very off putting that they would heavily advertise this fake news. Staff was condescending when asked about the mix up. What a shame- wanted to like this place.

This bar I'd randomly end up in whenever I used to be on Stone St..never knew where it is that I'd stumble into, but now that I work around here and get tired of working MUCH MORE, I end up in Ulysses. Became a favorite on the block, the food is delicious here, like seriously! The burgers are juicy, the fries are crispy and they have pretty good sauces for the apps. I was not disappointed when I came to eat here with my co-workers. Left full, and happy with all the margs I had. There's outdoor seating as well. Decent service and friendly vibe inside! I surely recommend to people searching for a bar to grub and/or drink at, when around FiDi!

Came here with a few co-workers for an outdoor lunch, and overall Ulysses has decent food, delicious drinks, and all of the FiDi bro culture you could ever ask for.

I ordered the mezze/hummus plate which had a perfect combination of dolmas, hummus, and veggies. I wanted to go the healthy route which is why I went with it, but their vegetarian options are lackluster in general. Next time I'd go for their veggie burger or grilled cheese.

The drinks are delicious, and after one of my friend's found a fly in her drink, they immediately made her another one. As someone who isn't a fan of beer, the beer here is good (their IPA's aren't super hoppy and on the lighter end).
Fun bar for after work crowd or late Saturday night. They had a live band that was player cover music from the 90s and it was absolutely amazing!

SO picture this... it's st. Patrick's day and it's mayhem at stone street (as per usual) and all we want to do is get into our favorite bar... Ulysses. Ross, the bouncer in the back, told us that if we waited in line that someone would get us soon to let us in. We wait in line. THEN we see Ross, behind us, letting a group in before us. Me and my big New Yorker mouth yelled at Ross, in a friendly way, and said that he better let us in next because I ain't blind and I can see him letting people in before us. With a laugh and a smile, Ross promptly let us in shortly after I yelled at him. Ross apparently isn't technically an employee at Ulysses but brownie points for him because he ultimately held true to his promise and took my yelling like a champ. Cheers!

I feel sorry for all the negative reviews- I empathize, and I can completely see all of those scenarios play out here.

Let me put it this way: this is not "bring your family for a dinner" location.

This is "my coworkers and I are stressed cause it's been crazy at work and we need to unwind" and/or "my friends and I were chilling at another bar but now it's 2am, the last bar is closing up and it's the financial district... where else can we go?"

Then you'll have a good time

Terrible experience solely because of the awful security. They bullied my friend and said her ID didn't look real (we are years past the legal age), when she called them out on it they barred us from entering any bar on the block. I'm visiting from out of town and it ruined my entire weekend.
Our local spot, good drinks music and staff. We love Simon and James they are so kind and always take such good care of us and everyone. Highly recommend Ulysses and our bartender friends :)

There is probably no bad bar in this part of town that is open late. Always a crowd no matter how late you arrive. This was definitely a harbor in the time of storm, albeit for a humorous reason, but the Mac-n-cheese bites and chicken tenders did not disappoint. Not really a dive bar, the crowd was too elevated, but certainly a place you can go as you are, which is more important.

Review based on drinks only, no food!!!! Have been to this bar a few times now, as it is close to me in FiDi. Sit right at the bar every time, no long wait, music playing at a good volume, and pretty good service. I've received a few free drinks every time from the bartender, in addition to the drinks being reasonably priced. Bar is not "classy" or "clean" if that is what you're looking for. Just a typical run-of-the-mill Irish bar with lots of seating and your typical drink list.

We didn't order any food here this was just a stop on our pub crawl the last night we were in New York. We were there after midnight and were able to snag a bar table with quick service for the beers that we ordered. Not too loud and not too quiet, a really nice vibe and atmosphere. Shortly after we arrived the tables filled up but everybody waited patiently until seats opened to grab the tables that were available. We're definitely starting again my next trip and try the food.

Food: mediocre. My boyfriends burger was ok and my chicken sandwich was terrible. Service: unfortunately bad. Our waitress truly seemed bothered when she was taking our order. I asked for a side salad and she didn't ask what dressing I wanted. I asked "what dressings do you have" and she just gave me a blank look. I said "ok do you have balsamic?" And she walked away. When our food came, the salad was just greens with a side of balsamic vinegar, not balsamic dressing. Apparently they don't know what balsamic dressing is? Really bad experience. I don't leave reviews much but I would avoid this place.

Honestly don't understand the negative reviews. As a service member coming in from a long day at work, this was a great place to cool off. This particular night I had a shift in a few and I need a lager to cool my nerves, but I didn't really have clean clothes so I decided to just pop in with my uniform on. Normally I get kicked out of bars if they see I'm in the military due to "issues with service members", but these guys were surprisingly accommodating. I even got a free Lager on the house. I also tried the quesadilla and it was crunchy, delicious, with fresh pico de gallo. Honestly one of the best bars I've ever been to, and I'll definitely be coming more often. The bartender was very kind as long as your not an obvious douche like most of the people writing these bad reviews are. Also to the guy whose wife got roofied, that sounds like a classic case of wife getting her pipes cleaned by another man. Tough titty buddy.

I have always loved Ulysses. Tonight I met trina the bartender. She was very rude to my girlfriend, who is a complete sweetheart. At the end of the night, I asked to close out. She said "I don't have your card". And walked away immediately (It was not busy at all). I then asked if she could check again. She rolled her eyes, checked again, found my card and said "here's your gold card" in a condescending way. I said back "you were very rude to my girlfriend earlier and now me and that's not very nice"... she then decided seemlessly transition into a barrage of insults as I left. I'll remove this negative review if Trina the bartender apologizes.

On a jaunt down to see the oldest street in America we stumbled across Ulysses - a perfect Irish bar playing American country / Americana music like The Steeldrivers, Devil Makes Three, Colter Wall, Old 97s, Turnpike Troubadours, and more. Good oysters, amazing fries, and even better whiskey / cocktail selection. I wanted to stay here and write lyrics for my next album all night long. There is outdoor seating but then you miss out on the great and historic indoor pub vibe. Service was awesome - even when I ordered a wrong drink - the bar fixed it and introduced me to my new favorite rye. Live music on Thursdays. It's a bit out of the way from my usual haunts but I love this place.

Used to be my go-to spot for couple points and bit when arriving in town for work. In NY for vacation with family and wanted to grab quick lunch on a Saturday .

Positives :  cant beat the Guineas pour- legit. Hummus app platter was good. Wife had effs Benedict from brunch options - it was meh  given very thin hollandaise sauce. Sons "morning after burger" would have been great but for moldy  bun which was sent back.

Overall, will keep this place on list for outdoor drinks when weather good - cant beat the Stone Street vibe. But will pass on anyThing more.

Came here after work with my friend last week - one of the less busy spots on stone street compared to the other taverns and restaurants. they don't have happy hour which is a bummer. drinks are alright. and the oysters were okay as well. pricy - $3 each. the service was friendly!

Went with my neighbor after a very long and stressful day (almost lost my puppy). We met two guys and my neighbor went to drop his dog (we live just around the corner). I was verbally assaulted by one of the two white guys (he said some graphic sexual things to me and picked up on my neighbor because he was guy)... when I stoop up to him he threatened me and said he would call the cops and so I told him to go ahead and that I would wait- his reply "well you know what they'll do to you" ... I was asked then by the manager and the bouncer to leave and have been banned from that place. At no time did they ask me what happened. They threw me out and the 2 guys stayed.

Few days later as I was walking my dog I saw them do the same to a non Caucasian person- I hate calling on the race card... but I absolutely felt attacked as a black woman and the manager is such a RUDE man alongside with most of their bouncers.
Definitely a -10 for me!

Im a harsh burger critic. Mainly because I come from wisconsin and we have the best dairy/farm meat. The majority of nyc burgers are a waste of cash.  

The cheeseburger here is phenomenal and I will be coming back to eat it. It tastes like a solid classic, soda fountain shop, drive thru burger. Smash style patties. Mamma Mia. I got a double and it was plenty of food. I'll get a single next time for sure.

Cheers to this place.

Pub place in the heart of Wall Street!  I'm liking the musky and dreary vibes, but modern restrooms!

Grab a beer with bar bites!  It's so divey - I'm lovin' the surroundings when I was here.  

Low key spot.  It's a great tucked away bar from the energy and wrath of the bull market.

Last night going to hear "Tramps Like Us," had all of the earmarkings of a SuperSpreader event. Someone decided that not checking vaccine cards, wearing masks and permitting wall to wall people with less than 1 foot of distance between fans was a good idea?!! Where are we in Florida??! Bruce would not have been happy to be honored in such an irresponsible manner.
Awful - do not get the crispy chicken sandwich, 99% sure they make it in a microwave. Fries were fine.

Meh.

Pretty standard for stone st. Food is fine, service is fine. But nothing stands out as spectacular here. I've gotten a couple of salads, a quesadilla and a burger and it's all decent but nothing to write home about. Service is good and the staff is pretty attentive. But overall, I'd rather go to underdog or dubliner if I'm looking for pub grub on stone st.

Huge busy spot with tons of craft beers on draft and a fun atmosphere. We went here for happy hour and scored some prime spots at the bar. They happened to have a whiskey tasting booth open which was a nice bonus. The bartenders were attentive and friendly. Definitely a fun spot for a drink and some shenanigans.
When it gets warmer they have an outside area on the closed off st where you can mingle with patrons of other bars...love it during his time.
ENJOY!

So much fun!! We went there for a friends birthday in late April, they don't take reservations but there's so much outdoor seating that I have never been unable to find a spot. We were a party of seven and we got in right away.

The food we had was really good, the chicken tenders and fries are both great bar bites. We also had a piece of cheesecake for dessert which was outstanding.

They waitstaff was definitely busy and the service was a little slow, so we ordered our drinks two at a time. We never felt ignored, we could see them running around. It's a busy place on a busy street, so you get what you get. The vibes were absolutely immaculate though, the staff sang to my friend for her birthday and the whole street sang along. Definitely a great place for events like this.

Bouncers let people back in even after they've THROWN UP in the bar!! Yes, you read that right. DISGUSTING.

The bouncer admitted "oh..yeah he threw up but he's fine now" as I watched him & his friend stand at the bar to order more shots!? He threw up ON ME so no he is NOT fine!? On any normal day, but especially a post-peak-covid world we live in now, why in the WORLD is that acceptable? To top it off, on a busy weekend evening there was NO owner or manager present so I couldn't address it on the spot. Never had an experience like that with a bouncer in all my years in NYC. Truly shocked.

Don't go there unless you don't mind being around people that are carelessly overserved. The bouncers are only there to glance at ID's, not keep you safe & having fun. Shame :(

Worst manager in the world
I came in to use the atm . The atm didn't disburse the requested amount and I brought this to the managers attention.

The manager, Santiago, literally told me " I can't help you. It's not our issue"

Give me my money back. Are you f*cking kidding me???

F*ck this place . Seriously.
My first time here and I already will confirm they will rob you at no cost.

Let me have been a white girl and I promise you, he would've at least attempted to give me the atm company or assisted me .

Stopped here with family after our revolutionary war era tour.
Very cool on the inside. Feels like an old style tavern. Restaurant is on cobblestone road.
Great ambiance. Very friendly service. Right as we walked in they insisted we sit at the best table in the restaurant.

They were able to accommodate my pregnancy request for a virgin mojito which I thought was delicious. My husband got the Brooklyn seasonal beer, a lager he enjoyed.

For food my husband and I split the salmon salad (the picture is my portion only). It was good.
We shared the chili. It's covered in cheddar cheese just like you see with Swiss over French onion soup. Delicious. We thought it needed a little kick so added tabasco sauce. But it was a perfect hearty meal for the rainy day that it was.
My mom got the grilled chicken gyro-she said she's had better but it was still good. The fries were good as well(it's hard to mess up a French fry though am I right??)
My dad got the steak salad and enjoyed it.
We were all very happy with our food choices. Food was out quick after we ordered. I wouldn't say omg you have to come here for the food. Really it's for the feel of the tavern and the food isn't bad and the service is great!
Of course it's a little pricey but it's New York.

If we were in the area again and had different family In town we would take them here!

Bouncers and bartenders got mad at various women for little reason (those outside of my group). I didn't get into specifics, but the way they talked to the women was all generally sexist. There are plenty of bars in the area who wouldn't have workers who act this way. I suggest going elsewhere, especially if it's just for a bar night.
Imagine thinking people's real ID's were fakes and refusing to serve them because of this - then banning them for asking for the manager to verify.

I have made a new policy to make my words sweet considering how many times I have to eat them. Mmmm... sweet AND salty.

I've seen too many awesome live shows here to care about the seating anymore. Plus it leaves room to dance, not sit! And people do dance.
I don't know who's doing the sound the past few times I've been this year, but I'm doing a slow clap for you sir. Outstanding. And ultimately, when you're here for the music that's what matters. Well that and my prerequisite doubles served in a pint glass.

Most shows I've been to have a $10 door charge but you get that back with the $10 drink ticket. After that, have all the cost and time effective doubles you want.
There's food, and I've eaten it in the past, so I remember it being good, but for the sake of journalistic integrity, I'll update when I've mangiare'd there again.

There's a lively crowd on Saturdays. Not crowded and there may be some people in formal dinner wear tumbling in. So this makes for the after-party-party spot around Wall Street. They were fun. But that's mostly because of the band, The Jewbadours, purveyors of classic Yacht Rock. Think of Hall & Oats and Michael McDonald and you've got the idea. Such a great night.

Drinks, dinner, a show and dancing... that pretty much covers everything one needs for a good time, and here it is all in one spot.

The only reason I come here is for Hello Brooklyn. They are truly the most talented group of 5. They bring an energy to the crowd that's unreal and unmatched. I've been here for other live bands and it's just not the same. Thursday nights, any time you see Hello Brooklyn, it is worth it to come. Performance you won't regret, experience you won't regret, DRINKS you won't regret. HELLO BROOKLYN!!!!! That's it, that's the Yelp.

Ulysses has become my favorite spot on Stone St. Plenty of space, good menu, and great liquor selection. This is one of the few pubs/bars that I'm excited to go to on a weekday, and definitely one of my favorites in FiDi.

This bar has been a staple for my friends and I for several years.  While it's a great place to grab a drink or a meal any day, the nights with live music are tremendous.

I only wish they would bring back live music on Thursday's as it's a great way to kick off the weekend.

Anyway, it's a cool bar, with a good menu and solid drink selection.  If there's also live music, you're in for a real treat.

"Ulysses" is not only a staple of 20th century literature but a staple in the FiDi drinking scene. The ambiance and environment make for a quant Irish pub experience. Ulysses is a great place to enjoy a finely poured pint of gat (aka Guinness) with friends and family. I've enjoyed many days and nights here and miss the live music very much. I wish management wasn't as blind as Homer (the Greek poet) but am hopeful the live music makes a return. If you're ever in the neighborhood do yourself a favor and stop in to share a pint. Highly recommended!

Ulysses is a FiDi staple that everyone should check out ASAP! You want cold beer? They have lots! Want dinner or late night food? They have it!
You want a pickle back shot? They have the best around!

I've been coming here for years with my friends and we've had countless memorable nights. Some of the best nights happen when they have live music, especially their Thursday night band, Hello Brooklyn!! I wish they would bring them back this year so we can continue to have great times!!

You should go to Ulysses if you want to have a good time!

I thought about this the other day as a lot of restaurants are opening outdoor dining, this was the first place I thought of. I actually visited this place last Fall and the outdoor seating is all spread out on the street and no one was sitting inside. Very spacious space to have a beer and food with friends. I would visit this place again!
Worst bar I've ever been to. Bouncer let their friends in who literally threw up on my fiancé and did not kick the culprit out. Disgusting staff. Bartenders were wonderful. Bouncers were disgusting.

Review for KBOB (Korean bowls):

I was ripped off at KBOB. After looking at my receipt, I was charged a bogus 3.5% credit card "surcharge" which I was not told would be charged prior to swiping my credit card.

After inquiring why I was not told, the employee shrugged. I looked at the register and asked "do you even accept cash?" The reply was "no, they don't really load the cash register." I asked "is there an app that I could have paid on to avoid the surcharge?" I was told "there is no app right now, no."

This is really outrageous and given all of the above, KBOB is actually robbing customers. I also hold Urbanspace responsible.

Update: Urbanspace graciously contacted me and made it right.

I'm a big fan of Urbanspace. The variety of vendors serve such a wide range of cuisines, you can almost always find something you'll be in the mood for.

From the few places I've tried, I can confirm that they are very generous with their serving sizes. The prices may sometimes seem high, but it's typically enough food for me to cover two meals - so it's worth it!

I would recommend this place to anyone and everyone!

I'm a big fan of Urbanspace's food courts that allow you - or, better, groups small and large - to sample options from multiple eateries at once. Indeed, they're perfect if you're meeting up with a bunch of people with different preferences, as there generally should be something for everyone at such affairs.

The Urbanspace here at 100 Pearl Street is a great example, with over a dozen options to choose from that include Korean bibimbap, acai bowls, grain bowls, tacos, Puerto Rican entrees, Japanese curry - you name it. Most of the eateries are casual walk-up affairs that enable you to mix and match among them and then congregate at common seating spread throughout the venue.

It was all curiously quiet when I stopped by on a recent mid-afternoon, but, thankfully, this food court isn't just open during office hours - it's open just late enough into the evening to serve as a solid dinner, takeout, or Doordash/delivery option. An excellent way to repurpose unused ground-level space here in the heart of the Financial District.
Signature fried chicken sandwich at extra sauce is #awesomesauce so many places to eat and super cute interior with enough eating areas -- much needed spot in FiDi

I have come here various times; once to eat the gyro and today for the ramen. The place is clean and the lines were reasonable. The ramen was good and it was flavorful and a good portion. I did ask if they had a combo and they said they were working on it. The gyro was very good and fresh and filling. I would come here to try other vendors.

Came in with a coworker around 12:30pm to grab lunch on a Thursday afternoon. It wasn't too full, but definitely filled up within the next 15-20 minutes or so. They have a lot of options, but I feel like a lot of the stalls are pretty pricy.

I had a Katsu curry from Katsu Katsu and it was just OK. The rice felt very overcooked and was actually kind of cold when I ate it, which was basically 2 minutes after I picked it up and found a table to eat at. The katsu was good, but overall it just felt like a very small portion size for the price.

Spacious, clean, dining mess hall like place located in the financial district. Many little restaurants to choose from. We went with Extra
sauce. A burger and chicken sandwich spot. I got the classic burger which was juicy and I really liked it. My husband got the BBQ Ranch sauce for his fries which he wouldn't stop raving about. The waffle fries were cooked to perfection. Another really good thing about this place is that there are bathrooms located in lower level. Coming back to try the PR restaurant Que Chevere. They were closed for Easter according to a sign at their site.

Came by Thursday afternoon for a quick lunch. There's a good amount of small tables and food options. I ordered a bowl with shredded chicken and lemonade from Gabriella's.

Bowl with Shredded Chicken ($14) : 6.5/10 Standard Mexican food bowl that tastes exactly how it looks; reminiscent of bowls from Chipotle. While the beans and rice were warm, the shredded chicken was cold and slightly bitter. The guacamole and salsa were fresh and plain flavor wise. Nothing stood out but if you're looking to get a quick somewhat balanced meal this is it. Recommend not getting the shredded chicken.

Lemonade($5): 7/10 Sweet and sour lemonade with a hint of zest. Decent food pairing.

Wouldn't recommend Gabriella's unless you're looking for a quick meal. Will be back to try the other stores.

Beer glazed doughnut from the Top Hops Beer Shop: 9/10 I was on my way out and saw they had doughnut samplings. Wow, was this good. The doughnut was warm, soft, and fluffy. It had the airiness of a bread loaf and the bounciness of a steamed bun. The glaze was smooth and sweet; didn't taste alcoholic. Although I had already eaten a full meal, I devoured that doughnut in minutes. One con however, was the greasiness of the dough. It left a layer of glistening oil on my fingers. If they had warm fresh doughnuts again, I would need to buy half a dozen to enjoy at a more moderate pace. Props to the baker

Nice and clean setup. A large variety of different foods. It has healthy to down comfort foods. Service is good. The only downfall is the price would be the prices. It is practically double in comparison to the wonderful restaurant outside. I guess we pay for convenience, especially if we work at 50 Water St.

Looks like there is something for everyone here. I dropped by and got a coffee from Grind. The decaf was ground fresh and tastes delicious! So much more flavor that a lot of decaf coffees you get.

I'll return to the market to try some food options at a later date.

I went to Bao by Kaya. The person taking orders was trying to rush so he spoke very fast and seemed annoyed with me, because I had to ask him to repeat himself. This made no difference because my order was wrong. I asked for two combos with fried dumplings and two beef bowls. In his haste, he only put in one order of each. I was so annoyed I just waited for my food. But the Young lady in front of me who'd already been waiting a half an hour; was even more annoyed because he had to ask her what she ordered and remake it because he had given it away. I'm only giving three stars because the food was actually delicious but the service and attitude stinks.

Perfect space to eat!!!! I absolutely love the ambiance so many eateries !! It was a love location at first site. I'd like to write paragraphs and paragraphs about how excited I am that this location is right next to my workplace but I'm hungry  I grabbed a chicken burger from Extra Sauce And it's mouth watering the fries are so good!! Next check in I'll try another restaurant cheers...

Hit or miss only because at least one vendor who was around mid week was not around during the weekend.

Otherwise clean with decent seating and a good selection.
Returned to Urbanspace with more of the vendors open - great place to go for a casual meal

I was ripped off at KBOB. After looking at my receipt, I was charged a bogus 3.5% credit card "surcharge" which I was not told would be charged prior to swiping my credit card.

After inquiring why I was not told, the employee shrugged. I looked at the register and asked "do you even accept cash?" The reply was "no, they don't really load the cash register." I asked "is there an app that I could have paid on to avoid the surcharge?" I was told "there is no app right now, no."

This is really outrageous and given all of the above, KBOB is actually robbing customers. I also hold Urbanspace responsible.

Update: Urbanspace graciously contacted me and made it right.
The burger, the fries, and the sauces were delicious. The service was excellent for a fast food place. I will definitely go back for the pleasant experience I had.

Great space that, surprisingly, was quite empty at 9:30am on a weekday.  The selection of stalls is great and, while I only ate at one, it was superb so I'm assuming the rest have some good quality as well.  If you have a diverse set of tastes in your group, come here so everyone has an option!

Hua R. From Bao By Kaya took very good care of me.
Amazing food, fast and great service. Highly recommend it
This space has a nice eating area and good fern-themed decor. It has plenty of food choices. Some are great and some are not so great; you can find what fits you.

We stopped here for a late lunch and got food from three different places inside. Everything was tasty and filling. The portion size from the vegan place was huge!! I wish more places had been open so we could have tried more, but I guess we'll just have to go back!
Nice space. Good variety of vendors and warm welcomes at every stall we went to. Not too crowded Thursday at 1p.

I got the taco "quinoa" bowl. It's a mountain of quinoa with avocado and black beans.
Fresh but not much else to it. Healthy.
The smoothie is fresh and good.

Ordered here for the first time.. got the Italian steak salad. Description said.. fresh greens, tomato, onion, fresh mozzarella, portobello mushrooms, sliced steak and black pepper. The salad was a little over $18 for the large. Overall the salad was decent. However, the steak was a little cold, the mozzarella wasn't fresh mozzarella and the black pepper was just your typical black pepper packets. Pretty basic salad for the price tag. Definitely not in a rush to order from here again.
I always have a good experiences when I come this sushi restaurant .The fish are really fresh, sushi is very creative and every single bite is just amazing.ニューヨークで1番大好きなお寿司屋さん。一口一口が贅沢すぎて、とろけてしまう絶品さ。

Good old OG. Good ol service. Simply fish. Nothing fancy. Price is a bit high for the space. Needs a revamp so hideo kuribara can step up the omakase game. Place is just too old and boring. Overall still pretty ok with a great chef.

My partner and I came in this Thursday for date night. I'd read some great reviews so it had been on my list for a while. We ordered the 20-piece omakase ($251pp). Unfortunately, for the price point, it ended up being a really disappointing experience. I think this probably would have been better as a $100-150 omakase, and even then I probably wouldn't have been happy with the pricing. That being said, it seemed that many of the others seated at the counter might have been regulars as they had quite the rapport with the head chef. Maybe we came on an off night, or maybe the head chef made the sushi better (we were not served by him) -- either way, the meal was really underwhelming.

My main issue was with the quality of the fish. It didn't taste very fresh, and I felt that for several pieces too much vinegar, soy sauce, or wasabi had been used specifically to cover up the fact that the fish wasn't fresh. A lot of the sauces didn't go well with the fish at all and were too tart or too salty or both. I was pretty shocked at how crass the flavors were for a price point that is fairly high end, and have had much better experiences at other places both above, at, and below the same price point as this place. Even the A5 Miyazaki wagyu was underwhelming, with a sauce that was too salty/vinegary which totally overwhelmed the taste of the meat, which is the whole point. Many of the other dishes were fine, but the overall taste and quality are not what I would expect for this price.

That being said, there were still a few pieces that I enjoyed: the baby eel appetizer, which was very unique, as well as the dessert with the rice balls and red bean. The service was also very good.

If you're willing to pay $250 for omakase though, your money would definitely be better spent somewhere else.

FOOD
The quality of the fish was very fresh but the way it was prepared was disappointing. The Uni was delicious but some of the pieces were a miss.  I would give the presentation 2/5, very basic and incongruent with the price point.

Unfortunately, 75% of the sushi that was part of the Omakase was salty. I could not pin point if it was the rice or the way the fish was prepared but there were a few sushi pieces that was borderline inedible.

EDIT: I was informed, the style of this fish preparation is called Edomae.

SERVICE
Our waitress was great! She was courteous and attentive.

DRINKS
I appreciated how they offered half bottles of champagne and a good selection of sake.

CONCLUSION
For my party of three, our bill ended up being close to $900 after tip for three Omakases and drinks. With that said, I didn't think the experience nor the food were worth the price tag.

If they address the salt issue and perhaps add one or two more pieces to the omakase, it would have improved my dining experience. I left feeling very thirsty and not quite full.

Amazing sushi! One of the best places in NYC for sure! Great service and all the food is delicious!
The tuna special was great! I loved each unique piece of tuna and the spicy tuna roll was so good! They had the best tempura I've ever had and you can tell the quality of the sushi place by it's egg sushi! The egg sushi was amazing and the best I've ever had as well. The pickled vegetables could've been more pickled and have more flavor but still good. One of the best parts was dessert! The matcha tiramisu is a must order! It was so so delicious and my mom from Japan who usually doesn't order or eat desserts at all said it was so good and she wished she had ordered her own. The other people in my party got omakase and said that every piece was amazing.

The chef is friendly and great at what he does! If you're looking for an amazing and authentic sushi and Japanese food in general experience in a laid back and friendly setting with high quality people don't look anywhere else. Can't recommend enough!

I had a wonderful time enjoying the 16-piece omakase. The pieces were prepared well and everything tasted delicious. I had miso soup with shrimp head, simmered bluefin tuna, baby eel, bonito from Japan, eggplant with akami, baby anchovy, fried cod roe with green tea salt, red snapper, salmon roe, sea urchin, sea eel, fatty tuna roll, shiratama anmitsu (sweet red bean paste, rice cakes, kuromitsu syrup with agar cubes) with black sesame ice cream, and a few other things I ate before remembering to take a picture.

Ushiwakamaru is a solid sushi restaurant that offers a fairly priced omakase with an experienced sushi chef. It succeeds where other cheaper alternatives fail, prioritizing quality, seasonality, and tradition with a bit of flair.

I was first introduced to the restaurant by Gordon Y.  on Yelp. He shared with me his fond memories of returning to the counter over and over again to sit with head chef Hideo and encouraged me to with with the chef and buy him a beer!

Hideo-san wowed me with some items I had never seen before: a special cut of toro sashimi, a seasonal matsutake mushroom soup served from a teapot, and fried mackerel with a soy garlic sauce.

The chef's rice was slightly sour, a function of the vinegar he uses to prepare his rice. Each grain was separate and properly loose. The warmth of the rice balanced the temperature of the fish well.

The nigiri featured a lot of wasabi; it wasn't too much, but it was a lot.

While the construction of the nigiri was good, the gunkan maki and handroll suffered from engineering failures. His signature yuba piece self-destructed as the rice was too wet and fell out of the bottom, splattering on the counter; the uni piece was so tall, I had trouble fitting in in my mouth; and the seaweed of the torotaku handroll cracked and detached as I ate it creating a mess as I tried to hold it together. Though these negatives were minor in the context of the meal.

My favorite courses of the night were the fried mackerel appetizer and the saba, ocean trout, akamutsu, and seared toro with truffle salt nigiri. The chef did use a few additional flavors like salt, lemon, and truffle, but thankfully no inappropriate toppings. The draft Sapporo was cold and refreshing.

I left feeling very full and satisfied with the experience. 4/5 would dine again.
This is my first time trying this place. the course was nice and very traditional Japanese omakase style. Love it !

Super easy to make a reservation here! Made mine two days in advance and there were some reasonable dinner times available then. I came here on Fri 2/25/22.

Omakase was $170 (the menu online is outdated) which consists of "daily chef's choice you're welcome to make any requests includes daily special that consists of fresh and seasonal fish". I didn't make any special requests, but chose sushi rolls (instead of nigiri) and this is what my omakase consisted of:

1) ankimo with delicious chewy seaweed
2) chef's special nigiri (this was DELICIOUS and sooo fatty)
3) white miso soup with a shrimp head in it. yum!
4) steamed egg pudding
5) 8 pieces of nigiri
6) hand roll
7) choice of dessert (I chose green tea tiramisu). This was delicious and had red bean inside, which is usually not my favorite but this was so good!

The fish was definitely fresh in the omakase, but it was not in the salmon sushi flight (wish i took pictures). I also love it when the rice is super fresh and warm, and most of these pieces were with cold rice. I also ordered a uni nigiri, toro taku handroll, and negi toro traditional style roll. Sake and beer selection were great. The tempura was also delicious and had a great mix of shrimp, kabocha squash, broccoli, carrot, and octopus.

Overall the experience and atmosphere was great and service was excellent, but the omakase was just a bit overpriced for the quality and quantity. I'd come back here for the non omakase items.

Probably should have gotten the omikase but was in a rush. I saw there was chirashi and tekka don. Below there was a salmon bowl which sounded good. I must admit, for the price, I expected the salmon to be raw. It was over cooked, flavorless, shredded over rice. Supposedly supposed to taste like miso but just flavorless. I hadn't eaten all day, was starving, and running out of time, so I ate as much as I could but it felt like I was eating dog food. Really disappointed. The sake they recommended was good so I gave it an extra star. The restaurant was empty and yet the service was ok. They didn't refill my water or ask how my meal was. I had to flag someone down to pay. Left very disappointed because the restaurant was beautiful and had many good reviews. Just get the omikase.

This spot serves the freshest Edo sushi I have had in a while. The ambiance is amazing and everyone is super welcoming and polite. Loved the master's energy and he also had a snazzy blue sparkly mask on. There were plastic dividers between everyone, and the spacing was definitely more than 6 feet. Felt very safe inside.

I came here for the Omakase to celebrate my birthday and it was absolutely delicious. The sake we ordered was called Take No Tsuyu, and it was super light and smooth. Such a fragrant scent, brewed gently in bamboo forests.

From the Omakase, I enjoyed the mackerel, blow-torched tuna, uni, and otoro hand roll. The uni was SO SWEET and smooth, and the otoro was super tender. The sweet shrimp also deserves a mention for its fresh ocean flavor. The rice also deserves to be highlighted, it was just that good.

At the end, the master asked us if we would like a few more pieces, and he made two more complimentary chef's choice sushi. One of which was an abalone that blew my mind.

Hands down will return for the immaculate service and flavors.

AMAZING. There was not a single piece I did not like and I actually left feeling full (rare at omakase places for me). We got the omakase - mix of sushi and sashimi for $158, which also came with soup, choice of dessert, and a few other items (see photos). Standouts were the monk fish liver (omg I could've had an entire bowl of it) and the tuna scallion hand roll with this amazing homemade soy sauce, followed very closely by the the first fatty tuna piece (forget what kind but sweet the trio photo after the soup), red snapper, shrimp and uni. But honestly there was not a single piece we didn't like. It was all wonderful.

The sake flight option on the menu that night wasn't available so we got the cheapest of the 3 sake options in the junmai gingo category. I forgot the name but it was $14 for a 4 oz glass, which I found reasonable. They also had some pretty high end bottles if you're celebrating a special occasion.

The sushi chef was very friendly and funny. Loved our interactions with him, even if through a plastic plexy glass wall (ugh covid). The waiter was not as attentive (rarely came to refill our drinks and forgot to come back to take my drink order) but it looked like he was the only guy working the entire restaurant, which looked fully booked, and I assume it was just due to understaffing during COVID.

In sum, HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS PLACE. Amazing sushi, excellent sake menu, and friendly chef. Can't wait to return! Easily one of the best places in the city.

I went there for sushi omakase but it was filled with other filler food such as soup as part of your omakse.  It was $198 for food I could've eaten for fraction of the price. For this price, I should've gone to sushi zo. This place is unnecessarily expensive. I had few pieces of sushi, salad, soup... not worth it.

I'm really shocked that I did not enjoy my meal at all because this is so highly rated and it looked really good. For such a high priced restaurant I expected so much more of their food. 2 stars because our server was really nice but overall I wouldn't go back. I think the problem was that the rice was extremely salty. I'm not really sure why it would be salted but every single piece was so salty to the point where I couldn't even finish my food. My least favorite and the most salty was the scallop wasabi hand roll. The fish quality was fine but not the best. There were also flies everywhere while we were eating.
The best kept secret! Delicious sushi, authentic and attentive service. A real gem. Dine here without a doubt.

Fresh, delicious fish. We ordered a la carte. Favorites: Hotate (next time ordering 2 pieces each) and the Chutoro. The Hotate was soft and sweet, the Chutoro a good balance of meatiness and fat. The Otoro on the other hand was super rich, marbled and fatty - maybe even too decadent for us.

We also enjoyed the shrimp and vegetable tempura, there was a misunderstanding and it came at the end of our meal, but we ended up really enjoying it as the end dish. The shrimp tempura was great but the crispy, flavorful veggies made the dish.

The dessert - don't leave without some ice cream. Their black sesame ice cream with a side of red bean was sooooooo goooood. Not sure if they make it in house or if its packaged but I need more of their ice cream in my life - lol.

Service was a little slow but our server was the only one working tonight. She was super sweet and tried to be as quick and attentive as she could. Ordering took a little bit of time but overall we had a great meal.

TLDR: If you're looking for an omakase to leave you feeling wowed, this is a good choice. Price is $158 including small appetizer, soup, 14 pieces, a hand roll and dessert. Solid value.

Ushiwakamaru was recommended to me by a coworker and gave it a shot with wifey. Of all the sushi bars we've been to, this is probably the most comfortable. These are not high chairs, the bar counter is at a very relaxed level - you feel settled in and ready to coast at this omakase.

They will ask you if you prefer your soup at the beginning or the end. Chef Hideo will then begin your tasting. The pieces here are a really nice size, still bitesize but every piece will make your smile. He has this care while he prepares your next nigiri and when he puts it in front of you, you know it is made with love.

The squid, golden eye snapper and soy sauce marinated tuna pieces are always incredible. I've been to Ushiwakamaru several times and we keep coming because it's definitely in our top 5. The dessert choices are very generous too, ranging from a slice of Lady M to a frozen grapefruit dessert.

I have a habit of finishing every omakase with an extra hand roll. Chef Hideo is the only one who will allow me to partake in my favorite commoner delight, a spicy tuna handroll. What I love about his is it's not minced tuna mixed with the srichacha mayo conction, his is more deconstructed. It's literaly pieces of lean tuna tossed in spicy mayo and it's just fabulous.

A great omakase experience
The main part of the sushi was amazing
The first starters were good.
But when the real show started it was one of the best ever. Sea perch, otoro, uni and other usual suspects, were amazing with an additional touch of flavor from the amazing Hideo Kuribaara sushi chef. The desert was great as well :)

Key Summary:  Killer Sushi, Killer Ambience for certain situations.

Am an extensive Omakase diner and Ushiwakamaru is on the top 5 list of my favorites in NYC.  The fish quality amazing.  However what stands this restaurant apart are a few things.  

1.  Ambience.  This is not a super busy, pretentious type of place.  If you are interested in scheduling a long, boozy evening (with friends, a date, or actually for business), this is the place for you.  They don't rush you at the sushi bar (omakase only), and you can have a very long, pleasant chat with the people you are dining with.  In my books, that's rare.

2.  The Chef.  Traditional japanese chef that is very skilled/knowledgeable.  Buy him a beer or three and you will have a lot more fun hanging with him.  

Just go there, PLEASE!

Hidden gem! I've tried numerous omakase sushi spots in NYC and this was incredibly fresh and authentic. My dad has been going to Japan for work for most of my life and I wanted to find a place that was traditional and authentic, but still had an nyc appeal to it. He LOVED it and so did our entire group. Price matches the quality, will definitely be back.

It was my favorite Japanese restaurant. There are too many stories and memories. I cried when I was tasting it. I don't think I can write a good review since I am too emotional and alcohol kicked in.
But I guarantee you it is the authentic Japanese restaurant where you can get the most fresh taste of sushi.

We went there a second time within a week. First time was on wifey's birthday. Second time had to bring my mom too. Chef Hideo Kuribara served us his work of art both times. It was that good. Their edomae style sushi is simply delicious. I don't want to explain what it is. Just go google it. Baby sea eel sashimi, edomae abalone, clam, shrimp, blue fin tuna, uni, just to name a few. Big glass of Sapporo Draft goes with the sushi. I also recently learned that it is customary to buy your sushi Chef a drink as a token of appreciation. We got Hideo-San one and started drinking together. Isn't it amazing to drink with your favorite sushi Chef?
The most amazing Omakase on this planet.  Delicious, unique, incredible presentation, high end and did I mention Uni??  Sit at the  bar and watch the chefs do their magic.

One of my favorite sushi places in the city.  I always recommend it to friends.  Highly recommend the omakase, it has not disappointed once (I have gone at least five times).  If you have never had omakase, make this place your 1st experience.  Our guy is Chef Suzuki!

If you enjoy exotic sushi pieces and a friendly conversation with the chef, check out this place for their omakase. When we went, we were the only party there (Covid special). It felt like we book the place exclusively for ourselves

I was not impressed at all! They serve decent sushi, but I've had much better sushi on many occasions. On top of it, this place is not inexpensive. I ordered the (assorted) Nigiri: 7 pieces of nigiri, 2 piece of gunkan, half of a "thin" roll, and a piece of tamago yaki. The fish was fresh, but was not of the quality that I would expect from the price. What's most disappointing was the rice. High quality rice and seasoned well, but it was tightly packed. For this level of sushi, I would be happy to pay $35, but not $48.

If you are looking for excellent sushi (in NYC), I assure you this is not it! If you must try this place, here are a couple of things to keep in mind.

- When you make a reservation, you have to give them your credit card number. If you do not give them a 24 hour notice for cancellation, they will charge you $25 PER PERSON.
- If you want to sit at the sushi counter, you must order omakase, which is market price.
- If you order the assorted sushi or sashimi, they do not let you substitute even if you have an allergy.

ニューヨークに住む知り合いからも情報を集め、その中で比較的お手頃で良さそうな店を選んだはずだったんですが、正直がっかりしました。美味しくなかったとは言いませんが、この値段でこの程度なのかというのが実感です。
Overpriced for quality but exceptional service. The wait staff is so friendly and attentive. The quality of fish isn't bad but compared to the price point it is far lower than where it should be.

Understated interior decor hides what should be a Michelin rated restaurant. Try the omakase at the bar and order a bottle of sake. You won't be disappointed. Prices are actually more affordable than other highly rated sushi bar.

Excellent sushi omakase. Best Hokkaido Uni I've had since Tokyo. Rice is very tasty and on point. Sushi size very ever so slightly too small. Tad bit rushed by wait staff because of their cadence in approach, not because they're actually rushing you. Price was just right but that should be the cap for this place.

Terrible place. Showed up at my reserved time, which was 8pm, but apparently was a little close to closing time? The older sushi chef looked at our order of omakase and gave us a look of disgust and shook he's head at us. I looked at the waitress and asked her if they was a problem. And she couldn't say anything. Why would then take a reservation at the bar at that time if they couldn't serve us what we wanted? We just stood up and left. Terrible service where service should be too priority.
Good Sashimi & Sushi prepared by a highly practiced Japanese sushi chef at affordable prices in a authentically appointed restaurant in Manhattan NYC. What's not to like?

Who sits at an omakase meal, talking about food and exchanging restaurant information with other patrons for hours on end while enjoying dinner?....you know who you are, Yelpers!

Ushiwakamaru came highly recommended by chef Gen-San at Yui Edomamae...so with no hesitation we bookmarked and made a reservation for our New York Trip.

We had to literally go through a snow storm to get here, but were warmly greeted by the hostess and our server Aiko-San.

Behind the sushi bar stands Chef Hideo-San and his team, though behind Chef Hideo-San there were many cluttered items...a rice cooker, computer screen, papers, etc...as I looked at the slightly disordered setting I was wondering if we had made a mistake. Fortunately, we had not. The food was very good; nigiri after nigiri appeased the hopes of our discerning taste buds. While not at the 5 star level of our local chef Gen-San at Yui, it was also at a more affordable price.

At the end, my love and I enjoy chef's offerings, and new friends we met during our dinner, but I would not seek  out here next time I am in NY.

-2017 review #34-

Fantastic meal sitting at the sushi bar across from chef Hideo Kuribara.

It was fascinating to watch him work: Each of his movements was precise, purposeful, and understated. Each piece of fish was an explosion of multi-dimensional flavor.

What an experience!

Nondescript entrance into a simple floor plan, Ushiwakamaru smelled a little bit like a fish market. It looked clean and rather spacious for just us and 3 other couples. It was still early. We were seated in the middle of the long bar in front of Chiro (let's call him), a Japanese man of about 65 with a shy smile.

Janice (let's call her), our server asked if we'd like tea or sake straight away and if we are opting for the 12 or 18 course omakase. We selected 18- sashimi styled. Janice asked if we'd prefer dry, sweet or something in the middle. I didn't  know the difference so she kindly brought 3 sake samples. It was determined that I liked dry. But I wasn't very sold on that particular one so Janice brought 3 more samples of only dry sake to try. Although sparse on words, the service was consistent and ample with warm smiles. Our chef who rarely made eye contact was busy the whole time prepping courses. Of course I would pointedly ask what each item was, sometimes twice because Chiro had a thick accent but he was always gracious, shy and smiling.

We started with baby sea eel- cool, smooth gelatin with a bite coupled with refreshing ginger lemon ponzu. By itself the eel was textually interesting but had no flavor.

Octopus- sweet and al dente meat with a silken center, the crunchy suction cups were the most delectable and fun to eat. Paired with lemon, salt and pepper.

Mackerel- lightly salted and reminiscent of the sea, it was sweet, robust, succinctly mackerel finely slivered with scallions and topped w ginger.

Medium belly tuna- luscious, flavorful tender tuna we were instructed to dip in soy but really, it didn't need anything.

O-toro fatty tuna- top seared for flavor and textural difference with sea salt, the belly utterly melts unto our palette. The buttery oils released from the small servings were incredibly bountiful, flavorful and very delicious.

Goldeneye snapper- a touch of sear to the skin to bring out the flavor profile of a perfect fish. Almost if you crossed a cod with yellowtail, goldeneye imparts hearty richness with the translucent snap of a lighter, vibrant breed.

Ikura- delicate little bowls filled with the sweetest big eye fish roe swimming in dashi  mixture. Funnily, it wasn't salty like it usually is; I couldn't tell if it was a palette cleanser nor could I get enough of it.

The coursing concluded with cooked "daddy" sea eel was a cute touch. Ushiwakamaru is a wonderful restaurant for solid omakase that's under the radar. The decor and sushi are minimally dressed, no air, service genuine- to the point, and best of all, fish flavor is maximally ensured.

The service and omakase were impeccable. Pricey but great experience. We even saw the chef the next day on the neighborhood and he recognized us and said hello! We were going to be a few minutes late and the restaurant accommodated us. Very unheard of for New York City. We really appreciated their flexibility. It seemed like a lot of the patrons were locals. While sitting at the sushi bar there were conversations being had amongst groups. Very welcoming atmosphere for New York.

Slightly better than 3 stars but definitely not a 4.

Came here with my boyfriend for dinner. The space and decor as others have said leave something to be desired.

Overall the service was good and attentive with a couple hiccups and fish was fresh. So why only 3 stars? I expect an Omakase to wow me, otherwise I'd just order 9 pieces of salmon and 9 pieces of toro and call it a day for less money. I also didn't feel too great a few hours after finishing dinner - I don't know if it was the sushi, but who knows.

Service:
The server did not give us hot towels when we sat down, we didn't know they even did this until we saw other tables getting this. Not good.

We both ordered the sushi only Omakase (miso soup, 18 pieces and a dessert) and a bottle of Sake, which was very tasty.

Unfortunately they must've thought we said Sushi/sashimi Omakase (you get a choice of only sushi or part sashimi) because they brought us out a mix sashimi portion to start - not good.

When we flagged the mistake they apologized and started work on the Sushi pieces (18 total) only. I think the kitchen staff got to eat the sashimi pieces which they were probably excited about.

Food:
For the amuse bouche, they brought me simmered tuna, which was very good. It had yummy teriyaki and soy undertones.

They did not have a gluten free amuse bouche for my boyfriend. Kind of disappointing given the price point, they could've literally brought out anything for him (a piece of pickled ginger even) and called it amuse bouche. Note that they do have gluten free soy sauce and they don't put any soy on the fish when you're not at the counter so you can control how much you want yourself at the tables.

Now onto the fish. There is no disputing that the fish tasted very fresh. Since we weren't at the sushi counter, they brought out the sushi in 3 plates of 6. I would suggest booking at the counter rather than at a table, but you can't book that through open table.

First plate of pieces:
I just did not generally like the sushi on the first plate. The only ones I remember were the first 2, which were both shrimp. I actually liked these - they had a creamy flavor and consistency.

The second plate of pieces were much better and probably the best of the 3 plates:
Barracuda - This was lightly smoked, very tasty
Snapper - A little chewy, not my favorite
King Salmon - Oh salmon why do I love you so
King of Yellowtail - Also liked this piece a lot
Stripped jack - Slimey consistency but good flavor
Big eye Snapper - Charred edges but pretty good

The third plate of sushi was probably second in performance:
King crab - Meh it's just crab
Uni - I must not have the palate for this and I just really don't get it, tastes like metal and the consistency grosses me out
Spicy cat fish roe - really distinct taste with spicy after taste, not my favorite
Blue fin tuna- it was good but just tuna, nothing special about it
Sea Perch - had a slightly torched flavor, soft and very good
Fatty tuna - Melt in mouth good!

At the end they asked if we wanted any extra pieces, as a salmon lover I ordered an extra of King salmon and my boy friend the King of Yellowtail. The king salmon was only $5! And the king of Yellowtail was $10.

Soba noodles came before dessert. I really did not care for this, I guess I don't like soba noodles.

Dessert:
We also got a choice for dessert - I chose the mochi (they only have vanilla flavor - come on add green tea!)

They were out of the gluten free option - again disappointing given the price point.

With Sake (100 bottle), the food (135 pp Omakase + extra pieces) and tip it was $250 each. I could've ordered 18 pieces of the king salmon for $90 and loved every piece instead of liking about 5 pieces out of 18 for $135.

Other Omakases in the city that I've had seem to do more with the fish in terms of torching, marinating, etc., but here they seem to just rely on the freshness of this fish, which although without a doubt fresh just bored me.

So, I likely won't be back, for the price there are better options in the city.

I really wanted to like Ushiwakamaru more. I really did. I had high hopes going in but found myself oddly disappointed - especially for a place that has a Michelin star. To be clear, I went for omakase sushi and sat at the bar.

While it was good, my mind wasn't blown. It felt like more of a standard than stand out experience. The fish/seafood quality was good but there was nothing special about what we were served. Also the chef's interaction was pretty minimal. Typically, there's a story behind each piece and we were just served normally, which took away from the experience.The other service was pretty standard as well. Attentive but nothing outside normal for a restaurant of this caliber.

One thing to note: you can mix your omakase with a few other chef dishes rather than the nigri only.

It's worth checking out once but I wouldn't go back. Especially given how many better omakase options are in NYC.

It feels unfair that we were the only customers in this great restaurant while places like Karomi, Yasuda are fully booked  - they are at the same caliber and I might say Ushiwakamaru is better on certain dishes, even more so if you count costs. It deserves to be crowded

Beautiful, memorable experience and perhaps the greatest sushi I've had - or at least up there with my other favorite sushi meal at Tsukiji Fish Market in Tokyo. A Michelin star well deserved. My husband and I joined some friends for dinner who come to Ushiwakamaru fairly frequently, so they had some great tips on ordering. I went with the nigiri platter and our group shared some starters including fermented squid, monkfish liver, and an incredible steamed egg custard pudding with shrimp and white fish. Umami to the max!

My nigiri was otherworldly and so absurdly fresh - the platter included fatty tuna, salmon, spot shrimp, white fish, tuna, sea urchin, salmon roe, eel, and tamago (plus half a toro roll). The quality is just awe-inspiring. Somehow we kept ordering more and I'm so glad we did - another highlight was essentially a flight of tuna. Fatty, toro, soy marinated... wish I remembered exact specifics. Regardless, we'll definitely be returning to delve deeper into the menu.

We've been to the previous location of Ushiwakamaru, so it's good to be back to their new location. I called to book the sushi bar for omakase, and it wasn't too hard to get weekend reservation if you are okay with 6pm seating.

Everything was what I remembered - courteous services, modest interior design, authentic feel. We ordered all sushi omakase, which started off with green tea tofu and miso soup. I've never had green tea tofu before, definitely something new. Miso soup is not overly salty, and it's enriched by a shrimp head. After that, the chef started putting in front of us rounds after rounds of amazing sushi. When it first started, rice was a little too hot, but maybe chef also realized that, after the first two, everything turned out to be just perfect.

Here are some highlights:
- Slightly tourched sea eel: so so tender. Not overly fatty, but it was so flavorful and soooo tender.  
- Japanese white shrimp: I though the texture would be chewy, but it literally melted in my mouth.
- Fried shrimp head: Japanese doesn't waste anything, so authentic places usually fry the shrimp heads after using the shrimp body for sushi. This shrimp head is perfectly fried, crunchy, flavorful, simple yet delicious.
- Medium tuna: I've developed my liking for medium and lean tuna after eating at Sushi Nakazawa several times. It doesn't taste as fatty as toro, but it still melts in your mouth. What can I say, I LOVE tuna.
- Squid: I've never had squid nigiri before, this was a first. It tasted like pickled squid, nothing too chewy but had some texture to it.
- Japanese Uni: do I need to say anything more about that?

So here's the verdict: rice was a little too warm at first, but they corrected it; light on soy comparing to some other sushi places. With price tag of $130 per person, we each had 18 pieces of amazing nigiri, including usual items such as amberjack, mackerel, tuna, uni, to a little more unconventional items like needlefish, squid, Japanese white shrimp. I enjoyed every piece of it, and I definitely would love to be back.

This is always the finest fish, the broadest selection, served with impeccable service on the finest rice.

Somehow the atmosphere is not quite as inviting as other edomae style restaurants, but the food is objectively excellent at all times, year after year.

This is still one of my favorite sushi experiences in the city. With a new sushi joint popping up every other block, Ushiwakamaru stands out by keeping the focus on the fish: quality, presentation and attention to details (temperature of the rice, etc.). Minimal and nothing in excess, a piece of nigiri or sashimi is the perfect bite that melts in your mouth, bursting in flavor.

The beads of home-cured Ikura is unforgettable and the spicy tuna roll is like medallions of glistening jewels - abstract art.

Each piece of fish is unique in cut and placed perfectly on the slate.

They served a dark roasted green tea complimentary which rounded out the meal beautifully. The home made black sesame ice cream with red bean sauce is a must!

Will have to go back for Omakase!

It's been three years since my first experience at Ushiwakamaru and honestly, if you want a more detailed review, go to my first one. My 2 cents is still the same here because always keep an opened mind on food and just let the sushi chefs serve you, especially if it is Chef Hideo. My husband and I have come to this establishment for maybe 4-5 times now and by no means does this mean we are a regular but every time we come, everything is still perfect. This time, we came for his 30th birthday because he wanted something he loves (sushi) while being perfectly casual and comfortable (so no eleven madison park). Since our reservation was the earliest time slot (6PM), we were seated in front of Chef Hideo and like always, he served us while explaining each piece. I knew I didn't go with the wrong dinner spot because each piece brought a smile to my husband's face as well as my own (especially the otoro!!). Plus this time, we got to a new thing which was the monkfish liver (my husband was super impressed by me not thinking it didn't taste good - in fact, I liked it because it was interesting!). And from 2017 to 2020, my palette has evolved and I have grown to really appreciate uni and the uni here was creamy and delicious.

If you haven't tried the omakase here, what's stopping you?

Ushiwakamaru is a solid Michelin-starred sushi restaurant. The omakase is fairly priced at $135 for 15 pieces, a hand roll, miso soup, and dessert.

The nigiri pieces were good for the most part. The chef loves to use a bit more wasabi than usual, and some pieces were fishy. The big 3 (toro, anago, uni) were great, but not the best I've had. But the trout and the hand roll were pretty awesome. The chef's serving pace was slower than expected, the other staffs' service was on point.

Ushiwakamaru in my opinion is the best fine dining sushi in all of New York City! I was blown away over the delicious Otoro Bluefin Fatty Tuna. It was just as good as when I had it in Japan. I highly recommend this place & literally cannot go back soon enough! Like most fine dining sushi expect to drop a few hundred dollars on dinner but it's so worth it! If you're looking for good sushi in the city, check this place out! I would skip competitors like '15East Restaurant' which I did not feel was of equal quality or worth the price. Go to Ushiwakamaru you will not be disappointed!
Had the omakase here. Overall, I'll have to give 5 stars, but I do have to say there are better alternatives at this price range.

Ushiwakamaru was awarded a Michelin star this year, which peaked my curiosity and led me to check it out. The prices here are very reasonable as far as both Michelin-rated restaurants and sushi restaurants in NYC go. For $66 you get a chef's tasting menu, complete with ~12 pieces of sushi, served in 2 courses.

The fish itself, ranged from divine to unexceptional. For example, the Toro melted in my mouth, but the Tako (octopus) and Salmon Roe did not taste any different than what I could have gotten anywhere else in NY. Overall, it was an amazing experience and worth the cost.

Pro tip: later reservation in the middle of the week, can be made a week in advance!

Also, Needlefish is not in season in September...who knew? Lol

I was one of first customers for this moved from West Village and re-opened Ushiwakamaru.

I made sure that his sushi still is one of the best in this City at first day party.
Dining room is obviously bigger and taller.
I saw few famillier sushi chefs in addition to owner chef, that also proof that we can get excellent sushi at any seats in the bar or table.

I just hope its easier to make sushi bar reservations now.
Can't wait for my next visit.
Kanpai!!

I LOVE OMAKASE

I have to preface this review with the following caveats
1)  I cannot recall each item I was served during my 20 piece Omakase
2)  I was dining with a long time friend and colleague who had just moved on to another job, when I said Sushi??? he said yes, when I said, how about Chef's choice?  he said yes. I was estatic

So we walked in at 8 on a Thursday, no seats at the bar ( even though there were seats)  so we sat at a table.  He ordered the 14 piece, I the aforementioned 20 piece Sushi/Sashimi omakase.
I also augmented my appetizer to be the Monkfish liver, Ankimo which was fantastic.
All of the fish were fresh and outstanding.  I loved every minute of the meal, The sake flowed and the good times were reviewed.  Although pricey compared to the former location, I couldn't have been bothered by it at all. The service was great.   I am sooo glad I checked the new Ushiwakamaru off my to do list

the only cons were I wish I had gotten the custard app as well,  and that the live sweet shrimp did not come with the fried head...minor nitpicks that didn't effect my very enjoyable experience.  The space is clean, bright. The service was attentive and the fish was great.

Absolutely delicious omakase! They do serve more pieces than I'm use to. We had around 16 pieces each and I was beyond stuffed by the 16th piece. The fish is extremely fresh. I like that they serve more varieties of fish instead of dressing up the common ones like salmon and tuna. My favorite was the white shrimp, I've never had it before and I think it's better than sweet shrimp. It's buttery and melts right in your mouth.
Their miso soup appetizer was good and a little different since they added some seafood in to the broth.
Also if you have any room left at the end of this spectacular meal, I would recommend trying the homemade sesame ice cream for dessert!

It is on the pricy side, it came out to be about $170/person for Omakase.
We were so tired and just needed to sit and rest! There is plenty of seating in this quiet cosy cafe. It was also the best mocha latte I had during our 4-day visit to NYC.

I have passed by this conveniently located coffee shop many times.  It looked open, airy, and artsy with the Gallery display. I also liked  the appearance of sufficient space between tables and chairs, so patrons do not feel cramped. The music is loud but not overwhelming. The people can be loud around you but not too distracting that you can't drown them out.

I saw the cute shortbread teddy bear-looking pastry. It was all I really wanted.

The tables and chairs are clean. I found a perfect table with an outlet to plug in my computer. The only thing is that previous folks left their Urbana cups on the table and didn't clean up after themselves. I never saw a stay member come by to monitor the place or clean up anything.

The only thing I found annoying is that once you pay using Square for your order, they automatically enroll you in their rewards program without asking.

Urbana is one of the most aesthetically pleasing cafes i've ever been to, and coming from me, that says a lot .  All the plants just give is such a lively, cozy vibe. This is the perfect spot whether you need to get some work done, or catch up with a friend. As far as the drinks go, you can tell they use quality ingredients and everything is absolutely delicious, and I'm picky when it comes to my drinks. 10/10 highly recommend.

So glad this new coffee shop opened up near my apt.  Clean, minimalist interior with nice splash of greenery to give you a calm vibe.  Great service, employees are very nice, wifi is fast, plenty of seating, including a bench across the front windows.  They also had an assortment of tasty looking baked goods, but I did not partake as I had just eaten lunch.  This will definitely be my go to spot!
It's a nice space in the neighborhood to do work. There's even a couch with coffee table books. I had the cheese danish which was yogurt-y. There's plants around and art for sale.

Where coffee meets art! A little oasis in Chelsea surrounded by plants and curated art. A nice chill vibe with a menu of coffee and baked goods. The cortado was excellent and had a nice heart design.
