You'll find seating for two at round tables and one couch with table for larger groups. They have a restroom too! Not too far from Chelsea Market.
Totally crushes all of the other coffee shops in Chelsea and Meatpacking.  Great coffee with delicious seasonal specials and friendly staff.  Also great wifi - I go there to work almost every day.
Decently priced coffee. Free Wi-Fi. Ample sitting area. Good vibes, nice barista. What's not to like about this place.
Tasty! Great lattes. Fun ambience and location. Great spot for work and for catching up with friends too.
Amazing coffee and lattes and tasty treats. The vibe is chill and relaxing, great place to catch up with friends, work or read.

I stopped at Urbana Cafe while on a break . I had some work to finish and needed a space. I stumbled on this cute spot. I love a nice coffee shop. I ordered a Chai Latte and apple turnover . It was delicious. The prices are reasonable and they have great food options, perfect for New Yorkers on the go. It's a productive,  modern and clean space and the staff is really friendly. I will be returning.

Since it opened I have been wanting to come in, since we live so close by. I was not disappointed. Coffee is great, roasted locally. The staff is very friendly. Nice spot to just relax and enjoy. Great location in Chelsea.
Best goddamn pink drink I ever poured down my gullet.  Starbucks, Schmarbucks.  Love you guys!
Coffee was served cold. Matcha latte was not good. We were initially excited for a neighborhood new coffee shop, but it was a disappointment

I wanted to hate it but I thought the burger was good. There's a lot of buts though when it comes to it. For one, service wasn't the fastest. I saw people who ordered after me get their food first. I saw people who ordered before me still waiting. As for the burger itself, too expensive. It's a good burger but I paid $15. I do not believe I got my money's worth. It didn't fill me and I had some issues with it. For one, there was barely cheese on it. I reached a point in my burger where there was no more cheese. I also tried the fries, best I can say is that they're not the worst fries. Bottom line, save your money and go somewhere else. It's a good burger but that's all it is. Your money is better spent elsewhere.

There is nothing exactly redeemable from this establishment. Their hours are completely ridiculous with it only being open before 3 pm now. Before it was 4 pm.
This is what $19 looks like with fries and the og umami burger. The patty is small, the umami sauce tastes similar to Big Mac sauce. Where's the umami? It was pretty tasteless. The fries were mediocre enough that I gave some away to my friend. The quality wasn't anything to compliment. The soda machines weren't working when I was there. Honestly this burger is not in the same leagues as big burger chains like five guys, shake shack, or smash burger even though it's smaller, less flavorful and more expensive.

Food was disgusting

Only finished it because I paid and waited 15 minutes for it

Their classic sandwich is a fried chicken sandwich with their house special sauce and pickle slices. The chicken was beyond burnt, dry and tasteless

It was the kind of chicken where it'll scrape up the roof of your mouth if you aren't careful eating it

Their mac and cheese was just corkscrew cavatappi pasta with powdered cheese sprinkled on top. This was tasteless and looked just as sad as the staff working there
Pretty delicious burger! I ordered instead of dining in. Great for lunch. I ate their burger before, and I routinely circle back to it. Very nice.
Slow service but amazing taste! A little on the pricey side but in line with everything else at the food court here

If you want to pay $50 for two burgers and fries sure...but at least aim for happier staff. Not one person behind the counter looked like they care about their job at all. They all looked bothered af when we walked up and didn't even say hello. Not the kind of unhappy people you want making your food. Weird location too, it feels like a food court in an airport. Hard pass.

Me, my fiancée, and my best friend were visiting New York City, we were looking for a nice steakhouse for dinner.  We saw this place close to where we were staying, so we decided to go here.

When we walked in, we were greeted by the staff and taken care of right away.   The service was very professional and top notch.  

We all ordered steaks and they were some of the best steaks we've ever had!  They were cooked just right and melted in our mouth.  It was totally worth the price.

If you're looking for a nice dining experience for a date or to celebrate a special occasion, definitely consider this steakhouse!

Ok experience! I Expected more for the price point. After arriving the hostess assigned us the seat right behind the hostess stand where we got to experience the calming sound (sarcastic)  of her slamming the menus against the partition. We had earlier asked if we could be seated someplace else and the hostess refused even though the restaurant was mostly empty.

The main course was really good! The Filet was perfectly prepared and Pork chop with sides were really good. For dessert I had the Apple pie which was very tart and dry.( the waitress was really nice and took it off the bill)  The cheesecake was really good.

The hostess assigned two ladies to sit next us, and they immediately asked for another place to sit, as they also were not happy with the seating in that area; however, they were immediately seated somewhere else.

This being our first time in New York City, we dressed up really nice and wanted to give this place a try.  

Overall - Main course was really good, Service from our waitress was good. Hostess could have tried to get us another table, but was not having it and was rude.

Would have been nice if the GM checked in with us, like he did with other tables. Would have rather shared this with him rather than putting it on here.

Went to this pace for our first dinner, the location wasn't the best as the area was forgoing construction but the inside had a nice atmosphere. The inside has good lighting, it was slightly on the darker side and there was great spacing between the tables, giving customers a sense of privacy. The food was very pricey ($50-$300 for a steak (my steak was $55), and $36 for the daily catch, $12 for the side of mashed potatoes) as you would have expected from a higher end steakhouse. We got the 12oz filet mignon with mash potatoes and the daily fresh catch seafood. The wait time was long and the food was creamy and had a good texture but not worth the price. What we didn't like about the restaurant was that our server kept on trying to upsell us and push us to order more sides or higher end steaks. The filet mignon had a tender texture, cooked under well temperature but lacked flavor. As for the seafood dish, the creamy sauce was mainly on the side vegetables and the fish steak itself lacked flavor. Overall, the restaurant gave off business professional vibes and everyone was well-dressed. Overall we would give it a 3/5 because we didn't think the food was worth the price but the restaurant is ideal if you want to treat out your business partner or discuss contracts. We provided a little breakdown below:

Overall: 3.3/5
Food: 3.5/5
Service: 3/5
Price: 2/5
Cohesiveness (in terms of overall flow of the restaurant): 4/5
Atmosphere: 4/5

Walking around the west side looking for a spot to eat, the man and I ended up wandering into Uncle Jack's. Classically designed steakhouse that kinda looks like your Italian dad's joint--a lot of wood, richly textured fabrics and dimly lit. That's not a bad thing. Super nice, well-trained staff without being too stuffy. Drinks came out quickly. Food took a bit longer than expected given the hour, but it was good. The man got the branzino (headless) and I got the salmon. Both surprisingly were overcooked, but still tasty. The a la carte mashed potatoes could've been a little more flavorful, but they were fine. My wedge salad was good. Could've used a bit more bacon and blue cheese.

Glad we kept walking by all of the burger joints and ended up here. Good time!

Was really looking forward to eating here based upon a friend's recommendation, however we were let down by the food.  Ordered the 8 ounce filet rare and it came out not rare but more medium and no real flavor.  The service was adequate overall, but did keep our drinks constantly filled.  The loaded baked potato was very good.  The chocolate mousse was not as fluffy or smooth as it could have been. My husband's hamburger was the best thing that was eaten at the restaurant.  The restaurant's ambiance was nice and comfortable.  Overall, the restaurant was so-so, especially for the high price.
service is good & food is even better! The ambiance is beautiful very classy & up scale definitely worth the money

I came here short on time and had the crab cakes; the Caesar salad, and a burger... everything was great. I didn't plan on coming here but it was the only bar in the short vicinity I was willing to walk and I wasn't let down. My server was a decent. Towards 9pm around closing time they started cleaning up pretty fast but I wasn't rushed at all. The drinks were great and upon leaving I had one more which ended up being on the house. Greatly appreciated. From what I saw their steaks look d phenomenal and I'm actually looking forward to coming in for a real dinner when I have more time. This place is a bit of a hidden gem & I highly recommend if your in the Penn Station area.

Excellent steaks. Pricey. Nice atmosphere. Very well-stocked whiskey bar. Fresh oysters and seafood. Interesting seasoning, like nutmeg in the creamed, spinach, chicken broth infused in the asparagus. Decent wine selection. Heavy duty forks and steak knives. Well trained staff. This place earns all five stars.
Had their wagyu burger for lunch. Excellent. Put the sauces on the side and it was a great indulgence.   Fries on the side and a few dips that come along , this was an excellent place for lunch.
Love me some octopus. Always good steaks and good service. Had the waygu streak - somewhat underwhelming for $195 but I tasted all steaks and they were good.

Service was top notch. Filet was good but not off the charts good. Sides were well prepared and the right portions.

Old school steakhouse feel except there was a bar with sports on TV.

A huge shout out to Mark the manager and the staff they were all amazing. The food was fantastic and service was on point. Steaks and chops were juicy and well seasoned and sides were large and drinks were good too. As for the atmosphere, old school New York, 40s vibe. Very Nice! Will definitely be going back!

While the service was very good and friendly, overall food experience was only okay. The Caesar salad was surprisingly really good, but the steak was asked medium rare, and just tasted over cooked. I think the bacon took away from the steak even though I religiously get blue cheese for my steaks. I usually love creamed spinach but did not care for this one. Of spending $100+ per person would expect a little better quality.

10/10 would recommend!
Absolutely delicious steaks. The baked clams and oysters Jackefeller were very delicious. We ordered a second round of baked clams. The ambience was very nice and I would definitely return.
The service was excellent. GREAT time and DELICIOUS food with even GREATER people. Recipe for the best of times and memories.

The decor is nice and the wait staff is very respectful! The food was ok in my opinion. My table ordered some tuna tartar, lamb lollipops, and bacon wrapped shrimp to start. They were all good but not blow your mind amazing. I ordered a wagyu burger and sweet potato fries. The wagyu was not how I expected and was a slight gray color. It was a fine burger but the butter sauce was overpowering the taste. The sweet potato fries were not as crispy as I was expecting. This was an overall ok experience.

We had dinner here two nights ago with our children and right from the start the service was excellent. Food fantastic! Our waiters were always attentive and we even spoke with the manager. The manager was very lovely as well and even surprised us with a beautiful dessert spread! Was not expecting that. Like I said...top notch service from start to finish! We come to the city often so we will definitely be back here!

I've heard amazing things about this steak house so we gave it a try. Our host was pleasant our waitress not so much. After taking our initial order we had to flag her down for anything else we needed. She was much more attentive to the new tables, one were she could speak Spanish and one that was larger.
My food was mid. I had much better steak at other steakhouses. The garlic mashed potatoes were decent though. I had the tiramisu for dessert and it was pretty good. It comes with random berries.

Food was good, me and my friend were really hungry and scarfed it all down in like ten minutes lol.

The corn brûlée was to die for.

Service was okay, we waited like 25 minutes before the waiter even asked us for our drink order.....
The service was impeccable. They sat us immediately. Only thing is the steak wasn't season to perfection. Was a little bland.

Large dining area with bar seating. This spot is perfect to dine in if you're looking to grab some food and watch some sports. Servers were attentive. The food I would rate it 3/5. Dessert was heavy and thick. Appetizers were decent, nothing too fancy. Steak was a 3/5.

I've been to Uncle Jacks before but the Bayside location. Yesterday was my first venture into the Manhattan location for a work lunch. We made reservations beforehand because it typically gets a little busy around lunchtime with all the office spaces, jobsites etc. nearby. Entered and was greeted warmly by the hostess who promptly seated us. Service top to bottom was superb. Staff was friendly, addressed all needs in a timely manner and accommodated to whatever was asked. For appetizers we had the bacon which was a great balance of sweet and salty - definitely recommend. For my main course, I got the Prime Rib which was cooked exactly to my medium rare request. Great char and crust on the outside and the meat was as juicy and tender as I could have wanted. Delicious for sure. Side dishes wise - we got the garlic mashed, five cheese mac and broccoli. All very solid as a whole. The mac and cheese was an interesting blend of cheeses, in a good way. There was a nice sharpness to the cheese which I enjoyed coupled with the steak. For dessert I ordered old reliable: the banana cream pie. It was a little on the sweet side from me but it wasn't to the point of being mind numbingly sweet and cavity inducing. Props to them for the fresh fruit on the plate though, the strawberries and blueberries were absolutely delicious and perfectly ripe. Certainly will be coming back!

Made a dinner reservation @ Uncle Jack's for me & my son, before a Knicks Playoff game. Obviously, I didn't read the online Menu too carefully, bc I got "sticker shock!" I arrived early & ordered an ordinary Bourbon "Manhattan" on the rocks at the bar (bar brand bourbon, nothing special.) It was $18, as was a Rye "Old Fashioned" for my son. After we were seated, and perused the Dinner Menu, we decided to pass on the $149 Porterhouse Steak (for two); and had a good laugh as the server attempted to talk us into ordering the "Australian Wagyu Beef" at (get this) $12 PER  OUNCE. Instead, we opted to split two "special sandwiches " - a "Big Jack Burger" and what sounded like a gourmet Steak Sandwich, served with Gorgonzola Cheese, caramelized onions, mushrooms and a side of "herb-infused" fries. Kudos to the menu copywriter. What arrived at the table -- for "only $25" each -- were two puny, unappetizing, and "nearly meatless" sandwiches.
If I were the Owner (or Uncle Jack, himself) I would be mortally embarrassed to serve these "White Castle rejects" to a patron in the Ozarks ... let alone to a Knicks fan, a couple of blocks from Madison Square Garden.
Anyway, our much anticipated pre-game meal with three drinks, total set this diner back almost $150, incl. tip.
While the service and ambiance was lovely, it could not overcome the tiny, overcooked, and way overpriced food. The next time I go to MSG, the game will be "You Don't Know Jack!" In other words, we will likely take a happy detour to the "Five Guys Burgers & Fries," which is right around the corner.

In other words ... Hit the Road, Jack!

Went to Uncle Jack's looking forward to a special pre-game meal with my son, before a Knicks Playoff game. Guess I didn't look carefully enough at the online Menu ... I think I got "sticker shock!" After ordering three simple "bar rack/non- brand" cocktails at the bar -- which were $18 apiece -- (plus a $10 tip), we cleverly decided to pass on the $149 Porterhouse Steak (a la carte, for two); or the "Australian Wagyu Beef" the waiter attempted to talk us into, at  get this -- $12 per OUNCE -- I figured we would be happy (and likely full) sharing a Medium Rare "Jack's Special" Burger, and a Steak Sandwich. What we received -- for "only" $25 each -- were two of the puniest "nearly meatless" bread dominant sandwiches I have ever ordered, especially in a so-called upscale NYC steakhouse.
If I were the Owner, I would be mortally embarrassed to serve these "White Castle rejects" to a paying customer in the Ozarks, let alone to a Knicks fan, only a couple of blocks from Madison Square Garden.
Anyway, our much anticipated pre-game dinner "only" set this NJ diner back $150, or so. Next time I go to MSG, the "game" will be ... "You Don't Know Jack!", and I will likely opt for the "Five Guys Burgers & Fries" ... which is right around the corner.

In other words ... Hit the Road, Jack!

I have been to every steakhouse in New York at least a dozen times each and some of them 2 and 3 dozen times each. This was by far one of the worst experiences I've ever had in a steakhouse. As we were going to a show, we ordered just 3 items. A pork chop a rib chop and a wagyu strip steak.  We also ordered bacon blue cheese sauce for the side.

The wagyu steak came out with so much cartilage and was very cold in the center and I ordered it rare so I know that I should expect a lukewarm to cool center but not like it just came out of the refrigerator.

The rib chop came out overcooked and the 1st 3 slices were literally white hard pieces of fat and on the top side the 1st 2 slices were fat. 5 slices were of actual meat.

The wagyu was $150, told the waiter this was the worst piece I've ever had, and he did nothing about it.

It took a long time for our drinks to come brinks to come and our blue cheese sauce never arrived even after I brought it to the attention of our waiter who delegated the responsibility to somebody else who never brought it up.

Additionally, my steak strip was advertised as 16 oz.   Nonsense. I even asked three times if the waiter was sure I wasn't given the 8 oz by accident. I felt cheated.

I'm in a steakhouse 3 times a week. This was not good.

Easily one of the best places I've ever eaten. Everything was cooked to perfection.  I had the prime NY steak, lobster Mac and cheese and salmon. The salmon was nice and fresh. I had a medium-well steak which was full of flavor especially after I added the roasted garlic and herb sauce to top it off. The greens were sautéed so nicely. My favorite had to be the lobster Mac and cheese though was nice and creamy. Would highly recommend this steakhouse if your on the west side of Manhattan

A pretty reasonably priced steak place in NYC Midtown with great food, great atmosphere and great drinks. I think I spent less here than at Charley's or Ruth's Cris for the same quality food. Highly recommend and I will return next time in NYC

Place could use an update. Worn out looking and not in that homey/comfy way.   Even the A/C was out and the portable units were not cutting it.  The drinks ... well their Manhattan was generous but not what i would call a Manhattan (Josephine's on 42 st makes the best in the city by the way). But! The steaks were quite good! Did not expect such a good cut and prep in an older, somewhat tourist driven place. Worth it for the steaks.

Came here after my husband reviewed a few other places. Almost all the places we wanted to go to were fully booked, so we decided on coming here. My husband was celebrating his birthday and wanted a steak. 6 months pregnant, I just wanted something very simple so I ordered a salad. The location was nice the restaurant was nice. Everyone was very attentive and friendly from the get go. We first ordered the Crab Cakes which were alright, nothing too crazy. I ordered a Caesar Salad which was good. I mean it was a salad after all can't really mess that one up, the croutons were great. My husband order the Tomahawk steak which was not good, it was extremely charred on the outside. I had one bite and asked my husband to return it. It was so overdone it lost the meat flavoring. My husband being the nice person that he is, did not and just didn't finish the steak.
Overall, the experience was alright. The food took sometime to actually come out to us, just for it to be mediocre compared to the prices paid. The service was nice and they were attentive. Maybe it was just a off night, not sure.

Absolutely do not waste your money in this place. This is the 4th time we have been here, due to the location and ambience. Trying to be hopeful that it will improve but last night was the worst ever!
2 hours from the time we ordered (party of 4) until our food was served, and 2 of the orders were inedible!! No manager anywhere in sight. Sad !!

From the start, an overwhelming amount of flavor experience here. The salad was perfect with the freshest tomatoes and lettuce.

I ordered the basic steak and I expected nothing less than perfection. They delivered one of the finest steaks I have ever had.  If you are staying in the Times Square area this is a must visit.

No disappointment here!  If you love steak, this is the place to enjoy!!

Generally speaking Uncle Jacks is a traditional steak house. We went on Valentines Day so it was very busy. I was a little put off when my porterhouse steak came rare and I ordered it well done. A steak house of this caliber should not make such a mistake. The server was also cold as ice. She had no personality despite being in a beautiful space collecting what could be substantial tips. They don't serve sangria either which was a surprise considering the wine list and bar capacity.

My daughter and I tried this place while in town for her 16th birthday. The staff were great and attentive but we were not at all impressed with the food. The oysters jackefeller was insanely greasy and salty, the ribeye had a lot of fat and my daughter described as "rubbery and tasteless". The sides (garlic mashed and brocolli) were yummy but that was about it. We even tried to redeem the meal with some NY style cheesecake but it was so flavorless. If I'm going to eat all those calories I need all the flavor ‍ My daughter who is a cheesecake connoisseur said it was one of the worst she has ever had. I was super sad this place wasn't what we had expected

This place is a solid neighborhood steakhouse. Solid location next to the Garden. Don't understand why people would judge it less than 4 star. Staff is solid. Steak is aged between 35 and 100 days. All cuts of beef are solid. Also solid bar selection (French 75, BT old fashion, and Rip Van winkle 10 or 12 yr was solid). Solid food, nice job. I will be back.

We stumbled upon this cute little steakhouse and it was absolutely Devine! We got the oysters (raw), the bacon wrapped shrimp and the NY strip steak and everything was sooo good! We ended the night with the lava cake and I have got to say it was the best lava cake was soooo soo good! Would definitely recommend this place. Our waiter was absolutely amazing as well!

Not great and menu is not accurate. Food is overpriced for what it is. Salmon cooked horribly. Steak was decent. 4 shrimps for $21??

I would avoid this place

Food is as great as always! Sergio as an amazing accommodating waiter. They were kind and fun for our kids. One of our steaks was over cooked but with no questions asked they brought us a new one!!
Thank you!

Walked-in off the street in tourist gear, and were warmly greeted by the tuxedo-clad staff.  The manager, Ike, is a real character. He knew we were in NY celebrating our anniversary and made sure we were very well looked after. The place is a blast from the past - classic cocktails, excellently prepared steaks and huge sides. A/C was a lit loud, but honestly we were just glad to be cooled on a hot September day.

This place really lost their magic post-covid.
Food was okay. Service was sub par. I was here for friend's birthday. Improperly cooked Kobe beef.

Kobe beef while tasted good, wasn't cooked or served properly. I've had Kobe beef in Kobe, Japan before. And there they cook it piece by piece, cut into cubes, in front of you and serve it hot for you to eat in real time, one cube at a time. At Uncle Jack's it was all cooked and served  at the same time - very disappointing!

The service was also poor. They didn't bring the bread until I asked for it. I told the waiter that it was my friend's birthday. He said that he got me, and promptly forgot. Then my friend's wife did the same thing, and the waiter forgot again. She then reminded the waiter about the birthday cake and he brought the cake without singing happy birthday. My friend's wife then asked for a candle so they took back the desert and brought it back with a candle and sang a very low energy happy birthday.

The waiter avoided us after that and we had to get the manager to explain the situation. The manager then offered to comp us drinks.

They also charged a fee for using a credit card. I think it was 15%. The manager said that it was the same fee to use a debit card. The bill for this outrageous experience was almost $800 after the tip and 'card fee'.

Overall, the experience was disappointing to say the least. This place is acceptable if you just want steak, not Kobe Beef, and if you're not there for a special occasion. Otherwise it won't be difficult to find a better alternative.
Simply amazing. Something I would highly suggest going. One of the best steak houses I have been to

My family's absolute favorite steakhouse in the city. The tomahawk steak is actually not a bad deal and my 16-year-old ate the whole thing. I had the wagyu meatballs pretty good. The lamb chops were delicious as an appetizer. We really just love having a nice family meal with the impeccable service at this classic New York steakhouse.
What a terrific place! We had a great time and that was mostly because of the manager Mark. What a legend.
Deena at the bar is amazing!!! She makes you feel like family.  The food is also top notch.  This place is a hidden gem!!

We ordered two of the exact same thing (bone-in filet) for a business meeting.  My colleague had a good cut with plenty of meat; however, mine was basically all bone and fat with very little actual meat.  Both the front desk host and GM made excuses about how this cut of meat has more fat than others (that doesn't explain the disparity between my cut and that of my colleague) and they rudely argued with me in front of my guest that there was nothing they can do about it.  In 20+ years of eating at steakhouses all over the country, I've never had a more horrible cut of bone-in filet than here.  After three rounds of back and forth arguing, they finally only took 50% off of the price for my steak (any other establishment would've done much more automatically).  The lack of care and lack of ownership of issues exhibited at this establishment ensures (1) I will never set foot in here again and (2) I will advise all of my business colleagues to steer clear of this place and opt instead for one of the many other great steakhouses in New York.

Wow, it's post pandemic and Uncle Jack's Steakhouse has officially jumped the shark.  Your first introduction to the interior is some very friendly greeters at a podium.  This is quickly offset by the twin rental loud, noises portable air conditioners semi permanently attached to the front of building windows.

The menu is lacking, the steaks nothing to write to (except for the exceptional prices for average food), the sides are incredible high priced - $12.00 for one order of sauce, 20+ dollars for what turns out to be single servings of lobster Mac and cheese and potatoes.

Should avoid if at all possible. It's a terrible ending for once was a beacon of a steak house.  Hey even my home broiler hits 1,800 degrees.  Maybe it was something special in the past, but the past is the past.

Okey dokey I have had a lot of french dips in the city. The only other one that is even worth talking about is hillstone and this french dip beats that.  So juicy and moist with great flavor. I saw a review that said the au jus is bland, yeah right. The au jus is the bomb. The Gouda perfectly complements the steak. Served with pickles, coleslaw, and fries all of which are really good. I'll also add a note to myself that the soda carbonation is very good as well. Gonna try the Mac and cheese next time I'm here as the table in front of me is eating it and it looks good. Will try steak next time. Great job job!

A good bar / steak house. Seems to have been around forever. You walk in and it is out of the past. They great you at the door and then take you to your table. The menu is short and to the point. The wine list is like a book. Lots of choices - and some very rare vintages of great wines.

The steak are wonderful. Well aged to perfection. You can even sit near the meat locker and stare at cuts of meat you cant believe. The portions are huge.

Start with a drink and it is intense. Strong is a good word. The wine list offers up great choices. Definitely start with appetizers. We had the wagyu meatballs which were wonderful. Also an order of the tuna tartre. It is the size of a meal and you can eat it as a dinner. It was great. We then had filets, lamb chops, tuna (sushi grade) and cooked black and blue. Also a nice bronzini fish. You have to order the sides, so I recommend the brussel sprouts, the asparagus, and the mashed potatoes. The portions are large. the food cooked perfect. The service is old fashioned.

It is worth the trip through the door. The prices are not cheap, but then you get what you pay for.

I have walked passed this restaurant so many times but tonight is the first time I ever stopped in and had dinner. All I can say is wow! Guadalupe and EJ you guys rock! In the 30+ years I have been visiting NYC, I have never met anyone so genuine as you two. Thank you for your warmth and hospitality on this 11 degree night. I will definitely see you again! Bravo!

Went here for dinner with my sister one night. Our reservations were scheduled for 9pm. Our table was ready for us when we arrived.

The service was great. Quick and fast. The food was unbelievably tasty. For an appetizer we had the crab cake and raw oysters. We both ordered steaks and shared a loaded baked potato and wedge salad with blue cheese and bacon. We had margaritas and they were strong but GOOD.

I will certainly be back soon.

Rated it a 5 bc Yelp doesn't provide more stars. The food is to die for and the service is second to none. Danny the bartender is THE BEST!!  Sergio and Bernie are excellent servers.  Food prices are  reasonable considering its location.  Recently celebrated my mother in laws birthday and she's still raving over the food and drinks.

My husband had the wagu beef which he said was amazing.  I would not recommend the salads.  Be double sure your waiter understands what you are asking for if you plan on customizing - my waitress had a hard time understanding.

I have been here before years ago.  And was planning a night out for a Birthday present and what a perfect place to end the night but with a Steak.  My wife said why not come back to Brooklyn and said why I'm in NYC and I know a place to go. Uncle Jack's was my first choice.  Good food. Great atmosphere.  Staff are friendly.  Maitre D was friendly.  Recommend this steak restaurant to anyone.

After passing this cart several times while entering // exiting the Hudson Yards 7 train over the years, it made me sad that it took *Steve Cuozzo reviewing it in the NY Post on the eve of Hudson Yards' grand opening to try it myself. My once-feverish thirst of the unknown dormant, compromised! Only to be awaken by confirmation of peers in the media! But hey, better late than never.

Steve wasn't wrong. The burger here easily exceeds expectations, and in the shadow of a multi-billion dollar vertical shopping mall that's in some ways its own new neighborhood, it's all the more impressive.

The humble operation is a tiny street cart. You order, then pay the man who will both break your $20 bill and make the burger as you wait. It seems to come, by default, as a double patty cheeseburger. You can make it a combo by adding fries, but that's something I wouldn't recommend given the mismatched quality of the fries compared to the excellent burger. It's got Shake Shack vibes with two thin, medium cooked patties with melty American cheese and a delicious secret sauce. It comes on a routine hamburger bun that would look right at home on a grocery shelf in Anywhere, USA--but all-in-all the whole shebang is fabulous. And at $6, as referenced in the article, it might be the best thing anywhere in the Hudson Yards vicinity.

My lack of pictures of the product is intentional as I wasn't able to appropriately capture the brilliance of this burger. So you'll just have to play theater of the mind for now and make sure you stop by yourself for an IRL experience.

*Steve Cuozzo's write up in all its glory: nypost.com/2019/03/19/sk…

The burger with fries and a drink is now $29.18, the burger is not $6 anymore, rip off

They've also covered the "U.S Veteran"

Absolute scam, they've covered all their prices, save your money.

Sad excuse for a veggie omelet wrap. It was egg, cheese, and iceberg lettuce... not the peppers, onions and tomatoes that's shown in the photo and that I asked about. Also, I specifically said no cheese. There's $6 down the drain.

The burgers are awesome. Juicy flavorful. Cooked to order. I didn't try anything else but I will be back for more burgers!!! Save your visit for off hours otherwise the lines can be long. Plenty of places nearby to sit down and enjoy your burger.

$25+ FOR A BURGER?!

Like many, I've walked by this cart numerous times on the way to the 7 and because of the pandemic, I finally decided to throw some business their way while my friend was visiting. The cart is stripped of prices but I ordered two cheeseburgers with fries and was told to grab some drinks for the combo so he got a snapple and I got a coke. I offered to pay and was told, no just wait until the food was ready. When my name was called, I picked up the food and got told, $25EACH for a total of $50. For two burgers, fries, and drinks. From a food cart. I commented, you can't be serious?! And was told, "for Hudson Yards, here?! Yes!"

That was the end of the argument. My bad for not asking how much it would cost beforehand, but those prices are ridiculous. The burgers were fine but worth $7.50 at best, maybe a combo for $15 each would still be within reason. But at $25 each, not worth the price, sorry.
Total scam. Doesn't post prices. Doesn't tell you the price when you pay. And no receipt. For a (mediocre) burger, fries, and a drink. She charged 29.18. Complete highway robbery
Should have read the other reviews before stopping by this food cart for a late night meal. It's very much a scam. $20 for a crappy burger and cold fries. No thanks
This cart is by far the best in town! Burgers are analyzing! I usually get the lamb and chicken platters which taste much better than the carts around. The guys are also very friendly
Do not go here. Total scam. Make sure you ask the price first since they are not following NYs law putting prices out for the public before they buy.

This burger destroys all other NYC burgers. All my friends are all arguing In N Out this, Shack Shack that right now. They are wrong. Step off, jabronies. US Veteran burgers are big, juicy, stacked, slathered with tasty sauce and it's $6. Super satisfying. I steer all tourists over here. Everyone has agreed with me. End of burger wars, this is a one stop winner.

Hands down my favorite burger spot! Extremely clean, always fresh and so many options for breakfast and lunch. They also have chicken and rice!! Soo good! You'll find it right off of the 7 train. My family loved it when we checked out the vessel. Can't wait to go again!
Their burgers are fabulous very tasty . Amazing service
Wowza! These burgers a fantastic. The prices are great. The service is wonderful. In an area of chichi overpriced crap  this is a very welcome place.
Really solid burgers must try. A friend recommended to try them and they didn't dissapoiny.
I work around this area, don't go there , worker always smoking and serving food without cleaning his hands

One of my favorite restaurants in NYC.
Whenever I visit, Uncle Lou is a must.
Love reminiscing about the good old days with family and friends along with guaranteed delicious comfort food. Uncle Lou prepares classic dishes that my grandparents, parents, aunts and uncles consumed and enjoyed, and dishes I grew up with and continue to enjoy. It's quite amazing how food and particular dishes are able to transport individuals back in time, withstand time and pervade across generations.

Uncle Lou's menu is comprehensive, so plan on multiple visits so you're able taste every dish. Try starting with classic dishes found in the "Lo Wah Kiu Favorites." Every dish on the menu is delicious, some of my favorites include:

-Beef with string beans
-Lobster yee mein
-Crispy garlic chicken
-Fried salt and pepper frog
-Stuffed eggplant, chili peppers and fried tofu w black bean sauce
-Buddha's delight
-Stuffed tofu skin wraps
-Sautéed pea shoots

The ambiance is modern yet has a traditional festive vibe. A fun atmosphere overall. The service is friendly, and efficient.

Thank you Chefs and service team for continuing to churn out and serve delicious comfort dishes that span generations.

Unfortunately this was a disappointing overall experience, given the normally packed restaurant and the higher price point. The flavors were good, but not worth the price, with how many other Chinese restaurants there are in Chinatown.

I ordered takeout, and it was ready in 25 minutes. Fun area to walk around.

Stuffed Eggplants in Black Bean Sauce Dim Sum - $7.25 - this was my favorite - came with 4 pieces, good portion, good flavors
Kung Pao Shrimp - $25.95 - this was so much celery it could have been called stir-fry celery with a side of shrimp. The shrimps were also kinda small. The flavor wasn't very strong.
Oxtail Stew Casserole - $29.95 - this had bone on almost all pieces of beef, which was disappointing, when I was expecting a melting soft beef. It also had a lot of tendons, and minimal pieces of oxtail beef. Definitely feel this was not worth the price tag.
2 orders of white rice - $3
Total: $66.15
With tax: $72.77

The restaurant inside is well lit, nice lights and clean.
The man who took my waiter was very "what you want" vibe, which I'll take if you're super busy and your food is very good, but this was not the case.

3.5 stars

I think the food was decent, but having been raised on home-cooked Chinese food, it just didn't quite cut it for me. Rice rolls didn't have enough ingredients, I felt like I ate more rice roll than actual meat. Crispy garlic chicken was too oily and overly salted. The eggplant in garlic sauce was really good though!

This is a bustling place with modern decoration, large portions and fast service. I would come again if with friends if they wanted to eat here, but probably wouldn't be my first choice for Chinese food

I went to this spot twice. Both times were very crowded with one being in a group of 9 and the other with over 20. Loud spot with a lot of waitstaff. As it is a semi-nice spot and due to it's crowded nature, I'd compare the food to an extent to Wu's Wonton though as of the last couple Wu meals, I prefer this spot, I prefer this restaurant as it was more consistent.

The first time we had the following:

Stuffed Eggplants in Black Bean Sauce: These were stuffed with shrimp and fish and they were tasty. Good black bean sauce

Peking Pork Chops: Sauce had a good light sweetness. Not as good as Wu's and definitely not as meaty but still solid and less fried by comparison.

Pea Shoots Sautéed Fu Ru: Furu refers to red sautéed fermented bean curd and it paired nicely with the pea shoots. Good version of this dish.

Dried Scallop & Egg Fried Rice: Said fried rice also had raisins, bacon, and shrimp. The fried rice was OK. It was better than the cured meat fried rice we got the other time as it was better flavored.

Pan fried Lotus Root Pork Patties: Very moist with a good crisp. Not too fried with a good pork flavor. This was served with 6 bao which was a fun touch. Probably my favorite of the bunch

Crispy Garlic Chicken: Good amount of fried garlic. Moister compared to Wu's though I found both a bit bland.

Cauliflower + Oyster Mushroom in XO Sauce: Very tasty. Strong umami flavor from the mushrooms and well made. Probably my 2nd favorite.

Steam Whole Flounder: Cantonese style whole fish has never been my favorite as I find it a bit bland but it's always tender. Good of it's style.

The second time I was here was with a larger group with some repeaters. Again, we got the crispy garlic chicken (solid again,) the lotus root pork patties (still delicious,) and the Peking pork chops (still solid.) The other newer dishes were:

Homestyle Chenpi Duck With Mandarin Orange Sauce: Chenpi refers to dried mandarin orange peel and that gives a hint that this won't be too sweet.  The sauce had a wonderful mix of sweetness and bitterness. This is popular for a really good reason and was easily my favorite dish I have had here

Braised Pork Belly With Mui Choy: Very tender pork that could be cut with a spoon. Good portion size with plenty of the fermented vegetable. A bit salty but that's normal.

Sautéed Pea Shoots With Garlic: Good garlic flavor and plenty of shoots. Very tasty version. Would recommend

Buddha's Delight: Plenty of things inside but as per usual for this vegetarian dish, it's just alright. Sauce was lighter than normal. Pretty good

Whole Peking Duck: Just OK. Skin could have been crispier and the meat could have been more moist. Just get the chenpi.

Fried Salt & Pepper Flounder Filets: Standard version with a standard fry. Alright.

Cured Meat Fried Rice: Not enough lapcheong/other meat for the price. Just alright

The first time I went here, it was probably a low 4 and the second time was a mid 4. The chenpi duck and the lotus patties are my easy favorite here. It's popular and the dishes we had both times were consistent. Very solid and I can see why it's popular. Would avoid the fried rice but otherwise, it's all very good.

Giving this place three stars -- while the menu offers that nod to the "Wah Kew" legacy of patrons, as per Pete Wells review, the bright decor paled in presentation and definitely deficient in service. Guess Pete got better hospitality than we did.  Don't get me wrong, the dishes were tasty and many flavors were accurate /mostly on point. But if you are offering the full experience then you should do so with the plating too. It was too simple and missing the creative food flowers or veggie decorations as garnish.

The menu had so much variety and paid homage to the classic family style joints I grew up dining in. Even the prices were not too outrageous considering they offered these as sharing entrees. For the proportions, it's cheaper than the fancy family dining restaurants but a lot more than your average hole in the wall. I'm not sure I'd make this a regular stop based on these prices.

I do recommend the steamed fish (flounder), hands down was a favorite at this table. And we enjoyed the salt and pepper squid. I personally wished it had a little more of a bounce but still good flavor wise. Sadly, our black pepper scallops were overwhelmed with sauce and way too much black pepper, it just  over powered our taste buds. The simmering hot plate it was served on was smoking for quite some time after it was served. But that just made it harder to see and eat.

The only service worth mentioning was that the waitress oddly offered us a square table instead of a round for a party of three -- we sat for ten minutes already then she moved us when a four seater opened up. I'm guessing they wanted to move us since we didn't need that much space and they could use it for a larger group. At this point, it was twenty minutes before we ordered. No waiter came by. And during our meal, we barely got refills on our water. Maybe because we went at an off time (3pm on a Saturday...).  Shame on you Uncle Lou, you were there!

Service was quick and food came out pretty quickly too. Nothing crazy.

Food was good ! The Shanghai Chow Fun had an masala twist to it that I enjoyed. The stuffed seafood eggplant was unique and tasty and nothing like I've had before. The Crispy Garlic Chicken was definitely crispy but the main flavor was honestly just soy sauce lol. Would recommend this spot tho !

Everything we ordered was really tasty and perfectly seasoned. The entire establishment was clean and modern. Must order: garlic chicken, eggplant, and the walnut shrimp was amazing.

This business also has a great story with Uncle Lou at the center. I love supporting great small businesses like this. We went with no reservation at 1pm on a Sunday with 5 people and had no issues getting a table.

First time trying Uncle Lou and the food here was all delicious and authentic. The ambiance is comfortable and inviting. Reservation however is only for parties of 6 or more, and there's a wait during peak hours, so come early and put your name on the list.

One trick I learned from dining here is to have the walnuts on the side for the walnut shrimp dish because those walnuts are caramelized and taste soooo good and crunchy on their own. They have a bar but I do however wish they have more drink options, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic.

Overall, we enjoyed the time here. Will definitely be back again!

food was nice, strongly recommend!
Service was great, and atmosphere was authentic Chinese

Best newish Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown!
Must have: eggy tofu w veggies!!! Went there first time w a bunch of friends, and came back for lunch just to eat the eggy tofu, lunch special is excellent price!

I came here with my boyfriend for Saturday lunch, and was pleasantly surprised by the food quality.  We ordered a wonton noodle soup and the seafood pan fried noodles.  Both dishes came out with huge portions compared to other Chinese restaurants we've been to, and the dishes were both flavorful and filling.  Usually I'm not a fan of pan fried noodles, but this one is def by far the best I've ever had!

Also, service here is super attentive and staff is friendly.  The restaurant can get quite busy and loud as lots of customers eat here.

Taking our daughter to school in NY, it's perfect time to try new Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. We like cantonese food and my daughter found this place, took the subway to here was fast from Manhattan-Chelsea.
We had to wait for about 30 minutes because it was on a Friday. The place is quite nice, not big but filled with people. We could wait outside or some chairs inside.
The service is quite fast, and the servers are attentive.
The food was amazing, no wonder it's packed. The price are not inexpensive but not too bad. The portions are quite large but the important thing is they're very flavorful and delicious.
We ordered the calamari and we couldn't finish with 3 hungry adults. My daughter loved the food here. Kungpow chicken, beef and green beans, xiumai. We're glad we found this place, it's worth the wait.

We came here without a reservation at 530 on a Saturday night and were able to sit at the bar, we were 2 people. The menu is large and lots of options. Typical American Chinese food like general Taos and sesame chicken, orange beef etc. but also chicken legs and jellyfish salad. Everything coming out of the kitchen looked good and big portions. It should be for the prices, chicken dishes were $20. Shrimp dishes $25. We ended up both getting the dumpling soup #90. It was only $9 and was a huge bowl of yummy soup with 6 shrimp dumplings and egg noodles. We also got fried chicken dumplings and a scallion pancake. The scallion pancake was thin and nothing crazy. It was brought to us really late so they brought us a free warm rice pudding type dessert. It was pretty good. They also give complimentary hot tea. I would try another place in China town next time.

Uncle Lou was recommended to me by a friend and it did not disappoint! Unassuming from the outside, once you step in you see that it is modern, spacious and bright. We snagged seats at the bar, but it was packed on a Wednesday night.

All of the food was fresh and tasty. We ordered chicken and vegetable dumplings - they were filled with large pieces of meat and veggies and came piping hot from the kitchen. We also ordered General Tso's, garlic eggplant, and chicken and broccoli. The portions were generous. The sauces were on the heavier side, but generally you don't order Chinese food looking for a lighter option.

I didn't realize until we were leaving that Uncle Lou was at the bar, taking orders and chatting with customers. A great experience all around.

(Overall: 90% | A) - While the restaurant itself may not be known for any type of extravagance, they have fantastic food options with a value budget in consideration. Very great option in Chinatown overall!

(Citrus Peel Duck: 92.5% | A) - This is a fantastic, abundant portion of duck that is tender and easy to eat. I love the abundance of tangerine sauce that goes well with the duck. and some paired rice.

(Garlic Pea Shoot: 90% | A) - The greens are tendered and well flavored. The garlic gives the leaves some dimension so its rather pleasant.

(Wonton Noodle Soup: 95% | A) - For only $7, this was a sizable bowl that is of great quality. The noodles were springy; the bok choy added color and substance; and the won wontons were decently filled and served in a soothing broth.

(Beef Chow Fun: 90% | A) - In terms of taste, the flavors were very authentic -- though I would've liked it if it was a little more concentrated. The beef was very tender and this was a good dish overall.

Uncle Lou is one my favorite go-to spots in Chinatown and there plenty of restaurants to choose from but I would always choose/recommend Uncle Lou! When I went it was crowded, which I wasn't mad about, because I'm happy that my favorite place has continuous customers.
Service was up to par to satisfy our needs and made sure our foods were gluten free. They were respectful of my girlfriend's allergy and provided us recommendations that can be made gluten free. The few food items we had were: Chicken with broccoli (no soy sauce), Asapargus w/ garlic sauce, and Singapore Chow Mei Fun (I recommend to take out the Char Siu to make it GF). Majority of the Singapore is gluten free; I just forgot to take out the Char Siu but overall it was delicious. The food options we did was worth the money and our tastes were happy. Knowing they can make items gluten free will make us come back!
Went in with excitement and left with disappointment. Ordered a beef chow fun, portion is good but the dish was very bland, the beef was not from a good cut, feels old, stringy and hard to chew.

Wife and I stopped for dinner. We ordered chicken feet, wontons in chili, egg drop soup. fried salt&pepper fish fillet, and pea shoots sautéed w/garlic.

First off our food came out very fast after ordering.
Very good food,and order service. Everything tasted fresh.

Finally found a place w/ amazing shrimp and lobster sauce.  This place puts all the Jersey places to shame - flavorful, big, fresh shrimp, generous portion, etc.  The wontons in chili oil are also great, as is the yung chow fried rice.  haven't tried anything else on the menu yet, as we keep going back for these.

This place is a great addition to LES Chinatown. If you want authentic, legit Asian cuisine. This is the place to be! If you grew up eating that fast food style. This will be an upgrade to your palette !

For once a local who grew up eating this type of food in every corner. It is now have scarce. With all that Asian fusion cuisine. This is were the roots are and if you want to learn and just experience it. It is highly recommended.

I know majority will go for the Fried Rice, General Tsao's, etc. Try something new!

Their Fried Shrimp with honey glaze walnuts is a must! Perfectly crisped and cooked to perfection. Drenched in their light mayo sauce on a bed of broccoli and YES you can eat the greens! It's NOT just for decorations as someone mentioned to me once...

I usually eat the Oxtail in a Tomato stew like but their take on it still gives me the nostalgic old school vibes. They don't skimp and make them paper thin like some places I've been!

The 3 Fried seafood ; Scallop, squid, and shrimp is a bit on the saltier side. But it is called White Pepper & Salt Fried so it's a given. Just needed a little more kick! with the peppers. But overall still good in my book!

All in all we had a great experience. Brings back memories of old Chinatown feels and I'm grateful they opened this place for everyone to experience this place.

I recommend coming here on a weekday 6-7pm. That's the time where lines aren't over crowded and the chef will focus on your dishes even more so! It gets a tad loud on the busier days but still manageable to carry a conversation.

I recently dined at Uncle Lou with high hopes, but unfortunately, my experience left much to be desired. The two dishes I ordered, the General Tso chicken and Jumbo shrimp in garlic sauce, fell short of my expectations. The General Tso chicken fat was overshadowed by excessive breading, while the jumbo shrimp failed to deliver on size and taste.

Starting with the General Tso chicken, I was disheartened to find that it was predominantly comprised of breading. It appeared that they took the chicken fat they clean from the chicken and coated it with breading and sauce. The chicken fat was overshadowed, leading to an imbalance of textures and flavors. This dish lacked the meaty bold and tangy taste I was anticipating resulting in leaving most of it untouched on the plate.

Equally disappointing was the Jumbo shrimp, which failed to live up to its name. The shrimp were far from jumbo in size, and their taste fell flat. I was expecting succulent and flavorful shrimp, but sadly, they left no lasting impression. The lack of seasoning or distinctive flavors made it a forgettable dish.

Overall, my experience at this Chinese restaurant left me with mixed feelings. While the ambiance and service were satisfactory, the quality and execution of the dishes were lacking. The worst part is that the entire time I was never offered a glass of water.

Considering all factors, I would rate this restaurant a 5 out of 10. While it may suit those looking for a quick meal, it falls short of delivering an exceptional dining experience.

All in all the Young Chow fried rice hit all the marks and so did the fried pork dumplings. The service was mediocre nothing to say about it. I hope the restaurant takes these feedback points into account and works towards improving the quality and consistency of their dishes.

Nothing stood out enough to make me want to come back here again. Sorry Uncle Lou better luck next time.

Great food. Great ambience. Great service. We were looking for a good family style restaurant and this hit the spot. The food was delicious and was large enough to feed 3 very hungry people. We ordered the duck but ate it up before we could take a pic along with the chicken wings. Can't go wrong with any of the food. Surprisingly, one of my favs was the crispy noodle lo mein with beef

Uncle Lou in Chinatown is a fantastic food spot for dinner among friends. They take reservations for parties of 6 and more. So if you're part of a smaller group, you can still call ahead of time to get an idea of how long a wait is likely to be. For dinner on a weekend, aim for early or late dinner: otherwise, it may be hard to snag a table.

We had a party of 6, and ordered 5 dishes.
- The Honey Walnut shrimp: do yourself a favor and get the honey walnut shrimp! It was an instant hint, and we wished there were more pieces of shrimp (instead of all that extra broccoli!)
- Twice Cooked Pork: I don't eat pork regularly, but others liked it
- 1/2 Peking Duck: another excellent dish! The skin is crispy and packed with flavors
- Saucy Ho Fun: solid dish as well, with tasty pieces of beef, although we felt it was "too saucy" (that one may be on us)
- Steamed fish: felt like a really healthy food option, and it does offer the opportunity to bond over some fish de-scaling/de-boning

It gets a little loud, but if you have your own large group to dine with this makes for a lively, excellent food spot.

Everything all around was perfect. Coming in the restaurant was very clean and friendly. The menu is huge full of authentic chinese food. You will have endless choices of different cuisines. The best part was the food. The food was fresh, crispy, and so much flavors.

Came here for lunch on a Sunday and the place was packed! I think they opened recently because the inside looks new. You get a festive ambiance because of the many red lanterns hanging from the ceiling.
They have a lot of the standard Chinese American dishes as well and dim sum and some authentic dishes. We ordered the crispy garlic chicken and it was so good! Very flavorful and soft on the inside. The noodle dish was exactly as I had in mind. Prices are cheap/very reasonable. It took us a little longer than normal to get our food (compared to other Chinese restaurants) but it's probably because I went on a holiday and they were slammed. Would come back if I'm in Chinatown!

went with over 20 people, and it was great. servers on point, food delicious, environment comfie and not crazy loud. Staff worked to make sure we all had a good time, and I appreciated it. We all family-styled the dishes and waddled out full AF.

We had:
*BRAISED PORK BELLY W/ MUI CHOY -awesome. succulent pork you can cut with a spoon, sauce just beggin for rice. bowl is big, so sharing is advised.

*PAN FRIED LOTUS ROOT PORK PATTIES (w/ 6 baos) -hella tasty, crispy edges, moist and tasty. not over fried, or greasy. I forgot there were baos for it, and just happily muched on my share.

*HOMESTYLE CHENPI DUCK w/ mandarin orange sauce. The best of the duck we ordered. Great sauce, not overly sweet. I would totally get this again.

WHOLE PEKING DUCK - tasty but overshadowed by the other dishes. cooked right, skin wasn't very crispy, but it was just basic to me. I'd get the chenpi.

CRISPY GARLIC CHICKEN -didn't like this. Very salty, and parts of the chicken were overcooked.

FRIED SALT & PEPPER FLOUNDER FILLET- this was another dish done well, but was common enough to get elsewhere. no big whuup.

*PEKING PORK CHOPS -i haven't had this dish in a while and i was glad to reminisce with this. it was hella moist with the crispy edge and a sauce that wasn't gaudy sticky sweet or mega salty. Totally get this.

*SAUTEED PEA SHOOTS W/ GARLIC -wonderful garlic flavor, tender shoots that danced in your mouth allowing themselves to be chewed. get it, even if you think you don't like veggies, or you had enough that day.

BUDDHA'S DELIGHT -ok. Good flavor, bowl full of delights, but not a primary dish for me. I could pass on it, but I'd eat some if someone I'm with ordered it.

I'm sure there are enough photos here to give you the vibe of goodnisss.

Came here with a couple friends and two dishes was plenty to share. We ordered in Chinese, so the server was nice enough to give us some starter chicken soup on the house. The pork belly buns were delicious- I've never had pork belly that melted immediately in my mouth. It was bursting with flavors but also not too salty, we probably scraped the stone bowl trying to get the last of the sauce and veggies out. We also splurged on the lobster noodles. It was definitely worth trying once, it came with an entire lobster. There was so much meat and it went with the noodles well. I was definitely skeptical of its authenticity, given its modern Chinese decor and good service but I dream about this pork belly and would definitely come back again.

Outstanding. Almost like a more modern (and in my opinion better) version of Wo Hop (which I also love). First visit, we got wontons in chili oil, shrimp rice rolls, vegetable spring rolls, braised pork belly, crispy garlic chicken, dried scallop & egg fried rice, and chicken lo mein. Just about every bite was amazing, to the point where I'd get any of this again but I'm also dying to try the rest of the menu. The pork belly was probably my favorite dish (especially with the buns that come with them), and my wife's favorite was the crispy garlic chicken.

One thing we learned for next time: the portions are really big, so that should play into our ordering strategy next time around.

The staff was also incredibly friendly to our two kids, and the kids also really loved their lo mein.

Had lunch with a party of 8 .
Baby Bok Choy
2 orders of Chicken , Char sui pan fried noodles
Young chow fried rice
General tso chicken
Pan Fried flounder
Shrimp and lobster sauce
Har Gar
Egg plant and Garlic
Whole Crispy garlic chicken
Steam pork with salty eggs and Chinese sausage

The food was excellent . Staff was good and accommodating . Seating us prior to our reservation while we wait for few family members .

Worth going back again .

Definitely make reservation if you can . It get packed very quickly especially for dinner after 6.00pm

Lawerence is a great host . He takes care of all issues .

My husband saw this place on TikTok and clearly a lot of other folks did too. It was pretty busy for a Monday night and you could tell there was a lot of tourist/TikTok/IG visitors looking for delicious food and photo-worthy good opportunities.

The restaurant itself is beautiful - definitely lots of IG pic opportunities the bar is small but enough to seat a few couples and single dinners. There is a decent sized waiting area which was nice because there is definitely a wait. The dining seating is very tight, you can tell they are really trying to pack people in.

The food was very tasty, but honestly everything (from the tea to all food dishes) comes out way too hot. Like burn yourself even a few minutes after arrival hot.

Once you're able to get past the food temps - the food is delicious. We had a couple of appetizers and then a couple main plates to share across two adults and two kids.

The service is not great. The wait staff is not attentive and you have to track them down to get anything done. They are busy, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt there.

I would highly recommend Uncle Lou as a spot to gather with your friends or family for a good Chinese meal.

A group of friends and I went to Uncle Lou on a Saturday afternoon. We got seated at a table with the rotating surface which helps if you're sharing your dishes aka family style!  

We ordered multiple meat dishes, some dim sum, and fried rice! You can go without the fried rice but if you're looking to fill your stomach some more, then definitely get it. It's nothing special so you could go without it. The pork belly with pickled mustard and bok choy had a unique flavor and definitely not for those who are particular about their food!

I would recommend getting the crispy chicken dish, it was a favorite at the table!

The service was quick and easy! We were able to get a table quickly and get out quickly as well!

Definitely would try Uncle Lou again!

Very very good food!

I'm reviewing for the takeout I did the past week. I'll edit when I eat in and it may or may not have that fifth star. For now 4/5 :)

However.. I can comment on the ambience while I was waiting on my food. It's definitely modern and beautiful in comparison to the neighboring restaurants in Chinatown, like the cleanliness is a perfect A+ from me judging from the bathroom and everything else aesthetic wise lol

My interactions with Uncle Lou himself.. he's a little rough around the edges.. like any Chinese family member speaking from experience lmao. Not particularly warm, but not too bad, idc. I'm driving around looking for somewhere to place my car and he's calling like "Your order ready for long time now, bye". Otherwise I believe he's a hard working man from all these articles written about him and the establishment!

Moving on.. this past Sunday I ordered the crispy garlic chicken, which was making my mouth water looking at previous yelpers' pictures of it, and it's exactly what my expectations would be. Juicy, flavorful, and the perfect blend of scallions, garlic and oil. The pieces of chicken were bony, yes, but it was just too good. I ordered it again for my in-laws to try for my fiance's birthday celebration yesterday and it was the first dish to be sold out.

Here's the part of the review that gets kind of.. unreliable (for a lack of a better term?) because it was hours later that night and the food would've been probably better eaten within an hour/fresher. The salt and pepper calamari got super soggy in the container.. the flavor was there but the texture got too mushy even when I tried to revive it in the air fryer. The lobster noodles that were $48.. could've been WAY better. My in-law said it left more to be desired and I have to agree.. I expected more. It wasn't mind blowing at all. The noodles were very gingery which wasn't the issue but it felt like the lobster could've meshed better on the dish. Ordered wonton noodle soup for the kids.. can't comment on it but it sold lol.. but the sweet and sour pork comes second place to the chicken because it was also very good and tangy and sold to my in-laws.

Otherwise I can't wait to come back and try more dishes and dine there!

Love this place! Very authentic Chinese food and brought me back to a restaurant that I loved in San Francisco which my uncle who was from Hong Kong would take us. The salt and pepper pork chops were to die for! Light, crispy, and delicious. Everything tasted fresh and the service was good. The inside felt clean and updated. We enjoyed our lunch here.

First time here! Heard a lot about it... Phenomenal!

Food/Drink: Very tasty, very well cooked, very well plated. Full traditional Chinese menu. Appetizers, drinks, and deserts. Like a billion things to choose from!

Sushi: None.

Dinning Area: Pretty large, open, quiet.

Prices: Relatively cheap. Lunch specials for $10, full meals from 16-25, and a few apps and soups. We spent $40!

Parking: None.

Bathrooms: Bathrooms were clean and beautiful!

Atmosphere: During the weekday lunch rush, pretty packed, but mostly only for a short time.

Staff/Attendants: So nice, and very assuring they appreciated your business. Always a "thank you" a "you're welcome" a smile...so great!

I'll go back because it's actually pretty damn good!

10/10

The food here is decidedly meh. We got the fried rice (tasted like Trader Joe's), crispy pork (tasted American), and a few other items. The service and atmosphere are good though. There are better places to spend your time and money in Chinatown.

I'm a bit torn on how to rate the place. It's pushing 3.5 stars but I'm going to go with 4. Off the beaten path in Chinatown this was recommended to come for dinner with my significant other's family. I like the set up of the place. It gets insanely crowded so I recommend coming at off hours. Which even though we did around 4pm there was still a 20 minute wait for a table for 4. If you're only two people, you might get off easier. We may have ordered the entire menu. No joke. I mostly went with the wontons in chili oil and the saucy beef chow ho fun noodle dish but tried a variety of other things.

The wonton in chili oil: Not what I was expecting with the consistency of the sauce. It's very runny and just full chili. Sometimes I like a little bit of a sesame or peanut taste. Pleasant surprise was that there was a shrimp inside of each. Reminders this is actually Cantonese food and not Sichuan or Shanghai. But I couldn't honestly tell you the absolute differences with each.

Steamed Vegetable Dumplings: Definitely the most disappointing thing we ordered. Very bland and filled with glass jelly noodles amongst other greens. I liked the consistency of the dumpling dough though. Just not the filling.

Eggplant in Yuxiang Garlic Sauce: Surprisingly pretty tasty. This might have been the star side dish that I guess is an entree. The sauce is nice and the eggplant almost has this caramelized texture and taste.

Baby Bok Choy with Garlic: I honestly would never order an entire bowl of bok choy. But it's a nice accompaniment and mixed in with other things adds freshness and brightness.

Half a duck: Again, I liked the sauce. I'm a huge fan of duck. Huge. HUGE. But it wasn't the best duck I've ever had. It was just very okay. I wouldn't splurge the price tag over it.

Twice Cooked Pork: Almost sent the dish back because there was just too much food ordered. I personally thought it was fine. That was it. It was very fatty meat. Didn't try the accompanying veggies with it.

Saucy Beef Chow Ho Fun: We ordered both unsauced and sauced because me and my partner wanted to get the same thing and he doesn't like sharing lol. But I will say, go with the sauced noodles. It's richer and fuller and comes with significant more of a balance of vegetables. Going to be honest, I thought the thing I ordered was the best thing I ate here and glad I went the noodle route while sampling a few other dishes. Ultimately everything was okay, the prices are pretty average. You can get $7 Tsingtao beers to wash it all down with. I'd come back but there are better options out there.

Mayan when my friends kept boasting about this place I knew I would have to make the trip out there and it truly did not disappoint. I tried a 3rd of the menu ordering family style with my party. Ordered the Chilli wontons, half peking duck, honey walnut shrimp, scallion pancakes and a whole bunch of other dim-sum low was Kiu favorites was not disappointed at all. Also the service is very attentive and give you tea to revitalize yourself before and after you feast. The restaurant has an asian supermarket/bodega vibe definitely instagram worthy. Will visit very soon

Food was amazing and service was pretty solid as well. Some of the dishes were a bit too salty and harder to finish without having a beer or water on the side. I would definitely come back since menu is large and good for groups. Clean renovated interior and right near everything in LES.

Food: Came to eat here after a friend's high recommendation for Chinatown eats. Loved the variety of Asian cuisines on the menu! Some of our favorites included the wonton soup, har gow, and garlic sautéed pea shoots, and beef chow fun.

Ambiance: Super clean interior and plentiful seating. We came in around 3-4pm with a party of 6 and were able to be seated immediately. Another time later in the evening, my friends came in a party of 4, however, and the wait was 30 min. Seems to be a popular spot so be prepared for a wait - worthwhile though!

Service: Servers were quick and accommodating! We asked to return a dish because it came out towards the end of our meal and we were already full. They were kind enough to take it off our bill and even gave the dish to another table for free. Would definitely come back next time I'm in NY!

Stopped by late but still plenty of people inside. We ordered the salt and pepper pork, honey walnut shrimp, and pea shoots. Food came out kind of slow, there were people next to us who came in later but got their food much faster than we did. The pork was very crispy and well seasoned. The shrimp was good but the walnuts were so crunchy and yummy. The pea shoots were ok, a little oily. I thought the food was good, but my canto boyfriend thought it was just average.

Uncle Lou is the bomb! I came here with my fiance and her family to celebrate a special occasion. First off this is a pretty large restaurant with great spacing and a more modern vibe than your classic chinese restaurant. The bathroom was also impeccably clean!

We ordered a bunch of stuff including bok choy, tofu skin, steamed flounder with ginger and garlic, beef with chives. The true hits were the fish and the tofu skin. Both foods that made me reminisce of my mom's home cooking. My fiances mom said the tofu skin was the best thing she's eaten in a while. I really enjoyed how the food was lighter on the grease and sauce than your average restaurant! This is a special place.

Welcoming, clean, family friendly with nice servers. Busy.  Recommended by coworkers born in China. Had the crispy garlic chicken (favorite), pea shoots (next favorite), pork and shrimp shumai, black pepper short ribs and pork lo mein.
Reasonably priced.

My only problem was what to order from the large menu. Hard to decide.

All in all really good.
Will definitely go back!

Uncle Lou may be a newcomer, but they bring amazing Cantonese dishes to Chinatown. This place is good for groups and families.

I highly recommend ordering a couple of dishes including at least one protein and one vegetable and then shared family style.

Fish Maw Soup - A classic soup usually served during wedding banquets and paired with red wine vinegar. Fish maw is considered a delicacy, essentially tasteless, but takes on the flavors of other ingredients, and with a spongey texture. This is a great way to open up the palettes.

Honey Walnut Jumbo Shrimp - This is a favorite among the American-born Chinese and for good reason. Lightly battered and fried shrimp tossed in mayonnaise and honey-coated walnuts.

Pea shoots sauteed in garlic - Pea shoots are a must-get. This is lightly blanched and cooked with garlic. This is a must-order!

Steamed buffalo fish with ginger and scallion - This was a hit with everyone at the table. This was a perfectly steamed buffalo fish segment with ginger and scallion with a light soy sauce. This is another must-order!

Crispy garlic chicken (1/2) - Another classic dish and done well. Crispy chicken in a soy-based sauce topped with crispy garlic. This is another must-order!

Fried Salt & Pepper squid - Salt and pepper squid was nicely fried. The flavors are good but nothing note-worthy.

Lobster Yee Mein -  This was a miss for me. I was disappointed since the other dishes were well made. The presentation was very appealing, but the noodles had too many broken shells throughout. This was a huge turnoff and I would skip this dish.

Not sure if we got lucky, but my party of 4 walked in at 6:30 on a Friday and got seated right away. We shared:

+ Crispy garlic chicken
+ Home style chenpi duck
+ Eggplant in Yuxiang garlic sauce
+ Egg drop soup
The highlight was definitely the chicken. Otherwise I found the dishes pretty underwhelming - fairly tasty but nothing special.

3.5 stars.

This is one of the nicer/slower restaurants in Chinatown and great if you're looking for a sit-down place rather than grab and go. We ordered the pictured dishes for 3 people and had plenty of leftovers. Nice family style portions and plenty of options for big groups!

The food here us fairly good. I'm pretty sure it was better in the past and now with it's name being passed around the ambiance definitely shows more diversity of customers, which in think is great! However I do think the quality was slightly low than if I went to a more hole in the wall location. Soft shell crab was probably the star dish for the night. The stuff eggplant was also very savory. The pan fried noodle was almost flavorless, but not bad. I understand it's to provide room to change the flavor with sauce, but no sauce was provided so the dish itself was bland. Same with the walnut shrimp and it wasn't that big for it to be $25+ a dish

I probably would come back but maybe pick other types of dishes

For the genre, Uncle Lou makes excellent Cantonese-styled food with fresher ingredients and less oil than some of their counterparts in Chinatown. We've ordered takeout from Uncle Lou twice and had positive experiences both times. In particular, our favorites have been the following:

-Crispy chicken: terrific roasted chicken with very tender and flavorful meat (9/10)
-Stuffed eggplant and tofu: hands down my favorite dish. The stuffing in the eggplant is perfect and the rich sauce pairs well with the tofu (10/10)
-Seafood stir-fry: Fresh-tasting vegetables with a good amount of seafood. Not too oily. (9/10)

Uncle Lou, like many other restaurants on Mott Street, does not deliver, but offers pickup.

We approached the restaurant, and, like a ghost out of the mist, a man exits the door. And whispers to me...."are you ready to have the best Chinese food of your life?"

While perhaps he was not a ghost, and it may not be  the best Chinese food in my life, the food was very good, and the man was very old.

As far as dim sum goes, it was very tasty, full of flavor and excellent for family sharing.

Highly recommend general tso's chicken and the dumplings.

Overall rating: 3.5/5

I came here on recommendation from a friend. I would say it is a good fix if you're looking for some authentic tasting Chinese food. I got the green beans, chow fun, duck and steamed fish.

The chow fun tasted like it could have used some more flavor and same with the sauce on the steamed fish.

The green beans and duck were pretty good. The duck comes with steamed buns to wrap in as well. Good crisp on the duck skin.
This place reopened just a year, since the pandemic. They totally redecorated very hip. As always food is  delicious

Came here on a Saturday morningish. Around 11 or so, the restaurant was filled with construction workers due to the construction site outside.  It took them 2 mins to seat us but 15 mins to get our order and 30 mins after ordering we still did not get our food. The construction workers before us actually half of them didnt get their food either. We finally got up and left after waiting for our food for 40 mins and left to find food elsewhere.

I came with a party of 9 on a Saturday for a birthday dinner, there were 2 or 3 other tables in the restaurant but the waiter was slow to greet us and take our orders.

The birthday girl wanted to order family style, but the portions really aren't large enough to do so (without ordering extra food): We shared two pizzas (Margherita and vodka), calamari, penne vodka, pappardelle bolognese, chicken Milanese and chicken parmigiana (all between $20-$30 each). The food was good, but not particularly memorable.

Similarly, service was fine but the wait staff is not overly attentive and the meal was served at a very leisurely pace.
