If this would've been pre-pandemic I would've given it FIVE Stars!  What a difference a pandemic makes!  Wow!  My first time back into Manhattan and my first stop is Upside Pizza!  Last time I was her was around February 2020. Since this place first opened around 2018, I e been always impressed with the pies here. From the perfectly tasty crust, to the exquisitely seasoned tomato sauce base and the nice proportions of cheese and meat and expertly cooked pies. What happened with that pizza?  What happened with the original guy that I saw almost every day....from spotting him early every morning preparing dough and getting the first pies in the oven. I could hardly wait for lunch.

When I finally got back and checked inside, everything looked the same as before, except that the original guy wasn't there anymore!!  How much difference could his absence make?  Unfortunately, it made ALL the difference in the world!!  Such a disappointing experience. To start with, the dough was like cardboard. No tasty irresistible crust, I felt like crying!  The tomato sauce, meh is a oak I can say. Is it different tomato's?  Roma tomatoes or San Marzano's?  Whatever they did it's not a good thing. I ordered a slice of the thick pepperoni (a square corner) cause they didn't have the spicy sausage available. After the big hit of salt, I was hit with the overcooked crust, nondescript sauce......such a disappointment to say the least.

I still gave it two stars, mainly for its nice guys and friendly service. I truly hope that the original guy comes back and makes everything alright with the pizza world in midtown Manhattan once again!  When that day comes, I'll be back. Until that day, I be buying a full pie at John's Pizza on Bleeker Street!

I'm not from nyc. IT's thousands of pizza shop or food shops in general I just randomly walked in here.. 8th Ave near time square

Got a deep dish square pepperoni slice. Crazy time there! Just a random pizza shop I walked in.
One of the best pizza places in New York. The crust is crunchy and delicious. I will definitely be coming back to try other slices.

Ordered two slices from Upside Pizza on Friday afternoon. In an area where the pizza options are mostly gross dollar slices it is a step-up, but definitely not enough to seek out.

Quality: Upside Pizza was decent, but not worth navigating the craziness of Midtown to get. I ordered two slices, a Sicilian and a Sunny Goldstein. The Sicilian was the better of the two, thanks to a solid interior. The tomato sauce was thick and creamy and the texture was soft. However, the cheese was a bit too burnt and the edges were charred. The Sunny Goldstein is a seasonal pie, which utilizes sungold tomato sauce. A bit tart, it provided a unique flavor, but not one that had me craving more.
Quantity: Standard size slices, Sicilian is a bit heftier than usual.
Value: $3.50-$5.50 for a Pizza Slice.
Ambiance: Upside Pizza is located in Midtown Manhattan. The location is tiny with most of the indoor space dedicated to the kitchen. Guests have just enough space to order and then are immediately back outside. They had two high-tops set up on the sidewalk, which would make busier times inconvenient. Expect to stand and hold your plate.
Crowd: Tons of people walking in and out, but very few ordering pizza. Tourist location creates weird traffic patterns.
Service: Friendly guys behind the counter, pleasantly surprised to see them wiping down the outside tables immediately after use.
Parking: Difficult to find any nearby parking.

A friend of a friend suggested this place for pizza. It's right on 8th between 39th & 40th Streets. It's one of those pizza shops where you can take out, or have them fire up the pizza slices for you to eat as you're on the go.

Me and 4 others swung by after gazing at the Christmas Lights Display around NYC. We all decided on NY Style pizza. All five of us ordered different flavors and toppings all but 2 had a few slices to take back for the flight home the next day.

Fun place to grab and go. According to their website, it looks like there are two other locations in NYC. This particular location is best if you are in Times Square and just a few steps away from Port Authority.

Tbh, the pizza was delicious and all, service was nice, but with so many pizza shops all around the city, It isn't so close to anything that I come by regularly.
Pizza is a little expensive and is just okay. It's a decent option for a quick bite, but by no means is it the best pizza in NYC.
A below average slice of pizza. I got a mushroom slice here, and it tasted pretty dry and overdone.

Pizza was okay. Have had better by the slice pizza. The cheese seemed a bit sour (perhaps due to the heat that day) from maybe sitting out. The mushrooms were fine and the crust wasn't bad. But the pizza needed some flavor like ricotta with garlic or oregano

Horrible pizza!

Thought I'd try the pizza here and am sorry I did.

It has a weird tasting sauce and cheese. The dough tastes funny as well.

Definitely not worth trying.

Don't get too excited! This isn't the best or the greatest pizza in NYC. it's good but unless you're sitting down and getting a pie, it might not be fully hot and there are so many pizza offerings in the city and in this area to try.

First, I'm not a pizza snob, maybe just a snob. Most pizza has its charms and there are categories depending on your mood, time of day or night, convenience, price point etc. You cannot give a blanket review without context. So with that in mind, I'll give two, thick and thin references.

The "thick" Sicilian style at Upside is very good and get it crisp, but when it comes to Detroit style thick, there's A Place in the jersey city heights called Low Fidelity that kills this style hands down. I mean, it's lifetime memorable and that to me is the sign of something great.

My favorite "thin" in the city and perhaps the world is the tri pie at Joe and Pats on 1st avenue, they offer the same pie with three sauces (vodka, marinara, and pesto) at their other family related locations. It's not cheap or by the slice, but you can get it by the slice at their staten Island location.

Happy pizza eating in the city that never sleeps and even the .99 cent a slice places satisfy.
No frills pizza that is tasty, won't break the bank, nice quality and stand up crust.  I thought it was Great.  I did the regular cheese and it was $26 for 8 slice pizza.

I am here to help plan your NYC trip based on PIZZA. Stay at the Holiday Inn Express on 39th and then enjoy late night pizza mere steps away! Or afternoon pizza! Or anytime pizza! I had a few too many glasses of wine and was ready for some late night 'za after a long day of travel. This corner shop for slices and squares DELIVERED. I said "one slice of pepperoni?" and the cashier said "just one?!" and I said "no, two," and thus began a love of Upside Pizza and their deep understanding of my NEEDS at that time. They know me better than I knew myself in that moment.

Two was the correct choice. This slice was unreal. Loaded with pep, greasy as can be, seasoned to perfection, with a soft-but-not-gummy dough. I am not even going to try and get to over the top descriptive here, because let's be honest, I ate this in my pajamas - drunk and alone in my hotel room. I might argue that is the best way to eat this pizza. No judgement, all enjoyment.

If you're staying near Port Authority, the warm glow and scent of this spot will likely draw you in at some point. Let it happen. Order two slices. Also, give their NYT feature a read, too! The owners are the same as 2 Bros and the history behind this spot is really interesting.

Emanuel & Dameon are the sweetest, greatest pizza makers ever. I would 10/10 recommended this place for the great pizza and even better service. They really are out there trying to sell slices and sold us more than we wanted to buy. The pizza was delicious and the good service made it better. It's a sourdough crust so it's a little different but very crispy and perfect. They need a raise!

As a lover of the square slice, I simply needed to stop by Upside Pizza while I was in the area. I heard about their cold-fermented dough that about 72 hours to rise, which was a major selling point to me. If the dough is no good, the pizza is just wasted.

I had the pepperoni square ($5) which was an instant flavor bomb of salty, porky goodness in my mouth. The cheesy frico crust was chewy but crisp, and so buttery. This slice is not shy about its flavors at all!

I will say, however, that it's best to ask them to warm up your slice a little longer in the oven, especially on a busy day where they might forget to check the time.
Wonderful slice, great crust, slightly tangy from the sourdough. I'll be back for sure.
Their food is AMAZING! wings are good as always. I decided to try the burger and it was real good! Recommend you come here
We stopped here while rushing to see a show and had little time. The service was fast and the pizza was solid. Can't say this is somewhere I'd seek out again, but it was perfect for what we needed.

Solid slice in midtown. The pizza guys from Upside just gets it. The crust is crispy but soft. The sauce has the perfect balance between acidic and sweetness, and the cheese is pretty awesome too.

Please keep in mind that there are not tables at this location. You would order your slice, wait until you're called and then fold and eat (it doesn't get any more NY than that).

Prices are reasonable a for the quality of the food. The slices are average size and the service is good (pizza guy is pretty friendly). I tired the mushroom white slice, and the pepperoni square both were excellent. The only reason I would not give it 5 stars is because of the location. We all know 8th Avenue is not the best place to eat a slice on the street. Other than that go and get your pizza and go elsewhere to enjoy it.
This was actually a bomb ass thin crusted pizza place. Good flavor and the pepperoni cups were nice and crisp. Definitely will be going back here for a $5 sliced pizza!
I've been here twice now and have really enjoyed their pizza! The Sunny Goldstein pizza is delicious!-
The pizza slice was really REALLY good and the guys waiting on you are quite entertaining, highly recommended

Best mushroom slice I've ever had I think and I've had so many. Often they look much better than they are but not this time, flavorful roasted mushrooms and small amounts of good cheese rather than gobs of gooey garbage cheese.  Excellent toppings and exceptional crust, thin, crispy and still a little chewy. Can't speak to the other slices, the Sicilian LOOKS a little goofy but the round pie crust is delightful. Bonus for actually having fountain soda which, as a large child like adult, I consider a necessary accompaniment to pizza.

steep prices. no chairs or tables to stand at, but they have a few hightops to stand at.

i loved the veggie slice. not gonna lie, it had a nice amount of garlic and mushrooms on it. cheese was decent. no flop on these slices, they had more of a crunch.

they take cards.

Just come in. You're already looking for good pizza. That's why you're reading this. Whether you're coming from Times Square or you're heading that way right now.
Just grab a slice here...as a snack. Then make your way back this way again for another slice.

The staff at this business establishment is horrible!! I visited this location between the hours of 12am to 3am and the cashier worker and another guy who worked to the right side of the store and was making pizza dough was horrible!! I witnessed racism literally in front of my eyes!! They were yelling racial slurs at a black delivery courier. They treated him like he was a nobody. They cursed at him repeatedly and told him to sell drugs!! Completely disgusting, then the guy who was making the pizza was talking over the pizza dough and a speckle of spit went in the dough!! Never visit this store ever!! Worst store ever!!
amazing food. We tried the mushroom and cheese and it was delicious!!! One of the best pizzas we ever had. We will definitely come back again. Service was ok.
One of the best slices in the area. I've shopped around for a while now near work and this is by far my favorite.

Got slices of cheese and mushroom pizza and it was SO good! I had been wanting to try their slice since so long, but my favorite pizza place(prince street pizza) is around the corner so always would end up there. I finally decided to try some today. The slices are huge, crust is thin and tastes so good. I liked their crust, it isn't hard or chewy. And cheese slice was great!

This review is a delivery review, coming to you straight from CoronaWorld.  Since we're all stuck at home, I thought I'd try to keep supporting local restaurants and try a new pizza place that I've heard very good things about.

First note - Upside is a little pricier than normal.  Pies go for 35-40 bucks.  Not a problem or anything, but expectations should be high at that price, you expect a really quality pie.

The good news is that I think Upside delivers.  I ordered two pies, the Sicilian Pepperoni and the Fuzzy Dunlop with sausage and pickled peppers.  The Sicilian is thick and has a well-cooked crust which is chewy and delicious.  With a sicilian pizza the most important thing is the crust and I think they nailed it.  Very good.  Good ratio of cheese, sauce and pepperonis as well.

The Fuzzy was also strong.  Again the sauce and cheese were in the right ratio, which not every place gets right.  The pickled peppers are pretty thinly sliced so you don't get overwhelmed by pepper flavor, it's a more subtle thing.  Overall this was a strong 4-star place and I'll likely order from them again soon.  Would recommend.

update edit:  I've gotten them a couple more times since the original review and still very impressed.  Especially for the sicilian style pizza, oh man.  That crust Does. Not. Quit. One of the best crusts I've ever had on a pizza.  Strong recommendation here.

Best cheese pizza in the city!!! From the crust to the sauce to cheese - *chef's kiss*

This place is a must try!!

I was wondering why the line was out the door for this place, so we decided it was a good place to eat. It was by accident that we found this gem and we ate there daily for our entire trip. The pizza is affordable and DELICIOUS by the slice. I had my taste of new york pizza and I will never be the same.

Touring around with my family and we spotted this spot on the corner. Ordered a slice of mushroom, it was great. Thin crispy crust, sautéed mushrooms with a hint of lemon. I'll be back to try more, especially since my lovely wife ate half of this one.

No bad pizza -thin crust but too much tomato sauce -for some reason the end crusts have an aftertaste
ordering a problem if you speak English- better pizza can be found in Midtown
This is the worst pizza I ever had in NY and 2 slices 10$ better just walk one more block and go to 2Bros couldn't even finish it flavor so bad

The price for a slice isn't listed.  Many places are $1 for a cheese slice.  For a slice of pepperoni it was $5.  It was just OK and if I had known it was $5 for the slice I would have gone down the street.  I had better pizza at the airport.  Sbarro has better pizza.

I came here just before Christmas while we were in NYC because I had heard such good things. I was so excited to try out the deep dish sicilian and got two slices of pepperoni. The pizza was, in no particular order:
- old
- hard
- inedible
- like trying to eat a brick

I ended up throwing most of it out. Waste of money! Won't be back.
Pizza was delicious and service was amazing.  The restaurant had a classic NY pizza feel.

Take out pizza place with plenty of pizza and upbeat music blasting.

I pretty much came here to taste their pepperoni square slice, which was tasty, but a little too "light" for my taste. I like deep pizza that if more dense, but this one was still ok.

Got here on a Friday evening around 7pm and there was no line.
Got done deep dish to go. Tasted gross. Sauce was a weird brownish grey color. Threw it in the trash.

Great pizza with a few really good staples, and the seasonal Sunny Goldstein is excellent. I initially really loved their squares, but I think I've come around to liking the rounds better (although I'd still like to try the Upside Don).

Crooks!!  Hoboken St Patty's day they tried to charge $28 for their plain mediocre pie!!!  Now I'm an opportunist, but gimme a break.  Prices on the board were blacked out for the day & "special" St Patty's day prices were instituted. I thought the workers jacked up prices to pocket a couple of dollars but the owner/manager was there & she was more belligerent than the irate customers!!   Effective today, I will never order from there again & I suggest that you don't either.  There are 10+ places in Hoboken that are better.  I hope the tourists keep you in business because the locals that you ripped off on St Patty's day will not forget & will find other options.
Scrumptious chopped cheese spot with a baller quick food entree in an unassuming deli that you would least expect it from. $6 a chopped cheese. 4.5/5 stars as a lunch spot.

I've been going to this place for the past few weeks for lunch and it has been amazing. The vibes are very welcoming and light hearted.

The food is all really good and healthy, it's a nice balance for what's on the area. My favorite thing is the Mike Tyson smoothie. It's so good and refreshing with a lot of nutrients. I also enjoy the butternut squash soup it's perfect for the cold days we've been having.

Definitely a gem in the neighborhood.

We came her and I must say it was very good. I had the party with jerk plantain which was delicious. I also had the Bronx bomber and it was quite tasty. They are very friendly and the party was delicious. The party was fresh and I did not even miss the meat. The jerk plantain was so good; I would definitely recommend everyone getting it. The store is pretty and has outdoor seating. The owner is very passionate about the community and ensuring the products are organic and good for the customers. This is definite must stop; I will come back to try more patties.
I go here every day on my break at work and it's a great place to get a healthy lunch and the staff is great and so is the food! :)

My review speaks to the customer service not any of the food/drinks sold here. We called at 5:10pm to ask what time they closed, the young lady said 6:00Pm so we drive and get there at 5:20pm, go in and she says we're not making any smoothies or juice because they close at 6...why couldn't she say that on the phone! NEVER going back!

A decent place to pick up a quick snack when you're hungry. Cheap food and you don't have to wait long for it. Convenient location too, its right on the busy Lenox avenue area of 116th street. It's pretty neat looking on the inside compared to similar places. A generic chicken and pizza place, the NY classic.

Ordered fries ,chicken and garlic rolls, awful just awful food. Im a simple guy with simple taste and I know this place is cheap and convenient food but it tasted so bad I just left the rest of the food for the pigeons to eat... That bad

Uptown Veg 2 is a lot smaller than the first location on 125th and some of the selection is more limited. However the food is still very good and the fact that it is vegan is a plus. The staff is nice and helpful and you can generally get a smoothie or juice made with whatever fruit you would like. You can also get a small plate of food hot food for under $20. I usually get the rice and beans, collard greens, and jerk "chicken" soy protein. Be mindful that they can be understaffed sometimes and it may take a little longer to get your order processed but this is a hard time for all food service places so please show some grace and patience. Overall it's a great place to stop by for a quick bite or on your lunch break.
Food was amazing I'm not vegan but this food is so good I've been considering becoming vegan , ambiance is beautiful , love the patio vibes ! Staff was extremely helpful

This place is good for what it is. They have a very limited number of dishes (about 12 on display to choose from) and they are all vegan. Most of the "meat" is soy protein, and the other dishes are plain.

You pay by the pound (as of July 2022 it is $9.49/lb) and this can add up quite fast especially if you get things like noodles or chickpeas.

They were out of their eggplant dish, which is really the only reason you should come here if you can! That is probably the best tasting item they have.

Would I come here again? Probably if I'm in a pinch and just want solid food that doesn't blow me away.

This place has horrible customer service. My friend who has a service dog for medical needs was denied entry from someone as soon as we walked in, stating "we don't allow pets inside you're going to have to leave her outside" My friend stated that she's not a pet but a service animal to which the worker replied "doesn't matter, we don't allow pets or service animals" not sure that is legal. either way we walked to the other location which is 1) bigger! and 2) had someone with their dogs. If you want good and affordable vegan food, go to the other location at least there they care about their customers.
Food was AMAZING! The service was great. They have a nice outside seating area to relax and enjoy the food. I highly recommend!!

Honestly have been searching for a NYC pizza place with solid plain pies. Finally got close with Uptown Slices. Called and placed my order, the service was friendly and Delivery was fast. The plain cheese pie was great and I'll be ordering again. Let's keep the local pizzeria alive during these times. Tired of Seamless and Uber Eats jacking up the price.  And Tip your Delivery guy.

Order ahead for a fresh cheese calzone, and when you get there take a look at the various San Pelagrino sparking waters they have in the fridge. Small area with bar stool seating to eat in also makes it very convenient.

Sometimes, walking down the street or loading a washing machine, I suddenly realize that it has been months since I've had a slice. As a native Manhattanite who spent two years in the birthplace of Domino Pizza (Ann Arbor, MI), such a realization naturally fills me with shame and bewilderment. Pizza is cheap, readily available, and delicious. It's not atrociously unhealthy, nor is it at odds with vegetarianism. I have no excuse!

Except, it seems, that there just isn't a truly great pizza joint near my apartment. While it would've been a lifesaver in Michigan, Uptown Slices is average at best for NYC. There's not much sauce or cheese, and the plentiful crust is just okay. If you like chewy crusts, maybe you'll like it more than I do! There's usually just a plain cheese, a pepperoni and maybe one other pie ready for heatin-n-eatin.

All that said, it's just steps from the laundromat,  the guys who work here are always rays of sunshine, and it doesn't have much competition in the nabe. Solid spot for a simple slice.

What do you do when you graduate from college with expectations and plans based on other people's desires? You give them your degree to frame and follow your passion.

So the actual story is a bit different but the first time I walked in here I picked the owner's brain a little bit. He was very forthcoming and friendly in sharing what led him to open up shop.  The pizza is made with love from his own recipe. It's a slightly thin crust with a bit of chew.

The shop is quite small and you have a full, plain view of the kitchen from the door.  There are only about 6 stools to sit in and the place is clean.  They sell soda, Snapple, water and a variety of San Pellegrino flavors.

No bathroom available to customers. Staff is friendly, especially for a sliver of a shop, and they deliver in the immediate area. Nice to have another pizza option with a mom and pop feel.

Wish I could come more often to Uptown Slices. Superb location. Every thing that we purchased was extra fresh and yummy. All of the staff are very friendly - you most certainly feel welcome and taken care of. Uptown Slices = Amazing.

The pizza was about a 3. I changed my rating to a 4 though because:

1: THEY ACCEPT CARD!!!! I'm from California, a land where even street vendors take card, but here in Manhattan it seems like NOBODY takes card. So that was a HUGE plus.

2: the service was very quick

3: the workers were very nice

4: it wasn't too hot.
Great, convenient, and affordable NY pizza. If you love real garlic, try their garlic knots. They were delicious. Thanks for the friendly, quick service.

Amazing pizza, hand-crafted by dedicated owners. Fast, reliable and friendly service. A prize local business in our neighborhood. These guys are awesome. Try the Lasagna if you get a chance, it's great!

My order arrived 20 mins earlier than the time expected. When it arrived the delivery guy read back everything to ensure the order was correct. He was kind and very polite. I ordered again and like the first time... ZERO COMPLAINTS! They got themselves a new regular!
Best pizza in Harlem. Fast, inexpensive and really good. And the guys who work there are so friendly. Great neighborhood place.

Chef Toni has done a great job bringing her heritage (French/Italian/German?) and unique emotional viewpoint in executing deli classics. While students vigorously debate the best offerings - Chicken Tortilla Soup, Fresh Sandwich Bar, and the slightly underripe banana offer great value.

Do not miss this restaurant if you're stuck in 3022 Broadway without more than 5 minutes to grab lunch. Highly recommend!

There are a couple of times in human history where an entire population was able to survive single-handedly from the same quickly-spoiling food day in and day out. One was the manna that fed the Israelites in the wilderness for 40 years, and the other is Uris Deli. Cheers to this heavenly establishment.

value investors: the hot dog will fill your stomach in a way that's easy on your wallet

investment bankers: the buffalo chicken soup and bread rolls create a beautiful merger not even dreamed of in the far reaches of Earth's spreadsheets

luxury retail goods community: the hot lunch bar allows you to get coffee IN ADDITION to all the food you can fit into your plastic circular plate
Chef Toni's heavenly peanut butter and jelly cured my lifelong nut allergy. It's a miracle! And for only $3.95 plus tax.

Uris Deli is located inside Uris Hall on the campus of Columbia University. Uris Hall houses Columbia Business School and is frequented by CBS students as well as a variety of outsiders, both young and old. The Deli operates very efficiently, with wait-times almost never exceeding a minute.

While some stereotype Uris Deli food as "cafeteria-style", I believe the food is vastly underrated. The soups are absolutely fantastic. My favorites include the Hungarian Mushroom, Chili, and Chicken Noodle.  

Also vastly underrated is the daily buffet, the hallmark of which is Taco Wednesdays, where you are able to build your own soft or hard shell tacos, add a variety of meats and sauces, and add a side-drink for ~$10 a bowl. As recently as yesterday, I had the Spicy Chili Talapia buffett, which was some of the best fish I have had in New York! A true hidden gem!

The service is splendid. The wrap/sandwich station is surprisingly quick, the lines are never too long, and the cashiers are delightful. And the cherry on top: the health rating is an A.

For a quick bite on Columbia's campus as well as the chance at having a wonderful conversation with a full-time MBA, EMBA, or engineering/comp-sci student, I highly recommend Uris Deli. The food is great, the people are friendly, and the memories will last a lifetime.

Update: I almost forgot to write about the coffee! Uris Deli has about six different self-serve coffee dispensers where you can get varieties such as Java, Blue Java, and Super Blue Java. I often grab a cup, fill it with ice from the soda machine, and add coffee for my own version of "Morningside Heights Cold Brew". Highly recommended for a morning upper.

Update 2: To alleviate confusion, Uris Deli DOES have an "A" health rating. The coffee stand across from the deli (on the south side of the room) has the lower rating, though the coffee there is still great. Not sure why people are so concerned with health - I've seen what you've all been doing for two years. The least of your worries is the health rating of Uris Cafe.

Ask for a made-to-order deli sandwich on a baguette, tell them which toppings you wanted, and get it toasted. AMAAAAAZING.  They're very generous with the portions and will give you more meat than you can handle in one sitting!

Salt and pepper fish. Do it.

$7 for an overstuffed to-go box of rice and 3 entrees in the Asian food desert that is Columbia? Can't beat it. I get a good 2 meals out of this. String beans also good. I get the same thing, salt and pepper fish and two portions of string beans, once a week. Great deal. Real Asian food which you can't get in the dining hall. Nothing gourmet, nothing frilly, just some pretty good eats for $3.50 if you split it lunch and dinner.
excellent green beans. good greasy truck food. kind server, quick service, bang for buck. i recommend.

I disagree with some of the characterizations of the food here being sub-par. In fact, the food here is very passable. Yes, it doesn't exactly taste better than some of the other options on food truck row, but for value, UL is probably the best of the food truck options.

What time you come here will largely shape your ordering experience. As far as I can tell, it is always the one same dude operating the vehicle. During lunch, there can be pretty long lines, so keep that in mind. Columbia's block schedule for noon time ends at 11:55, so expect TONS of people to start showing up right around 12. As a result, if you come during this peak time, I'd say plan to wait at least 10 minutes to place your order. However, once you place your order, unless you order something complex, you should get your food in under a minute.

No cooking is done on board- I think all of it is done in their restaurant, which is actually located pretty nearby (106 and amsterdam), then brought over to the food truck via another vehicle. So, yes, the food isn't exactly its freshest the later in the day you get, but at the very least it's kept pretty hot. As for the food... for a safe bet, get the $7 rice box with tomato and egg, beef, and string beans. There are many other options here but until you start going several times and get a close look at some of the options yourself, don't order anything too wild. I also think the salt and pepper fish is quite good, in case you don't eat beef. I would also advise against the pork bun/burger. It's fairly filling and pretty affordable, but has very little taste, for some reason.

Something important to note: these people don't have fixed hours, but generally the truck will start closing down at about 7 oclock (as per my conversation with the staff). However, they might close earlier on some days, sometimes perhaps simply if they feel like it? One of the reasons this place closes early is because they'll sell out of food on any given day, and this can happen even as early as lunch time, with regards to certain items anyway. If you're going to come, try to stick to the 11-6 window.

I haven't tried this place recently but when I used to get it, I always got a stomachache which can only mean one of three things:  the ingredients are old/spoiled, the ingredients are not washed properly, or there is chemical leeching from plastics or other materials.

I was eyeing the Chicken Fried Rice, but after the cold 10 minute wait I was in, they said no fried rice today. So I asked about the noodles, and they said not that either--takes too long. At the end, I told them white rice would be fine. They said for lunch, I could choose 3 side dishes and the only thing I was feeling was fried chicken.

Upon opening my box, I was surprised to find literally only white rice (I thought I would be getting "Chicken Fried Rice" but instead of fried rice, it would be white rice...) and some weird looking fried chicken, not that I was expecting Popeye's or anything, with randomly hot parts. The chicken was quite salty, but otherwise alright, but this wasn't the lunch I was craving today. Kind of a let down. :(

Keywords: SALTY, FAT, SAD, RUN!
Tip #1.if you see a middle age woman, please fun. She gives very little food. Literally only one small spoon of my favorite tomato eggs.
Tip #2. Do NOT order the beef because it's ALL FAT and gross, or the fried chicken because it's ALL flour.
Tip #3. If you want to feel happy after eating your meal, do NOT come here because their food made me super sad during and after eating.
It's cheap. But next time I'd rather buy a $5 meal from the Hillel food car. Or get a burrito from Chipotle.

$7 for massive portion of 3 dishes over rice? Yes please. The food was very flavorful. I got the string beans, mapo tofu and pork with garlic sauce. Can def see why this is a hot spot for students. Cheap and delicious!

Onto the negatives: def don't recommend the sweet and sour chicken. It's all breading and no meat. As it is a food truck, it is a bit on the polite side.

This food truck is fantastic.

The hot and sour noodle soup was AWESOME. It comes with pork and peanuts (bleh).

The guy doesn't speak much English, I asked him for no peanuts and instead, he gave me no pork. I ended up Googling "peanuts" and showing him an image so he could fix my order.

This was the closest thing to Pho in my neighborhood so I loved it. It came with rice noodles and some great soup similar to Bon Bo Hue.

This is a low cost option near Columbia for lunch or dinner that is worth getting. I actually get food from this cart for lunch and always have a significant portion left over for dinner. Viewed like that, I am paying $3.50 for lunch and $3.50 for dinner.

Like others have said, you pick 3 options that go over rice. I recommend the salt and pepper fish, the braised beef (it's fatty though) and the tomato with egg. Food is not fancy or gourmet, and that's OK, I plan to be back.

Food truck that typically has a nice, long line no matter what time of day or night. I've never eaten here because walking to main campus for my lunch often takes way too long from my office.

I happened to be walking back to the office from this truck one evening and felt a bit peckish. I ordered the fried chicken noodle a.k.a. lo mein with fried chicken bits and it was above average, but nothing stellar.

Now, this is the only thing I sampled, so the rating is purely based on these chicken noodles, but they were flavorful, not too greasy and the battered chicken was a nice touch. I asked for plenty of sriracha and dug right in. Generous portion for $6 and it was ready pretty quickly, so I could sneak back to the office without being gone too long.

I'd have to return and try a few other things on their small, BBQ menu to see if they really deserve to have these long lines of students waiting for their noodle and rice fare. Overall, decent meal and if you're pressed for time (or your wallet is being stretched too thin) this is a convenient truck for a quick meal.

Chef Ken is amazing. Unique Omakase has a very run down look on the outside, and a very generic sounding name, but the food inside is great. Chef Ken prepared each part of the omakase with different flavors and they used a great variety of fish. Some omakase places give you a lot of the standard fish (salmon, yellowtail, tuna) with little variety but we had fish like dorade royale and kuromutsu here in addition to the standards. Most importantly, you felt the difference in taste of the different fish. The setting is intimate, about 12 seats I think, with each chef responsible for 6 people each. I never felt rushed like at some omakase places and the chef spoke both English and Chinese to explain each piece. I also read another yelp review commenting that the chef is chinese. It is funny when people mention the ethnicity or sex of the chef when what matters is how the food tastes and Chef Ken made the food taste great. Even when you go to Michelin star omakase restaurants, the main chef whose Japanese name may be on the restaurant may not even be there so guess who is preparing your sushi? It's clear that Chef Ken had the training and practice to do justice to the fish.

Is this going to be the best omakase you've ever had? Of course not. But unique omakase 100% punches above its weight and is worth the money you spend there (Currently $96 for 16 courses - 3 appetizers, 11 nigiri, 1 handroll and 1 dessert). Will definitely be coming again.

I've been to a ton of omakase spots in NYC and this one is definitely up there with the best.

It's 16 courses for $96 which is one of the best deals I've seen, but what really makes it special is how fresh & creative each course is.

The staff is extremely nice and answered all of our questions about where the fish came from and why it's paired with certain things.

Also the fact that it's BYOB is a major win for New Yorkers.

"Unique" is a bit of a misnomer. More like "less commonplace than all the other boring Edomae omakase spots". See also: Sushi chef is Chinese. Is that unique?

Anyway, this is one of the more affordable options in the city for 15 courses ngiri and small apps. $85 will nab you some fun dishes like shrimp in shell with uni and seasoned seaweed.

But the main reason to come here? Your birthday. We did a group birthday dinner here (3 out of 4 of us had May birthdays) and were surprised with not one but two generous dishes of birthday sashimi and rice--for free! And those were some pretty generous cuts of salmon, tuna and yellowtail.

Me like free.

I will say this omakase lives up to its name, it is unique (in a good way)!

For $85 you get 15 courses and I will say it is well worth the price. I was excited and engaged in each course because not all were traditional nigiri.

There were composed sashimi bites and a miso soup (on the house) course integrated in the omakase, which was a nice respite and all so complex and perfectly timed.

Atmosphere was modern and service was impeccable. Definitely check out this spot especially to those looking for a stray from a traditional omakase!

I am SO impressed with this place! This is very worth the price. Very unique in NYC, and I have had quite a few omakase places! We made reservations here day of a few hours before while wandering around NYC and it was such a happy surprise.

A few pros
- 15 courses!!!!! VERY GENEROUS. I remember being at course 7, and I could not believe we weren't even half way over. It was insane. And the portions were HUGE.
- No time rush. Usually cheaper omakase places are like 60 or 90 minutes and you feel like you are heaving down all the food. It makes it more about eating than actually enjoying the company and time. I LOVED this one. We ended up being there for close to 2.5hours. It was nice getting to spend time and chat with the people I came with.
- Very intimate setting. Not a big restaurant! I say there was 10 to 12 people at the bar max.

ANYWAYS, in general I am a huge huge fan of this place and I will be coming back! I'm almost kind of sad to be leaving a review, bc I think this place will blow up and be annoying hard to get reservations.

Made a reservation for Tues. at 7:30pm for 2 and we were the only people dining there the entire time.

Maybe we went on an off day but they had to substitute a couple of the pieces with different fishes since they were out. That was disappointing. The pieces are more creative than the traditional omakase spots. We also got the Sexy Mac as an add on and it was a really good rich mouthful, worth the $26.

Overall, I had high expectations since I was recommended this place but my experience was a little different than my friend's and I was left feeling like something was missing. However, 15 pieces for $85 is definitely a steal since other places nearby are charging more for less. I would recommend coming on the weekend when they have done most of the prep for their busy days and perhaps all the fishes will be in stock.

This place doesn't look like very much and you can walk right past it. They've only been open for 2 months. Currently it's BYOB since they are still awaiting their liquor license. It's best to make reservations since it's a relatively small restaurant. For $85 and 15 pieces it's a good deal and compatible to other omakase places in the neighborhood.
The chef was catering about 6 of us at a time. They were very consistent with the tea and water were served and the cups were never empty. Service was very good. I look forward to the next time I'm back.

15pcs for $85 and BYOB!

Truly "unique" since some of the fish combo were different than other Omakase I've had ex. Tuna w truffle  radish or madai with hot yuzu sauce. The chef was nice and friendly and the waiters were attentive. If you're looking for something new, give this place a try

纽约omakase遍地开花，在下着些小雨的周五，我打卡了这家传说中同胞开的诚意满满的性价比高高的omakase----Unique Omakase

15道course 85刀一个人不含税不含小费，店内装修潦草，喂就算打性价比牌子表面功夫还是要做一下的啊！一般来说日料店档次怎么样，看厨师后面架子上的酒就能看出来。看了一圈都是一些比较低档的开架清酒，用的器皿和杯子也都是不成套的，茶杯的手感有点次，没有陶器应有的厚重质感，感觉像从超市进的货...透明水杯是宜家的，这些其实很容易改进。

菜单罗列很清晰接地气，你这85刀每口吃掉了多少还真能算出来，但最后也没有吃饱，每一份都很小。本来是冲着白子来的，结果主厨说没了...暴风哭泣，不过多送了一片Scallop sashimi.

整体调味有点复杂，鱼虽然新鲜，但很多味道都被配料侵占了，导致口腔里鱼肉的鲜味冲不上去。甜品我有点无力吐槽，因为我还挺重视甜品这一环的，一顿饭如何收尾非常影响整体印象，mochi雪糕就和超市里的一模一样...

虽然说吃的还可以，但倒真没有那种卧槽赚到性价比之王的感觉，就是一分钱一分货吧，实在。

也可能我去的那天不巧，感觉食材和用料没有其他小红书发的那么大方[笑哭R]氛围非常一般，可能是所谓的匠心不够？导致没有很享受吃寿司的过程，就是一贯接一贯，半个小时就吃完了，主厨像没有感情的做寿司机器。服务员和厨师一看你是中国人，也非常自然直接用中文给你介绍，倒是挺亲切。

12/10 recommend for a wonderful and delicious dinner in a low key environment. Big hole-in-the-wall vibes and the food is amazinggggg. The inside is very nice with only bar seating (10-16 max) which is great because you get to see the chefs put together the beautiful creations for you to eat. Each piece is unique with such a wide range of flavors. The staff is super friendly, attentive and easy to get to know. They remember people and take care of return customers. $85 for 15 (!) courses is totally reasonable, especially given the experience. Hope y'all will go show them some love and support!

It's a great experience for the price. I enjoyed the food a lot and service was great. The chef threw me an extra piece and that was super nice of him. 15 pieces are a decent amount and I was super full afterwards. I'd say this place is more modern sushi experience rather than traditional though. I'd recommend it.

This little hole in the wall located in East Village that recently opened is a pretty solid value for money. Would recommend.

Food: 15 courses for $85 (a steal!!) but I'd say it's more like 14 courses of 'real sushi' and then mochi (which were super yummy, no hate). Each portion is slightly smaller sized than usual omakase places, which was fine for me. I still left feeling very satiated.

Standout sushi pieces were the Scallop and o Toro. Always a sucker for those. The toast was creative and as restaurant name implies, very 'unique' but also very 'odd' to me (sorry not sorry). Initial taste was odd but after opening my mind to new experiences, aftertaste was actually quite good! It's really hard to write descriptions about sushi - but the phrases that come to mind are fresh, yummy, variety. So good memories!

Seating is about ~10-12 people along a sushi bar, as well as a cute, sheltered (but not super well ventilated) outdoor space where we were able to cut our cake and chill after the omakase meal! The AC was strong inside, 100% necessary in this summer heat

Btw - pet friendly :)

10/10 would recommend.

I LOVE UNIQUE OMAKASE! I have come to this restaurant six times now lol, and every time I came, it got better. Whether it's the program of omakase, the balance of the sushi, dessert, or service, every time I come, they made it better.

Now they don't have a menu of what they serve, and I quite like that. Because I genuinely look forward to what will be the next piece.

Also, it is not a big place, but there's a room behind where you sit so you can walk freely without getting into someone's face lol also, the room in the back where you can finish your drink after your meal is just top notch!

Quite a good selection of items for the Omakase! Definitely somewhat unique and different flavor profiles. A small sake selection available too. Would come back for a quick and friendly meal.

The shop is located in the East Village, and you need to buzz the front door to come in. It would be nice if the buzzer was less loud or silent.

Wow, how fortunate we are to find this hidden gem! At first we realized this omakase location did not have a single review, which made us skeptical about trying it out. However, the pricing and selection appeared reasonable so we decided to try it out. Boy, was that the best decision ever! The selections followed exactly the menu by, with a few exceptions since they were missing the seabass and saba, and each piece was incredibly fresh and flavorful! Our chef, Ken, utilized yuzu, truffle, and other seasoning ingredients to bring out the bright flavors and freshness of every single piece! We are incredibly lucky to come across this location, for they only opened shop 3 days ago! So if you can, definitely come here before they skyrocket as one of the most affordable and delicious omakase in NYC! Some of our most memorable pieces are: the fresh and meaty kumonomo oyster with uni, the shima aji, the bouncy botan ebi with uni, the incredibly meaty hotate, Chu toro, the melt in your mouth seared o toro & CAVIAR, fresh truffle and Hokkaido uni, and A5 wagyu with melt in your mouth FOIE GRAS!!

Every piece was delicious and fresh. Since some other omakases offer 10 course for well over 100 dollars, this 15 course is definitely very generous and was worth every penny! They also offered us their Black & Gold house sake which was incredibly smooth. Definitely a must-try omakase experience!

A unique omakase experience, indeed! This place gets 5 stars because the fish is fresh, presentation is amazing and worth the price tag, and service was amazing.

I went here to celebrate a friend's birthday, and it did not disappoint.

Fresh fish + innovative presentation: You could tell that all the fish served to us was extremely fresh. It melted in my mouth and the texture and mouth feel of the fish served to us was delicious. My favorite piece was definitely the oyster served with uni AND caviar.

Great value: I've never had so many gold flakes or caviar or pieces of truffle served during an omakase! It was such a nice surprise and definitely had flavors unlike any other omakase I've had before.

I would definitely come back here again and bring your friends! It is free BYOB which can easily turn this into an even greater value if you're tryna split some drinks with friends.

You can easily miss the place when walking by but this is a must try! This place offers 15 courses for $85 - which is honestly a pretty good price for that amount of pieces. Every fish was fresh, the place was quiet and had good music playing. Staff was friendly. Will definitely come back again!

Fire highly recommend for something calm but semi bougie
Fatty tuna is my favorite piece with the caviar

Not even sure where to begin. Been to just about every Omakase spot in NYC and I put this at the top of my list.

Friendly sushi chefs and service provided matches the quality of the sushi. Menu consistently evolving and changes based on the fish they overnight from Japan. Fresh and truly a Unique Omakase experience (pun intended) lol

Not sure you can find another $85 Omakase menu comparable to $200+

I came here for their 15 course Omakase for $85 and it was amazing! Surprisingly this made me full and it had everything in the course (appetizer, sashimi plate, nigiri, hand roll, and dessert)! My favorite has to be the seared O-toro, but everything was amazing! I highly recommend if you're looking for an amazing experience for you palate!

Super intimate space. The chef and small staff were so kind and attentive. Sushi was incredible. While each piece was delicate and artfully assembled, we still left feeling full and satisfied. Definitely check out this spot for delicious and affordable omakase.

Unique Omakase

July 23, 2022

A laid back 75 minutes of luxurious experience complimented with seafood delicacies satisfying every taste bud for Japanese gastronomy enjoyers for under $90!!!

You know what's unique about this restaurant? I don't even know how there is any profit margin. There is legit caviar. Legit truffles. Legit uni. Legit legit legit. Fresh! Look at the pictures. Quality is insanely superbly marvelous. Chef Xin's knife technique is perfect along the rice texture and flavor. Everything is on point and far beyond expectations. Words cannot describe what I want to say. Must visit to enjoy and appreciate the work of art they have achieved through a unique gastronomy experience. This restaurant has been added to my favorite restaurants of all time.

July 28, 2022
Today we came back a second time. This time we dragged my parents along. I was craving for sushi so what should I do? Come to Unique Omakase!!  Another crazy experience we have enjoyed here again. Quality is exactly the same. We left with a big smile grinning ear to ear. They had lots of amazing Japanese gastronomy in Hong Kong and still praising how fresh and good it is here. Definitely best bang for your buck!

Fresh fish, good match up on omakase, made it with all heart
Good quality, and they try fish with different sea, then import Best one, definitely going back again

We heard about this place recently so Me and my friend went to this place couple days ago, but it was a total disappointment.
The experience was so bad, we didn't get any service at all. Once we got seated the server just came up to us and offer cup of water and never went back to ask if we needed anything the whole time. The sushi rice was hard most of the sushi there are lack of flavor just like defrosted fish and additionally the chef there never talk to us while serving cause he was too busy talking to others. I felt disrespected the whole time. I guess we'll never going back again and definitely would not recommend this place to anyone.

We got super lucky,  found this place during their soft opening.   This is one of the best omakase that I have tried.   i was skeptical when i saw the price was under $100,  and if you factor in the value to quality ratio,  this is by far one of the best meals...   The dishes were creative,  first time i had foie gras sushi,  at the price included caviar and wagyu sushi as well.

On a quest to try every under $150 omakase in NYC. This gets 7 out of 10.

Tried it the week it opened so the kitchen still working out the kinks. Ikura was the star, some of the best I had. Rice was ok, not enough vinegar (usually it's the opposite) and it rarely reached umami because of that. The blander pieces of fish that need rice that need carry them through fell through. The more intense (uni, ikura) were great. Overall the pieces were on the fattier side, too fatty for me. Biggest disappointment was microwaved, dry eel (unagi). Hopefully they will iron those things out because it seems promising.

We stumbled upon this relatively new spot in the East Village and were happy we did! With just about 10 seats inside, it is a very intimate restaurant. The chef took the time to engage with us and tell us about each of the 15 items he would be making for our Omakase, and we enjoyed every one! It is currently BYOB and they poured the sake and whiskey we brought whenever our glasses were empty.Will definitely be going back soon!

Wow. Just wow. I had to try a new omakase restaurant while on a business trip to NYC, and stumbled upon Unique Omakase. The restaurant opened earlier this month, and the food was incredible -- fresh, flavorful seafood, and creative composition. I was very impressed by the owner / chef, who has been making sushi in NYC for 20+ years.

By dessert time (after 14 courses + 2 complimentary courses), I thought I wouldn't be able to eat any more.. but the mochi ice cream was a must have.
Great quality fish and price. The staff were also extremely kind. Definitely will be coming back!

some of the best sushi i've ever had in my life. definitely worth make a trip to the east village to go to.

I was told that they were in a soft opening phase and they're having problems with other apps, but once they're fully open we'll be back many times.
Loved the atmosphere! Set up and most importantly sashimi and sushi dishes ! Will come back !

The quality, taste, and presentation are spectacular. $85 for 15 courses and they also have a 10 course option for lunch. Very good price for the quality. We've been to a lot of omakase spots in the city and with all things considered this is one of the very best. Owners are also very sweet and it was a pleasure to dine at their restaurant. Highly recommend!!

This is really worth! Only $85 person for 15 courses. Food
is amazing and fresh. Chef is very professional. I will come back many times when it is fully open.

So good and fresh! Everything melted in my mouth. Drinks are BYOB :) I just wished maybe the lights were slightly dimmer and louder music so it creates a more classy atmosphere but the sushi was so good and our chef was really nice. Will definitely come back

This place completely ruined my holiday. I have been working and studying non-stop and all I wanted to do was treat myself to a little something on the 4th of July before I started my day of studying. I made a reservation for here on Resy and was looking forward to it. When I arrived it was closed even though they asked for my credit card information to hold my reservation. It's extremely frustrating to be on a time crunch wondering around the streets on a holiday trying to find a suitable replacement. Just ended up eating nothing.
A fairly priced place. BYOB for now. Would recommend make atmosphere/BGM/food consistent.
Delicious, fresh and affordable! Amazing flavor combos and a great new spot. Will definitely be back!

Friday night and craving sushi. Made a rez and was seated promptly by friendly staff. Really enjoyed the high quality fish paired with interesting accents such as caviar, chunks of truffle, roasted garlic, and tomato. Staff was very considerate -- they gave me an extra salmon piece when they saw I was not having the mochi ice cream dessert (I'm lactose intolerant).  Recommend!
I went back and had diarrhea for 2 days after eating here.  The chef talk to each other all the time, fast food omakase, no sense of atmosphere!  Really not recommended

This place is a bad addition to the neighborhood. They don't honor reservations, yet they are all too happy to charge your card to hold your reservation. Simple message, if you accept a reservation be open. If you cannot accept a reservation then change your settings on reservation platforms. Shame on you. You will never have my business again. I saw many other people waiting outside your restaurant who also had the same issue. Not a good look, do better!
Great new omakase spot in the East Village. Won't be surprised if they start to book up quickly. 15 courses for $85 is a steal and each course is delicious.
Incredible and unique. Very high quality, and the chef is awesome - definitely check it out.

SO DELICIOUS!! FOOD COMES OUT SO FAST!! VIBES ARE AMAZING!! And on top of that, my Chinese friends approve and take me here. It is truly a testament to see how long the line extends for dinner time.

Food: 10/10. So delicious. My favorites are the Beef Rice in Stone Bowl and String Beans with Eggplant. They are to die for. And for the price, this is insane for NYC.
Drink: I only got the Osmanthus Oolong Cocktail and it was really delicious, but super light, not sure if I tasted any alcohol.
Service: crazy amazing. They are so fast with the food coming out. The tables are a bit small so the staff are very attentive and efficient in reorganizing our table to fit everything. When you come, you will need to put your name on the waitlist. The process is very smooth.

we got the garlic eggplant, shanghai pork soup dumplings, scallion pancakes, sichuan chilli fried chicken, fish in pickled cabbage, peking duck, sautéed string beans, cabbage and glass noodles.

some of the dishes were just ok -- the dumplings (skin too thick), scallion pancakes, fried chicken (quite spicy but unbalanced ratio of chilli peppers to chicken), peking duck (skin wasn't really crispy).

the rest of the dishes were delicious! especially the eggplant. the staff were very accommodating for our huge group. we walked in at 5pm and got a seat easily without reservation.

First off, I loved the vibes here! The inside was modern and sleek, which made it a perfect setting for intimate dates.

We quickly got seated on a Thursday night with a short 5 min wait. We ordered 3 dishes for 2 people which didn't seem like enough at first with its smaller plates but it ended up being more than enough food.

We loved the roast pork egg fried rice and stir fried pork belly with egg. Both were so flavorful and cooked just right. We also ordered the Mapo tofu which we weren't a fan of. This might just be based on personal preference - I'm used to the Cantonese style Mapo tofu and I don't like the Szechuan "mala" numbing spice. Other than that, I'll definitely come back again. It was delicious and affordable, considering it's NY.

Great ambiance and yummy Bloom cocktail! Service was unfortunately very slow and not attentive. We ordered the Sweet & Sour Ribs (9/10), Crab Meat Soup Dumplinge (6/10) and the Rice in Hot Stone Bowl (5/10, a little bland).
I personally didn't think that the food lived up to the nice ambiance of the restaurant, but would definitely come back for a drink or two either before or after dinner!

I've been to Uluh twice already! I love Szechuan food and I would get it even if it was 90 degrees outside. I enjoy the ambience of this place and the staff also make it super enjoyable. They are extremely attentive and takes the time to answer any questions about the menu. And I love how they warn us about the spice level haha!

Although pricey, I think this is one of the top Szechuan places in NYC for me. They are great portions, the flavors are there, and they don't skimp out on the meats/seafood. They also have great cocktails, all very creative and unique, although I don't think they're generous with their liquor pour.

My siblings and I shared:
- dan dan noodles - good portion, perfect texture noods, signature Szechuan dish
- mapo tofu with meat - love the flavors, very spicy, but pairs well with rice
- fried whole fish with pineapple - this was our favorite, the fish was fried to perfection and that sweet and sour sauce was the perfect complement to the texture of the fish
- beef and tripe in chili oil - another classic, also, the most generous portion I've seen in NYC restaurants
- fish in homemade pickled cabbage - there was a KICK to the soup but it's perfect for a cold day. The fish was fresh and plump and the soup has so many flavors. I'm drooling thinking about it!

We also got a few desserts, they were all so pretty and unique.

Give this place a try, you won't regret it. But bring friends!
Pretty authentic and the flavors were quite on point. The boiled beef, soup dumplings, Sichuan fried chicken, all just really done well.

Not too bad. For my personal preference I didn't find this store as good as it was hyped to be.

The vegetable was a bit bland and the Peking duck wasn't THAT good. The "bun" hardened very quick and made it harder to chew.

Service was also a bit slower than expected, had to waive down the waiters multiple times but they were still overall pretty attentive - they brought me a new pair of chopsticks when I dropped mine to the ground.

The 无锡猪蹄 also known as the Boneless Pork Trotters was simply amazing. It is a must order on every table. It's so tender and savory - the perfect amount of spice for a flavorful eat.

The drinks were also good. My friends got the Tipsy Peach - it was carbonated so you don't taste the alcohol but I'm sure there's like half a shot in there.

Wow!! I didn't have high expectations for these dishes, but everything was super yummy. Every single thing had lots of flavor, but the taker of the night was the sautéed string beans. It was crunchy, flavorful and not overly salty. Additionally, the tipsy beach was so good! Light and refreshing with a hint of sake so you're feeling just buzzed.

Service was very nice, and they were very helpful and attentive. They gave us everything we needed to have a positive dining experience. The area was dimly lit but with lights right above the table so the "spotlight," was just on us. We also sat at a table with a shield that gave us a very private area. It was definitely a better experience than expected!

Although all the food we tried was good, I think the dishes were overall overpriced.

Mini pumpkin puff: surprisingly one of our favorites - the outside of the puff was crispy, and the inside had warm, liquid salted egg yolk
Brown sugar glazed peking duck: pricey but the duck was very well made, and paired well with the wraps and sauce
Boneless pork trotters: spicy and savory pork - it was very tasty but portion size was rather small for the price
Vegetable fried rice: a pretty Americanized dish
Crab Tofu: soft tofu in crab sauce, portion size was rather small

Staff were friendly, and service was fast. The dim lighting and elegant decor added to a sophisticated dining ambiance.

My son was raving about this place saying that it is his fav Sichuan place in New York. So we went here for lunch. Got there at 11:30 when they just opened, got seated promptly. When we were seated the restaurant was almost empty. About 10 minutes later when I turned around, the restaurant was full house and bustling already. By the time we ate and left there was a long line outside on a Sunday afternoon.

What we ate:
*Cucumber salad: refreshing, just the right amount of spicy. Crunchy and perfect appetizer to get our appetites going.
*Woodear mushroom salad: cooked to perfection. Springy, fresh, woodsy, and good crunch to bite. Lovely salad for mushroom lovers
*Mapo blood tofu - mapo tofu made with silky tofu and duck blood. Sooooo yummy!! Very good and this dish alone makes this place!
*Boneless pork trotters - wow! Gelatinous pork trotters abound this dish with spicyness that will last you the whole week and not for people who can't handle spicy food. Very good!
*Lamb ribs volcano - juicy and tender ribs twice cooked to crispy morsels. Spiced generously with Sichuan peppers and peppercorns. Not for the faint of heart.
*Crispy duck - this was one dish that didn't hit the mark. Duck was dry and seasoning on a salty side.

If you order a pot of tea, they come with two tea cups, but the cups are more like sake cups. Very small. Need to switch their cups to proper tea cups. Decor is modern and catering to younger crowd like my son. Modern Shanghai vibe.

Highly recommend this place for a solid Sichuan/Hunan style Chinese food!

Though expensive, Uluh was delicious. I dropped in on a Thursday night with a friend to try some of the Peking duck (which is the first time I've had the dish) and I'm definitely going to come back for more.

The cocktails at Uluh were quite interesting - they didn't serve it in a glass but rather a pitcher which I was left to pour into a shot glass of sorts to drink from. They do have a cute gourd motif to everything which was quite fun.

Highly recommend Uluh overall, but I'd likely not order any drinks in the future.
The duck was excellent like last time.  The fish dish had ample meat, as well as an exuberance of kick and spiciness.  Okra was crispy and the dan dan noodles were great.

Really authentic Szechuan style food with dishes thar warm the soul and encourage a family-style meal experience. Portions were big and perfect for sharing in big groups. We particularly enjoyed the crab tofu, sauteed string beans, fish fillet with green peppercorn, and spicy crispy chicken. While it is a bit pricey, I feel the cost is justified by the quality of food and how Hwappy you are after leaving the establishment.

After hearing amazing things about this spot, I was super excited to try it! I came with a group of 7 at around 6:30 PM. We had to wait around an hour for a table. However, I'd say the wait was worth it. We ordered a ton of dishes:
- sweet and sour pork ribs: one of my faves tonight
- tripe in chili oil
- sour and spicy fish
- beef fried rice
- pumpkin crispy balls? I thought these were super yummy and this dish was actually recommended to me but not everyone liked them :(
- half duck
- szechuan chili chicken: also a fave
- soup dumplings
Overall the bill came to around $35 per person. I would definitely recommend this spot!

This restaurant is everything! I always like to judge a restaurant based on the bathroom and this one had heated seats - incredible.

Brought my mom who was visiting here for some elevated Chinese food. We were that hungry so we split an entree and an app which was the perfect amount of food.

The shrimp rice cake in truffle sauce was unlike anything I've had before and it was so flavorful. This is a must! The mix of chewy rice cake texture with with al dente shrimp covered in a truffle oil sauce is immaculate.

The fried crispy pork was sprinkled in a mild spicy seasoning which was tasty but honestly you can skip this. It's nothing special.

The staff was so attentive and filled my water up every-time it was below half without me asking. We also were there around 2pm on a Friday so it wasn't that crowded but still busy for that time of day.

The prices are a bit higher but it's really good food!

Really enjoyed my experience at uluh! My friends and I were waiting for a table of 4 on a Friday around 6PM. Our wait wasn't too long. The interior design of the restaurant feels mixed traditional/modern and a bit moody, but really loved the set up.

I tried this restaurant when they just updated their menu, so for some items I don't have the exact name because I wasn't able to reference the newer menu, but I'm trying to describe them as best as possible!

Here is a list of items I would recommend trying:
- osmanthus oolong cocktail -- the presentation for this cocktail is super unique and you're essentially sipping from a teacup!
- cucumber salad -- super simple and garlicky. It was refreshing and was a great balance from the other dishes
- fish fillet in chili oil -- huge serving of fish and extremely spicy. It was really flavorful though and had the perfect amount of mala
- stir fry pork belly with bell peppers -- the pork belly is on the crispy side, so adds in a bunch of texture to the meal
- (can't find name) -- it's a sesame + mala soup based noodle dish. It has the thin potato noodles with some sliced beef inside. It came in a more traditional looking pot but would recommend getting this as well if your server can think of it!

We also got sautéed string beans. These were solid but not mind blowing. Would recommend trying another vegetable!

~ Braised Pork Trotter w/ Chilli ~
The pork trotter is super smooth and tender, very flavourful too as it is soaked in a chilli sauce. What's best is that they have a warmer (candle underneath the plate), so the sauce won't solidify (since trotters have a lot of collagen, the sauce would become dense and sticky when it gets cold).

~ Fish in Green Peppercorn ~
I think this is the spiciest dish of all 3, as I spicy lover I'm satisfied with this level of spiciness! Altho it is soaked in chilli oil, I don't find it that greasy, maybe because it is a  very aromatic and flavourful chilli oil, adds great flavour to the fish and vegetables. The fish itself is ok, not the freshest fish I had but it's acceptable.

~ Sichuan Chilli Fried Chicken ~
This dish is surprisingly good (I had really low expectations because I thought it would probably taste like American fried chicken lmao). The fried chicken is mixed together with a lot of spices and chilli, very flavourful and with a hint sweetness (the traditional ones wouldn't have any sweetness, but I kinda like it becoz it's very light and slightly enhanced the flavour profile). It's not really spicy though.

Will I be back? Probably
I like spicy food! t's not 100% authentic but I guess it's good enough and I'm satisfied.

This restaurant is sooooo good!! Everything we ordered from the rainbow soup dumplings, to the pancakes to the duck were all delicious!
The tables are very tight so just be aware of that but as soon as you start dining your just amazed of how good everything is. Especially the duck! The duck comes with these thin little wraps which is enough to share but you can also order your own. Everything tastes super fresh also. The service was good and the ambiance is cute.
There was a bit of a wait when I arrived but it was well worth it.

Uluh is one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in NYC! Their food is amazing and the interior design is impeccable and perfect for family and friends gatherings. I've been going very often and ordering a lot of takeouts over the last few years and their food never disappoints. The only thing I'd comment is probably the portion. I wish their portions are more generous considering the price point they set.

Service-wise, they're just ok. They don't take reservations which is rlly a bummer. There's usually a very long wait especially over the weekends so I'd suggest you go early to put your name down and wander around the Eats Village while you wait.

Some of their most popular dishes include the Peking roast duck, soup dumplings, spicy pork trotters, etc. These top hits are all MUST ORDERS and I also wanna recommend getting the pumpkin dessert towards the end if your meal. They're super cute to look at and super yummy to taste!

Already thinking about my next Uluh foodie adventure

This chic restaurant offers a modern twist on traditional Chinese food! The interior ambiance is beautiful and sleek. Service is quick and friendly, and speaks both Cantonese and Mandarin!

Starting with a classic, the duck fried rice is perfectly fried. The duck flavor is present but not overpowering or too heavy or greasy on the palate. The portions are rather large for this dish!

The Szechuan chili fish is a little too oily, but par for the course for Szechuan cuisine. The spice is pungent and the fish is very tender and flakey.

The star of the show: the signature Peking duck! The wrap is very soft and gently holds the roll of duck, crispy skin, cucumber, and dressing together. The crispy skin steals the spotlight here: the crunchy texture with the sweet and savory flavor is a perfect bite. The duck meat is also very tender and flavorful.

I recommend the soy milk with red bean and mochi; the drink itself has such a unique, chewy texture from the mochi! It's also a great palate cleanser from the salt and spice.

Overall, I can't wait to come back!

If Uluh has one fan it is ME!! I've been to this place 5+ times now and loved it every time. Uluh is what really brought me to Sichuan food! The wait does get pretty long on most nights so make sure to book a reservation :)

I've tried quite a few of their dishes:

Mapo Tofu: A classic Sichuan dish. I find that theirs is pretty spicy and peppery but sometimes lacking flavor outside of the spice. Not the best thing on their menu but you can't go wrong! 7/10

Fish in Homemade Picked Cabbage: REALLY good if you enjoy sour soups. The dish was perfectly seasoned and the fish was cooked just the right amount. 9/10

Lobster Mapo Tofu: Sublime!! Expensive but the portion is big- good for sharing. Better flavoring than the regular mapo tofu and generous amount of lobster! 9.5/10

Pork Soup Dumplings: A very standard soup dumpling in my opinion- expensive for what you get. 5/10

Stir Fried Pork Belly with Egg: I get this dish every time I come because it helps break the spicy dishes. The egg is cooked pretty firm which goes well with the pork. Very well seasoned! 9/10

Uluh is modern upscale sichuan place which serves a number of elevated Chinese classics. Although a little pricey, the flavors and food overall deliver. Service can be a bit slow when they get busy - it took us a while to flag a waiter for a water refill.

Some of the highlights of our meal were the Beijing style roast duck (which comes with wraps), the vegetarian dry pot, and the pork trotters. Note the pork trotters might not be fit for everyone as they do taste more fatty as they are pork feet.

We also got the crab tofu and the rose lychee Panna cotta. The crab tofu oddly tasted a little like Salted eggs and there didn't seem to be much crab meat. Despite this, it was really tasty. The rose lychee Panna cotta that we got totally took us by surprise as it didn't taste or look like Panna cotta. The presentation was nice, but it had the consistency or shaped rose/lychee ice cream rather than Panna cotta.

Probably my favorite Chinese place in manhattan!! The interior is beautiful and all the food is presented amazingly with great lighting haha. All the food has punches of flavor and can't go wrong with any dishes

Amazing spot for authentic Szechuan! As a group of five, we ordered quite a few of the menu items and were surprised to be so full with a 1/3 of the bill we expected to receive. Everything was delicious and the Mapo tofu was a favorite for me. Very cute and great for larger groups as well. Wonderful service & quick to accommodate without any reservations needed. Can't wait to come back!

Overall 10/10
One of my new favorite Chinese restaurants in LES. I love food with strong flavors, and Uluh definitely does not shy away from putting spice and flavors into its food. Most of the food is spicy. If you're not a spicy food lover, maybe some of the dishes are not the right restaurant for you, but there are still a lot of other none spicy options for you to choose from.

Interior 10/10
The interior is sleek, and beautiful, and makes you feel like this is a restaurant of taste.

Line: 8/10
If you come here during lunch or dinner rush hour, you 100% have to wait in line for a while, so I highly recommend you make an appointment. However, if you come to a small party, I actually don't think the wait is that bad. It's very double compare to other popular restaurant in the city

If you're looking for peking duck, this is the place to go. Their signature brown sugar glazed peking duck is AMAZING and always leaves me craving for more. If you have a larger party I 100% recommend getting the large size. It comes with the traditional toppings including the pancake/wrap, scallions, cucumbers, and sauce. Of course, their other Sichuan dishes are great too. I enjoy the spiced lamb ribs and thin sliced pork with pepper. For dessert, I would recommend their mini pumpkin puffs, which are filled with egg custard inside. Uluh doesn't take reservations, but the wait is quick.

Classy and modern Chinese restaurant with high quality food from different regions of China but mainly Sichuan. They offer all day dim sum options to go with other authentic Chinese foods. I ordered the Uluh Dim Sum Platter ($20) - the mushroom, corn, and shrimp, har gow and shrimp/corn shumai were both really good. The har gow skin could've been slightly tighter but was still tasty with a nice stretchiness.

The Lychee Shrimp Balls ($27) were really interesting as they came on these long skewers (refer to the pic) and were literally balls with lychee and shrimp inside- a very interesting combo that I've never seen before but as a fan of both lychee and shrimp, I enjoyed very much as the lychee gave a nice sweetness while the shrimp gave some savory flavor to go along with the fried exterior. There was also some skewered fruit as well (pineapple and strawberry).

I also ordered the Scallion Pancake ($7), which was average.

The other dishes I tried like the Braised Chicken with Chili ($23) were decent as well but definitely have some heat and should only be tried by those who enjoy spicy foods.

The interior of the restaurant is really nice with dimmed lighting for an intimate experience, and nice elegant decor that incorporates a somewhat minimalistic modern style with some traditional elements mixed in. There is some interesting modern artwork along the walls too. There is quite a lot of seating and it was pretty busy on a Friday night. They only accept walk-ins but we only had to wait a short time for a table. The noise level is moderate. The staff were friendly, helpful, and very attentive. The prices were definitely a bit on the high end but could be expected given the nice environment.

Overall, I would give Uluh a solid 4.5 stars if I could. While the food was very good and I loved the environment, the prices were just a bit high, so I am settling on 4 stars for this review. Still, if you are looking for a nice modern Chinese restaurant, then Uluh would be a great option for you.

Nice ambiance and fast service! We ordered tons of food here and although nothing REALLY shined, I think the basics were done well. Really loved the pumpkin puff as it reminded me of the salted egg yolk dessert at dimsum places, and was also a fan of the woodear mushroom salad and pea shoots.

The crab tofu was creamy but got cold a little quickly, and the picked vegetable fish was definitely quite spicy, but was filled with veggies like enoki mushroom, cabbage, and glass noodles which complemented the dish well. The fish was also soft, but standard of boiled fish I have had at other chinese restaurants.

We arrived an hour before closing but were told to order quickly because the kitchen was closing. Food came out quickly and tasted great! Portions are perfect for family style sharing. The restaurant was nice but the tables in the front were very close together so could get loud and hard to hear across the table

This is an elegant restaurant in St Marx area, excellent for soup dumplings and a variety of tea. Tea has a huge section in their menu and very popular with visitors. They serve the mixed soup dumpling basket that has veggie, pork, chicken, crab, spicy , total of 7 different kind and colors of dumplings. All of them are super good.

We tried the dim sum sampler which also had some good pieces. I wasn't fond of the fried duck, it was too dry for me. Having some sort of dipping sauce would have helped. I also wasn't expecting egg yolk lobster to be the way it came out. I didn't find any taste in the lobster being baked with egg yolk.

The staff at the restaurant are very sincere, they follow up constantly. Food is prepared within a quick time.

Wow Wow Wow! The crab tofu was a hit! I've been meaning to try this spot, but decided to just order it via delivery and I was not dissapointed. The crab tofu had a generous amount of crab, and tasted absolutely wonderful as a compliment to the tofu. I highly recommend that you order this! The spicy soup dumplings were good too! I will be coming back to dine in!

Was recommended Uluh by someone I trust. She came here twice during a single NYC trip. That's high praise! And my experience did not disappoint. I can see how some might find it a bit overpriced if they come here for a more dim sum-heavy experience but for the quality and ambiance (i.e. clean and upscale for Chinese), I think the price point was reasonable.
