I can see why my friend came for a repeat experience.

The Crab Tofu seems to be a popular item here and it was definitely flavorful. If I lived in the neighborhood, I could see myself ordering just this one item alone and spreading it out across a couple meals with some rice.

The cabbage was great too. Very garlicky flavor and the perfect amount of spice.

The pumpkin puff is certainly cute. But at $4.50 each, it's definitely overpriced. It was good though! But I wouldn't order this one again.

I visited on a Sunday evening with 2 friends, and we were seated within 10 mins of arriving at the restaurant. When first walking in, I was struck by the ambiance of the restaurant, which was slightly dark but very, very pretty. The aesthetics of everything were truly on point, from the decor to the food and even the menu.

All of us were super hungry so we ordered a good amount to share. I was a bit skeptical of how well they were execute each dish due to the range of regions the menu covered (e.g. Shanghai, Sichuan, HK, Singapore), but everything turned out to be delicious.

Crab Tofu (10/5): MUST GET. I rarely order crab tofu at restaurants, but the tofu at Uluh is on a whole other level. This was so umami and savory, yet light - I could eat this every day with rice.

Boneless Pork Trotters (4.5/5): I love pork trotters, and these were good. Spicy and tender!

Fish in Green Peppercorn (4/5): I was expecting this to be a spicy dish with a clear broth, but this was more similar to Sichuan boiled fish.

Vegetarian Dry Pot (4.5/5): Really liked this dish due to the variety of veggies that were included (e.g. wood ear mushrooms, lotus root, bamboo shoots). We opted for mild spice, but it was still quite spicy.

Mini Pumpkin Puff (4/5): Recommend this dim sum item. Each order comes with two, and they were the perfect palate cleanser after all the spicy food. The glutinous pumpkin wrapper was nice and chewy, and the salted egg yolk filling wasn't too salty or sweet, making for for the perfect balance. Be careful when eating the puffs as the filling can be quite hot!!

Service was fast and the staff were super attentive. It was funny that the waiter questioned if we would be able to handle the spice for the Fish in Green Peppercorn, but then watched as we demolished everything. I will say that the flavor of the dishes started blending together toward the end of the meal, but that was probably due to us deciding to order all spicy dishes :')  Highly recommend coming with a big group so that you're able to try more items.

Ambiance: 5/5
Service: 4/5
Food: 4.5/5

Nice setting inside. Very clam ambiance.

Variety of tea you can try and it shows what country it's from. Highly recommend Dimsum platter and soup dumpling platter. You get to try most of the flavors.

Service is great. Staff is very friendly.

My friends and I came here for lunch (no wait) because it's hands down my friends favorite restaurant. It lived up to the hype!

We did family style and ordered Dan Dan Noodles, Sauteed Pea Shoot w. Garlic, Shanghai Pork Soup Dumplings, Sichuan Chili Fried Chicken w. Pineapples and Brown Sugar Glazed Peking Duck. Honestly, everything was amazing and done so well. I particularly loved the sichuan chili fried chicken. There are so many peppers, but the flavor was delicious so I kept eating them. Service was good and the food came pretty fast. Overall, definitely a 10/10!

Came here for lunch with a large group and had a fabulous meal where we were able to order a ton of different things. The food is excellent, and there's a lot of variety, but service is a bit lacking. Everyone was nice and polite, but we just kept having to ask for things, whereas these things were automatically provided at Chili (a similarly expensive, upscale Chinese restaurant).

In terms of food, the pork trotters, pumpkin puffs, beef scallion pancakes, Chinese broccoli were my favorite - truly very well done and/or quite unique (the puffs and trotters). The duck was solid as well. The soup dumplings were quite good, but just relative to the other amazing food, they were much less memorable and I wouldn't get them again. The mini pan fried buns were fine. Lastly, got the birds nest for dessert, and that was excellent as well. Overall, the food was outstanding, and I'd bring anyone who likes authentic high quality Chinese food here.

Everything was delicious and flavorful to the point. The drinks selection was also very interesting and presentation was very well thought for everything here. The ambiance and seating was comfortable. If you are looking for some very tasty Chinese food in a comfortable and nice restaurant this is the one.

My mom and I really love this place!! This time, I took her here for mother's day lunch on Sunday. We got there a couple minutes before they opened and there were already two parties in front of us. This time, we ordered the rose goldfish tea, crab tofu, boneless pork trotters, sauteed string beans with eggplant, and mango juice sago pomelo w mochi.

Rose goldfish tea: light flavor, would probably steep for longer for a stronger taste

Crab tofu: amazing savory/umami flavor and salted egg flavor, soft and tender texture  

Boneless pork trotters: every bite was full of flavor, a bit numbing, super tender and melt in your mouth, one of their best dishes we've had

Sauteed string beans with eggplant: really delicious and amazing wok flavor, fragrant

Mango juice sago pomelo w mochi: can't go wrong with this... perfect balance of sweet mango, grapefruit, mochi, sago and super cute!!!

Uluh is definitely on the fancier/pricier side, but it's a great place for a special treat. It's hard to go wrong with their menu. Like some of the reviews say, it is a bit hard to wave down the servers sometimes, but they are nice and accommodating once you do.

I visited Uluh during my NYC trip and it was an amazing meal! For drinks, I highly recommend trying their Rose Oolong Tea with Whipped Cheese Foam - the foam was incredibly creamy and the oolong taste was strong but not overpowering.

The Mini Pumpkin Puff was a unique twist on traditional dim sum. The skin was chewy and had a light pumpkin taste, and I loved the salted egg filling.

I also got the Brown Sugar Glazed Peking Duck, and it did not disappoint. The skin was crispy, and the meat was tender. The sauce was great, and the refreshing veggies were a perfect complement. I especially loved the texture of the whole wrap - it was just the right amount of chewy.

Lastly, I tried the Crab Tofu, which was probably my favorite dish of the meal. The crab flavor was strong, and I loved the combination of crab and tofu. The tofu was buttery smooth and melted in my mouth.

Overall, my experience at Uluh was great, and I would definitely come back to try their other dishes!

I can't believe I've been sleeping on this place.

The vegetarian fry pot mala Xiang Guo is one of the best we have ever had, and this is coming from 4 Singaporeans who eat a lot of mala in Singapore.

You MUST TRY the pork trotter with chili.

Food: 5/5 - SUPER amazing sichuan food, I've visited uluh twice and everything (except the dessert) have been great
Atmosphere: Really good lighting for the food despite the dimly lit atmosphere, perfect for date night.  

If there's a dish that can be improved on it will be the pickled cabbage fish - I didn't think the broth was very flavorful compared to SMH's but it was still nice.

Prices are a bit steep and service could have been better but the food here is great and the ambiance is nice.
Amplle seating and nice plating with a modern take on sichuan. Cocktails are also great and highly recommend the lobster which is coated in a mala numbing spice.
Would go back to try some of the other famous dishes including the crab which is more on the creamy side supposedly.

Went here on a Sunday night around 6:30 PM and waited around 30 minutes for a table for two. Only got to try two things, but the food was solid. We got the crab tofu and the pig trotters, which are two of their most popular items. I really liked the crab tofu - the sauce was savory and slightly sweet, and the tofu was really soft. The pig trotters had good flavor but the meat was almost all fat. I wish it had more lean meat in it, but maybe that's just personal preference.

One thing I was pretty disappointed in was the service. After we were seated, we waited more than 5 minutes without a waiter acknowledging us or bringing us water, and ultimately had to flag one down to order and ask for water. One of the dishes also came out way faster than the other, and we also had to flag another waiter down to bring out the check. Not sure if it was just an off night, and I usually don't care too much about service, but it was pretty disappointing, especially considering this is one of the more upscale and expensive Chinese restaurants in the city.

Overall decent food but not the greatest experience.

This is the only restaurant I revisited out of my busy binge-eating schedule trying to make a dent in my 100+ NYC bookmarks in the last few weeks. Uluh is currently my favorite (semi-elevated) Chinese restaurant in New York.

That said, the menu is massive and the english menu descriptions can be off. There are definitely hits and misses if you just order like shooting darts in the dark. Below is a list of items I recommend after trying ~80% of the menu (so you won't have to).

High recs:
- Crab tofu, best version I've had in North America, must get
- Salty egg yolk pumpkin pudding, another must get if you're obsessed with anything salted egg yolk like I am
- Stir fried cabbage with soy sauce
- Black sesame soup dumplings
- Pumpkin puffs, basically a salted eggyolk lava bun from dimsum restaurants but with fried mochi exterior, delicious if you aren't sick of salted eggyolk yet. Be careful eating this because I've seen the inexperienced biting savageishly into it only to have the salted eggyolk custard squirt out in all directions
- Osmanthus oolong cocktail, one of the best drinks I've had, tastes like sweet Chinese fermented rice wine with a hint of matcha and floral osmanthus, just don't expect to get drunk off this unless you're a literal baby

Other dishes:
- Brown sugar glazed peking duck, good, just not the best I've had, order if you have more room and/or if you're just obsessed with peking duck
- I'd skip all the savory soup dumplings, no particular standouts compared to those from the many other restaurants that serve them, recommend optimizing for more unique dishes from Uluh's menu
- Sticky rice cubes with duck, skip

Nice dimly lit ambiance, just a bit hectic with the popularity, the menu and portions are best suited for 2-4 people.

Came back a second time and still 4 stars. The duck was very good, as was the spicy cabbage and the cucumber salad. The steamed sea bass was actually a little fried and had tofu and wood ear mushroom. It was interesting and not bad but not sure I would get it again.

Moody, dimly lit restaurant with the kindest servers. Cozy and intimate -- recommend for groups so that you can try lots of dishes.

They pride themselves in their drinks , esp the cheese foam with peach or oolong green tea. This is a MUST bc it helps with the Szechuan numbing spice. Truly helps cleanse the palate.

+ rainbow dumplings - pretty, but pass! just get the regular dumplings to share
+ mapo tofu - so creamy and comforting. Not too salty but a rich, umami flavor.
+ fried szechuan chili chicken - their version of popcorn chicken , wish there was more chicken bc the ratio of peppers to chicken is off! Loved the spicy kick and the crunch.
+ fish in chili oil - you really must LOVE chili oil to like this dish bc the fish is DRENCHED in the oil. The fish is tender and so delicious with the cabbage, but quite spicy!
+ vegetarian dry pot - a personal fav with all the veggies like the lotus root, cilantro, mushroom, and glass noodles.
+ beef roll - a great appetizer if you love beef rolls!

Love the ambience, food, and drinks!!

They're aesthetically pleasing and delicious

Here's what we got:
Rose goldfish 4/5: tea flavors not strong enough but still good

Osmanthus oolong cocktail 5/5: def shareable between 2 people and very delicious, couldn't even tell that there was alcohol in it being 15% ABV

Tipsy Peach 5/5: lit taste like peach soda

Wontons in chili oil 4.5/5: the sauce made it soooo good but wonton were so tiny and not meaty

Truffle soup dumplings 3.5/5: a little disappointing, soup base was not hot (just warm) and didn't really taste the truffles

Mini pumpkin puff 5/5: highly reco!!! It's basically a drippy custard bun in a clementine form. Super cute

Would come back for another hi tea sess!

Came here for Saturday brunch with decent expectations and definitely wasn't blown away by the food tried. I did just get small bites so maybe their entrees are better?

First off, the spacing between tables is awful. It's sooo cramped and half your body is going to be touching the next table, especially as you try to exit after the meal. I'm more intimate with the strangers dining on both sides of me than with my partner sitting in front of me! Came upon opening, and while the space is pretty big, they sat us table after table in the first section while the bigger dining hall was completely empty. Wish they would've sat people more spread apart as it wasn't even crowded when we first came in, and when we left later.

Mini Pumpkin Puff: our favorite of the meal! They look more like tangerines to me hehe. But so cute! They're filled with super hot, oozing salted egg yolk that was sooo good. The outside is crazy crispy so it's a little hard to bite into the center, but once you're there, it's like a flavorful flood going into your mouth. Yummm. There should definitely be more than just two per order -.-

Dandan Noodles: another highlight! The meat sauce was spicy and flavorful (though lacking much meat, as usual) and the noodles were very good. Super small portion so not good for sharing

Black Truffle Soup Dumplings: barely a hint of truffle, does have some juice, but pretty average. Some of the soup dumplings had already popped when served. If you want truffle soup dumplings, these ain't it

Pan Fried Mini Pork Baos: not a lot of places have this so we were pretty excited to try. It's definitely super mini! I knew the skin to meat ratio would be off, but I wasn't going to care that much. The filling is pretty average, the skin is definitely thick, and while there was a little juice inside the buns, unfortunately all the buns stuck to the plate and ripped. Sooo when we picked it up to eat, the baos had no bottom skin, and no juice. Wahhh

I loved everything about Uluh from the decor down to the food. It's walk-in only but we were able to come in with no wait on a Saturday.

The service was really quick and our waitress recommended the beef and rice pasta dish which came in a hot stone bowl and was the perfect amount of spice. I especially loved the Peking duck -- the duck was tender and the skin was crispy.

Someone at the table next to us had the pumpkin puffs and they were so cute I couldn't resist ordering them. The outside was similar to a sesame ball at dim sum and the inside had a sweet and salty filling.

I'd definitely come back here for the amazing assortment of food and the quick service.

Edit: if you write a review and show them, you get a free sweet potato dessert. Not complaining since it was free, but the sweet potato bites were frostbitten, and the topping tasted like gogurt (tubed yogurt). It was not at all enjoyable but you live and learn I guess.

Not us ordering more desserts than the actual meal cause they all looks so eyes catching & yummy !!Beside their infamous Brown Sugar Glazed Peking Duck, definitely recommend trying the

- Bouncy sweet potato vermicelli w beef slices
- Rose lychee Panna Cotta ( the icy filling in it adds a nice refreshing layers to the dessert)
- Osmanthus oolong cocktail to wash down the spiciness! Bonus point of the use of cocktail jar design, great for insulating the cocktail!

The minus star is not due to the foods but the 30 mins+ wait time even though we already reserved ahead. Will be back to try more dishes!

Great food, fast service, and a cool interior.
The standouts of our meal were the crab tofu, pork trotters, and the rose lychee panna cotta. The pork trotters in particular were melt-in-your-mouth tender, and had some amazing richness.
The only thing I wouldn't get again here was the dim sum platter - the veggie dumplings were not good and everything else on it was basic.
Prices are a little high, but Uluh definitely delivers. The dishes all have amazing, authentic flavors, and the overall experience was super satisfying.

Yep.

Everything was top notch. The crispy potato latkas, the pierogis, the borscht. I'm sad I just haven't had the time to come back. You'll see me soon.

I am Eastern European heritage so the food served here is totally something I love.  As kid yessss I am old I use to go to this hood a lot for the food and Ukrainian experience.  

The Kompo, Kompot, Schnitzel, ice coffee, brown bread, salmon etc food was all delicious hearty, the real deal trust me.

Hugely satisfying return after many year's absence. Enjoyed nostalgic dinner of tender, juicy, breaded pork chops; potato pancake and boiled carrots. Complimentary brown bread and butter was so good with the Spanish rosé wine. Warm, homey room; friendly, unobtrusive service. Ridiculously low prices for such a great meal!

Excellent Ukrainian home cooking. I started with Horseradish vodka.   It was hot but tasty and encouraged sipping. I had cold Bortshe  which was terrific. I had the combo which had sausage sauerkraut stuffed cabbage and perigees . A cold night in Manhattan. I felt warm and revived fir the trek home.
The decor was pleasant in keeping with the culture. Service is slow so lose your edginess and go  for the ride. A local diner came over and coached us on what to order abdominal what to expect. It was very charming.

At times it feels like Manhattan requires all new restaurants to be either 1) fusion 2) a farm to table wine bar or 3) Chipotle, so it was great to revisit this classic spot.

The Ukrainian combo was outstanding. Thankfully I went with a work friend from back in the day, so we talked about mysterious promotions and strategies for passing LinkedIn's SEO skills test, preventing me from eating the whole thing in five minutes. The kielbasa was predictably excellent but the stuffed cabbage was probably my favorite component. The combo also includes excellent pierogi and sauerkraut.

If you want to extend your celebration of non-Duane Reade NYC, stop by the adjacent Sly Fox for a shot of horseradish vodka.

A cute restaurant with diner vibes! You can tell it's good because many Ukrainians come here

Food: they have a very expansive menu! I went with the chicken schnitzel which was really good! It comes with two sides, so I got the fries and kasha. I liked the l kasha but did not like the fries, bc they felt old and soggy

Service: good service

Ambience: major diner vibes that attracts people from all ages

Price: reasonably priced

I had an appointment in the East Village and on my way back home in the  rain, I spotted this place so decided to try my luck. The space is very unique and spacious.. the restaurant is located underground... I ordered the traditional Ukrainian combo plate...  sadly it was less than mediocre... they threw some Farfelle pasta on top of it... it was pretty tasteless I am sad to say.. I don't think I will try again

Slava Ukraini! I've eaten at Veselka a dozen times or more, so wanted to mix it up. This place feels even more humble, but has some great home cooking style comfort food. And at a very reasonable price!

Stuffed Cabbage: Not too cabbage-y, just a few thin soft layers. And the filling is a delicious soft mince of meat and spices. Love the tomato sauce on top, to give it extra flavor. So much comfort.

Mixed Pierogis (Cheese, Cabbage, Spinach, Meat): Was disappointed that a potato pierogi didn't come in the sampler platter, but the others were so delicious. Especially liked the semi-sweet and squeaky cheese pierogi, which reminded me of fresh crumbled paneer. Cabbage is a classic as is the meat one. Spinach pierogi was just alright, maybe the weakest link and could have been replaced by potato.

Kovbasa + Sauerkraut: A very snappy kovbasa, like I had to try a few times to stab it with my pork. Very rich and smoky and fatty, way better then the grocery store stuff. The sauerkraut was essential to contrast the richness.

Letcho + Potato Pancakes: I just wanted an excuse to get potato pancakes so ordered this. And I was not disappointed since they were fluffy on the inside and crispy in the outside. Tasted more like mashed/minced potatoes than shredded, which I really liked. The stew was very nice too with super tender beef and a nice sauce and some veggies. Though the meat portion felt a little skimpy compared to the amount of potato pancakes.

Apple Strudel: Shockingly we had room for dessert! Good thing because the warm apples wrapped in a thin buttery dough was the perfect way to conclude a meal.

Homemade Compote: Refreshing cherry drink with lots of stewed cherries to scoop out, which is more fun than bubble tea. Kinda sweet, which is perfect for me.

Ukranian East Village Restaurant is located inside an office building and serves delicious Ukrainian comfort food.  My food highlights were the borscht (as good as I've had), the kovbasa, and the pierogi. Our server was personable and very helpful. There's a large back room that hosts events. On the Wednesday evening we were there, a lively dance party erupted at 8:pm. It didn't disturb us as there is a door that can be closed to block out most of the noise. Veselka next door may be more popular, but, based specifically on Ukranian food, this place is at least as good. Highly recommended.

My friends and I dined here before seeing an amazing show at Theater for the New City nearby. The line for Veselka was too long of a wait so we came here instead - its only a few doors down. We were pleasantly surprised with the authenticity and dining hall experience. The borsch was delicious. I also loved the pierogis.

Fantastic Ukrainian spot in the East Village and, personally, a preferred option over Veselka (which is right next door). There's a whole bunch of classic Ukrainian dishes, with some other Eastern European dishes sprinkled in the menu. Came here for the first time today with a friend and ordered the:

- Pelmeni (5/5): I absolutely love pelmeni - these little meat-filled dumplings are so simple yet delicious. You can dip them in the side of sour cream or eat them plain.
- Potato pancakes (5/5): Crispy. Crispy. Crispy. Slather (or dip) the apple sauce on top and *chef's kiss*. It might be a strange combo if you've never had it before, but the sweetness of the apple sauce complements the savoriness of the pancakes - must try!
- Combo plate (5/5): This is a great option to sample some classics - vareniky (mixed - ours came with spinach, potato, sauerkraut with mushroom), kovbaca (sausage), kasha (buckwheat - or you can choose sauerkraut), and holubtsi (stuffed cabbage with a mushroom gravy). The only thing is that I wish they added the potato vareniky and made their holubtsi with a tomato-based sauce.
- Borscht (5/5): Refreshing, light, flavorful, not too salty. Great to have as a side or starter!

Perfect place to pop in for a quick, hearty, filling meal that doesn't break the bank. Highly recommend!
It's a nice restaurant with really reasonable price. The food is decent, feeling very traditional.

Ukrainian Restaurant has been a hidden staple of the East Village for decades. It's well tucked into the Ukrainian National Home building next Sly Fox. You don't come here for trendy aesthetics or the best service, you come here for the comfort foods of Eastern Europe. I've patronized this spot over the years and it's one of the few places that still feels like old (90s/00s) New York.

The last time I ventured here, I shared a bowl of pelmeni and ordered the porkchops with a mushroom gravy, potato pancake, and sauerkraut. The porkchop was tender and the potato pancake was massive. The pelmeni appetizer were small addictive little dumplings that could easily become a meal on its own if you ordered a second or third round.

After a long day of shopping in Soho, a homely meal was just what the doctor ordered. Service was a bit slow but friendly. The food was all yummy and comforting. We got the goulash, meat perogies, veal dumplings, and krokety. The krokety was my favorite.

Ukrainian East Village Restaurant is certainly one spot we've been wanting to try for a long time! It's nestled in a building that's right next to the popular East Village joint Veselka. We arrived there to find ourselves waiting in a long-ish line. But it was understandable because 1) it was a Saturday, 2) dinner time, 3) Ukraine's not exactly escaped the headlines of lately.

I must say once we got in, I liked the decor. It feels homely, and very family-style. Kind of like the understated sibling of Veselka. And, I am sure there are many who come to dine here more often than next-door because it feels more authentic. The prices are better, for sure.

We ordered typically authentic Ukrainian dishes, starting with the Ukrainian Borscht. I may be uncultured insofar as I can't tell the difference between this version and the Russian one. I did like it, however, making me wonder why I am not a fan of radishes in the first place.

Our main dish was the Ukrainian combo, which we meant to share. When it did arrive, it felt like a dish for 1-1.5 persons, rather than for 2. But it wasn't all that expensive. So, do take all that into consideration if you are hungry!

The main dish underwhelmed. It felt bland, and nothing really stood out to us. I suppose I liked the stuffed cabbages with beef. The pierogis with meat were good as well, but the rest was fine, without being exciting. I can't blame it much on the restaurant itself for Ukrainian cuisine might not be my favorite. Rozena thought the same as well.

Certainly did not regret our meal here. So, we might return, but we will probably order something else.

Coming through a tunnel entrance, this restaurant was a sight for sore eyes. I wanted to stuff my face with pierogis, soups and potato goodness. Wish granted on this Friday. I also wanted to make my dearest Ukrainian friend feel like home as we both had long crazed weeks. Beer, potato blintzes and sour cream spreads will do it. Loved how homely and wide this restaurant is. The staff are so warm and hospitable to our needs, like how when you come visit home and your parents want to welcome you with a home cooked meal. I enjoyed everything we ate in this place. Even the beef kielbasa hit the spot to add as our protein dish.  My favorite of all was the Ukrainian beer, so light and frothy with a gentle buzz. My friend taught me the right way to toast Ukrainian style and it was a good shift from the usual Salud cheers. Comfort food well done. Will come back like the batch of birthday parties we saw come in the restaurant center having the time of their lives.
Posting more photos of my recent date here.  I love the pierogis and also the borscht soup!

Great alternative to Veselka in terms of pierogis, but the meat stew we got was a little tough. It is also tucked away and private, so it's nice to have some quiet within the east village. Also incredibly strong drinks!

Wow! I've never been treated as such a peace of garbage in my life. Took my mom for lunch there today and was waiting to be seated for 30 minutes, we were the only ones waiting and the restaurant was less than half full.
A lady with short red hair passed by us at least 10 times and refused to acknowledge us so my mom had to seat because she couldn't stand anymore. We couldn't leave because it was pouring rain outside.
She finally screamed at us to seat and when I started ordering and asked her one question she screamed at me again, so I lost my appetite and didn't order for me, just for my mom. My mom doesn't speak English so she couldn't say anything. Was this discrimination????
Then she gets mad and says in Ukrainian "stupid girl" (I understood) and left. She literally threw the plates on my mom's face like we were begging for food.
After I needed to pay and she was ignoring me again. When I was finally able to get her attention by asking the other waitress she threw the bill at me and said "here sign there" and left.
I felt like crying... never ever ever wish somebody treats her that way. I hope she finds peace on whatever she was going though.

I used to go to this restaurant when I was in college, in the 70's. I lived nearby. It was wonderful. Decades later, I decided to order from them tonight. I ordered their goulash and potato pancakes. The meat was tender. The sauce was thick and a pleasing color but.... it was so salty that I was unable to eat the dish. The potato pancakes were soggy, strange tasting and mushy. The apple strudel was passable -- but not woth ordering ever again.
Sorry to give this once terrific restaurant a failing score.

I was at this place with two others after not going originally to B+H Dairy and then seeing the massive line at the more well block away Veselka, we decided to stop here. The food here was tasty and the service was pleasant. I got a glass of Kompot to drink and it was lighter than most places which I don't really mind as some places are a bit overly sweet. I believe it was a mix of cherry, apple, and cranberry but I am unsure. Another person with me got the borscht as an appetizer and I tried a bit of it and it was tasty.
For my main dish, I went with the Ukrainian goulash which comes of two sides. As it was just going to be the stew, my sides were egg noodles as well as sauerkraut. The goulash had tender beef and it was tasty though the noodles were a bit overcooked being slightly mushy but I am someone who likes their egg noodles to be someone underdone/a little bit hard. Another person had the Varenyky/pierogi and I tried a part of one of them and it was also tasty. I don't remember the main dish the last person had.
The flavors here were light and tasty and there was a nice communal atmosphere. It's not the best food you'll ever have but the prices are reasonable and the portion sizes were nice. Mid/upper 3
I went here on a chilly early evening for a quick bowl of borscht. I'd do back again but for their pierogis!

This is a no frills restaurant yet it does have some Ukrainian decor here, which is a nice touch. The food was basic yet very tasty & I would go back, but I would recommend not going if you happen to be in a rush. The night I went there was one waitress for everyone who was working alone on a Monday night so she also brought out all the food, sat everyone, made all the payments & cleaned all the tables too & they were a little busy.

First time visiting an Ukrainian restaurant. Pierogis are similar to what I usually have at Polish places, and I think my favorite flavor was potato! Potato pancakes were also yummy (always a yes to carbs!) Very home-y environment. Would love to visit again!

So charming!  It's in the back of old-school office building type thing, with bright  sunflowers and yellow and blue flags guiding the way down the hallway.  The food was very hearty and well seasoned - come hungry!  We got the pierogies, pelmeni, borscht, compote, blini, and goulash. All the food feels real, like it came from a grandma's kitchen. I've never had blini fresh fried off the griddle before, and it was so addictive.  It's definitely a slow meal - service is not in a hurry and you shouldn't be either.
Accessibility warning: the bathrooms are down some stairs.

I lived in NYC over 40 years ago. As a poor young student I relied on the Ukrainian East Village restaurant as a reasonably priced, delicious restaurant. I lived on hearty soups with black bread and blueberry blintzes for dessert. In fact, I stopped eating blintzes because none of them were as good as here.
My husband and I ate here this week and it was exactly as remembered. He had beef stroganoff and I had Hungarian goulash and both were excellent. The potato pancakes were the best I ever had. And of course I had the blueberry blintzes. Heaven!

Again, amazing place to get Ukrainian and Russian food.

1) I got the beef stroganoff with egg noodles. 10/10, must get.
2) Try the potato varenyky, it is the best version.
3)  If you try the blintze, get with cheese and order sour cream.

Came in here excited to try some Ukrainian food and left 15 minutes later disappointed in the service. I walked in and waited for 15 min as servers and workers walked past me without even acknowledging my presence. Not even a "hello." Absolutely rude and disrespectful. There were 2 other parties seated and it was evident that the older waitress cared more about collecting their money rather than seating me. I was waiting on my partner to meet me there at which point I just called him and told him to meet me at a different restaurant. HORRIBLE customer service and upon reading reviews here, apparently their food is horrible too and makes people sick. Glad I didn't spend my money here and won't be returning.
Fantastic!! Loved everything we got, especially the pelmeni. Also got the Halusky which was amazing.

this place is an old school institution. i remember coming here when i was little for their cheese and potato pierogi/varenyky, as well as their potato pancakes. not much has changed except for the prices. ambiance is old school and service is rather brusque, although i never experienced any outright rudeness. imo their pierogi/varenyky are on par with veselka and they're a good option if you don't want to brave veselka's lines.

Came here for a late night dinner since it was open late! Started with the tripe soup-- which I never knew was a part of Ukrainian cuisine! It was very hearty and absolutely worth it! Pelmeni were tasty but we should have probably added in sour cream. Compote was delicious!! Way better than usually is at almost all Russian restaurants I've been to. And the lamb chops-- absolutely wow!!!! Delectable and just amazing. Can't wait to come back!!!
Seated quickly but service was slow. Understandable though since it was dinner rush and all the servers were running around. Pierogis were all delicious and the potato pancakes were crispy.

pierogis were so good!! recommend the sauerkraut and mushroom ones theyre surprisingly really good & also ask for applesauce on the side for the latkas it makes the experience much better :) fav part was def the pierogis tho they remind me of dumplings fr. just a little heftier than a dump. a hefty dump . i will say tho that the waitresses were like nonexistent like dont get me wrong i like that they are no bs and they just take our order and put our food down and leave,, but there was a huge line out the door and there were multiple tables that were long done eating and had a lot of trouble grtting their check / getting it paid so we were literally stuck in this restaurant for 2 hours and spent the last 45 min trying to get a hold of someone to give us a check lol. anyways be sure to bring good company because u may be here for a while !

Nataliya's review is spot on. The borscht tasted like pickled beets and vinegar.. and the sour cream costs extra. The varenyiki were just ok - dough a little too thick, and the cheese used tvorog that was way too sweet. The potato ones needed some more flavor for sure.

We scarfed it all down after walking all day, but the dishes really need work and love! I hate to tell my visiting Slav parents that the best place is Streecha, which was closed.

The beer from Lviv was the best though!

Was on a date and decided to stop here to grab a meal. Hostess was rude. Waiting time was abysmal for how mediocre the food was. If you like ugly decor maybe you'll find something enjoyable here. Other than that, go to a real restaurant.
Wonderfully authentic! Comfort food at its finest. It's not glamorous or exciting, but decent

This place is my go-to when Veselka is too packed, and I've never had any problem with the food. There's even a Soviet-looking dining hall one can peer at while waiting for one's food. I will say though the last time I went here, I was with my girlfriend, and though the service was excellent, the only other table was a big one full of older mostly white male NYU professors. Some of them kept looking at her rudely cuz they were hetero and privileged with no LGBTQ friends to speak of.
Delicious comfort food! Never crowded like a neighboring Ukrainian restaurant, which is also very good.

This was  a horror beyond all imagination.

I went here with my son on a late Saturday afternoon. I had some vague recollection of a good meal I had here several decades ago. I had never been back.

We were walking through the East Village and I saw the nearby "Veselka" was packed to the rafters. All indoor and outdoor tables were full and there was a line.

So I told my son "I know another good Ukrainian place near here", and we walked into UEVR.

When you go into a restaurant in a busy area and the restaurant is COMPLETELY DESERTED it should have set off red flags. We got there and this HUGE restaurant was TOTALLY EMPTY. NOT A SOUL IN IT.

You had to go through a corridor and doorway to get to the UEVR, and I peered through the glass window. I was sure it must have been closed. But then I tried the door and one of the waitresses yelled "Come in, come in!!".

I hesitated. Why was there not a single person in there, especially since Veselka, another Slavic restaurant, was standing room only?

Foolishly (in hindsight), we went in and sat down. The waitress was friendly, brought us cold water and a menu.

This was the apogee of our meal.

I won't go into a lot of detail. I'll just briefly mention what we had, since I will NEVER SET FOOT IN THERE AGAIN.

My son ordered the red borscht, jellied pork and the kielbasa. He ordered a compote.

I ordered the red borscht and the Weiner Schnitzel. And a bottle of beer.

Let me preface this part of my review to state that I have eaten all over the world, in street stalls to expensive hotels, and I RARELY GET SICK.

I'll be brief. I won't describe the food in too much detail, since I will never go back, and if you value your life and your palate, you won't either.

1) Red borscht. Very ordinary, tasted insipid, watery, like it was made a long time ago. It came with sour cream. I ate it and was unimpressed.

2) My son got the jellied pork. Usually, I love this stuff, including the Jewish version made with cow trotters, called P'tcha. We were served the pork version. It was horrible, melting jelly, off-colored old dill, and tiny flecks of pork. Disgusting.

3) After a long wait, my Weiner Schnitzel arrived. It had an odd odor. The greasy breading immediately fell off, in oily chunks, with no adhesion to the "veal". It definitely smelled slightly spoiled. I don't know what compelled me to eat it, but I did, with the dry mashed potatoes (no gravy, no butter), and the lousy sauerkraut.

4) My son reported the kielbasa, which should be great in a Ukrainian restaurant, did not taste good. I tried it and confirmed it. It was not hot, and it has some strange taste I could not identify,

Neither of us liked the food. I was starving, so I ate most of mine. He did not eat most of his. I told him "don't waste food", but he refused to finish it.

After a bill of close to $70 for a terrible lunch, we started walking outside.

My son said to me: "Do you feel sick?"

Yes, I did feel bad. I felt sick and dizzy. We both did.

I was planning to walk home to my downtown apartment, but I started to feel so queasy I wasted money on an Uber. On arrival home, I went straight to the toilet.

I spent much of the next 24 hours in the toilet. I had ghastly smelling diarrhea.

So much for nostalgia and my memories of tasty East Village food from decades ago.

This place is disgusting, unclean and a rip-off. I'm sorry to write this. The waitresses were nice, but I feel obligated to warn people off.

IF A RESTAURANT IN A BUSY AREA IS EMPTY, THERE IS A REASON.

Next time I'll heed my own sixth sense. I can't imagine what kind of morons or brain dead are posting positive reviews about this place.

Bleecchhhhhhhh!!!

What a hidden gem in the village.
Delicious fresh food, wonderful warm decor,
Friendly service and affordable pricing

Def a must try if you like authentic Ukrainian food

Made a visit to this cozy old school joint and ordered the combo with the assorted pierogis, potato pancake and cheese blintz. Everything was delicious with the generous amount of applesauce and sour cream provided. Solid, no-nonsense service. Good value. Easy to see how it has survived for so many years.

This place is genuinely my roommate and I's happy place. We try to come every Sunday but often plans fall through so when we do make it, it's amazing. It has such a warm inviting environment and is always decorated to the nines. We especially love when this amazing Ukrainian choir comes in to eat and sing their way through their meal. It is the most beautiful singing I have ever experienced and I hope to hear it every Sunday. The food is also amazing, just soul food to the max. Anything on the menu will wow and the service is exceptional. You can feel the closeness of the staff and the work that goes into running this restaurant. I will recommend this place till the day I die.

While craving a Ukrainian meal for Sunday brunch, but not being able to wait in Veselka's 40 minute line because I was in a hurry to go watch the Jacksonville Jaguars lose, Ukrainian East Village was an exciting easy find since it is located right around the corner.

Pros: Two different types of Ukrainian bottled beer, long menu full of authentic dishes, quick service, fairly low prices.

Cons: All of the food is a barely edible, lazy version of traditional Ukrainian/Russian dishes that did not satisfy my cravings. The borsch tastes like vinegar and boiled beets with pickled beans, and it does not come with meat or sour cream (although I got a side of sour cream once I asked for it). The jellied pork had a distinct taste of meat that was past its prime. The Ukrainian combo platter was also left most untouched - flavorless cabbage rolls (stuffed with mostly overcooked rice), soggy pirogis, sauerkraut, and polish sausage.

Truth be told, I still cringe a little every time I look back on this meal. This is a hard pass for all my future food endeavors.

One of my "go to" restaurants in New York City for lunch when I am here visiting.  It's old world.  Very comfortable.  Great for conversation.  On the quiet side.  Tables spaced well apart.  The food is simple Ukrainian food.  Similar to Polish food.  Prices are reasonable.  It's just a great place.
Great prices, truly authentic food, plus it's good tasting too. Highly recommend a visit!
I was disappointed that the Ukrainian East Village Restaurant could not handle a recent takeout order. The dining room wasn't so crowded that they couldn't accommodate a takeout order.

prices  have  more than doubled  over just a  few  years  ago.  however  a much better  bigger  and  fresher  meal  than  the Vecelka  next  store.   They also do NOT  rush  you out  like  Vecelka  does  next  store.  I  f  you like  Soviet or  Eastern  European  food this  is  a  good place to  go,  one o f the last  ones  left  o  f the maybe 13  we had in the  East  Village  traditionally.  I  find  the portion s to be  much smaller  than before.  The bread   is  industrialized  American style  bread  and  long gone is the homemade  Challa  Bread  o  f  long ago.  I  ate there  recently  a  few  times  and  it was  satisfactory.   You will have a  shock when you see the prices  on the menu  as compared to before.  They like many other  stores  have used   the  excuse  of  inflation  to  massively  hike  their  menu  prices. However  they are  still a better deal  than the  horrible  Vecelka  next  store.    The  quality is  not as  good  as years  ago  but ok.  They used to have terrible  radio  music  on and would refuse  to turn it off  or  down though we were paying their salaries  obviously.   They have finally stopped  the horrible forced  music.  On  balance  despite  price  engorgement  and  less quality  than before  its  still to be recommended.

We ordered the pierogies and the halusky, and it was so good it literally restored my faith in humanity.  you have to walk back a little ways into the building and the restaurant itself can look a little bit interesting, but trust me, it's worth it!

I love this restaurant!! I was inspired to try it because of the current situation in Ukraine. Veselka next door often has a line around the block. I wanted to support other Ukrainian businesses as well. I had the varenyky (dumplings) and the strawberry blintz. Don't miss trying the desserts here, the blintz was excellent. Also good coffee at a reasonable price. On a return visit I got the borscht and the potato pancakes. The staff was very sweet and remembered me, even with all the terrible things happening in their country right now. Get to know this wonderful restaurant and community!

I was craving Ukrainian food and discovered this place randomly as the ones I tried previously were not good.
We ordered chef's special plate which included pirogies, sausage, buckwheat and stuffed cabbage and borsch ( beets soup ) and cheese pirogies.
Borsch was very good, good balance of veggies and broth. Pirogies were ok, nothing really special. Cheese ones were made with  kinda sweet cottage cheese which did not match with sautéed onions on top.
Overall, pleasant place with no lines

Firstly, the udon here is some of the best in the city. I used to frequent Udon West by Grand Central, and this is basically the same. I got the Nabeyaki Udon and it was exactly what I'd want. Very good and flavorful broth (and well balanced), noodles with good flavor and bite (not perfect but way way better than what I've gotten at Tsurutontan), and nicely done tempura.

It is a fairly small restaurant (not surprising for St. Mark's Place), with a few seats at the bar and something like 4 or 5 tables. We came in with 3 people at about 6:45PM on a Wednesday and immediately got a table but there was a slight line a bit after. Service was quite prompt, though, which helped quite a bit. Also note: cash only!

I'm so excited Udon St Marks is open again!!!

The fatty tuna don over rice and udon set, and the gyu don and udon set are both my favorite. I love the classic Japanese setting now that I've gotten to visit Japan and can appreciate it haha. The portions are still pretty amazing and for the price, it is well worth it!

Great options as a set and a la carte, and super speedy. I love that you can watch them prepare it sitting at the bar. There is good beer and sake options too.

I think I arrived too early after they opened and it smelled heavily of cleaning liquids but I'll still be back just later in the day :)

Great food. Great price. Great location. Just wonderful udon and bonito broth.  I'll come here every time I'm in NYC. I think the owner hangs out at the bar sometimes as well. Love the no frills we're here to eat noodles vibe. Cash only.

A good option for something quick, simple and affordable on st marks. Nothing to write home about but it does the job! I cant speak for the hot udon, but the cold udon contained so much mirin it tasted like sake, which I didn't love. They do have a minimum price per guest to be able to dine here- I think around $8 or something (totally reasonable but just an FYI if you weren't hungry enough for an entree or were just accompanying friends).

I'm glad this place is open again. Great tasting udon. I'm a fan because their soup is on the lighter side and not salty. All their menu items are on the cheaper side for nyc. I usually get the kitsune udon or Wakame udon which is a vegetable based broth. Their other udon is fish based broth. Friendly service. They have bar seating and tables in the back. They have limited seating. One bummer is they only accept cash.
I was so sad to see it closed. I'm happy they are open again. Their spicy tuna don is amazing!!!! Anywhere else I've had doesn't do it for me! I can't wait to come back!
Great portions and tasty food. Can be a bit of a wait but we'll worth it. Place is tiny and very cramped.
Open again! Great team working here and delicious food! Soup still comes out hot during summer! Love it. Also option for cold udon too. Very nice renovations!

While I don't think it'll win any awards for the best udon in the city, Udon St. Marks is still a place that I think is worth venturing to when in the East Village. Given the closure of some very popular nearby spots (#1) I am genuinely happy to see them thriving in what might be the closest thing to a Lil Japan (#1) in NY.

Like many of the establishments in the motherland, Udon St Marks is a tight fit. A narrow bar / counter stretches across the inside, where just over a dozen seats face an open kitchen of a rowdy staff cooking things up for folks. There is a few sit down tables for couples but they're in a narrow corner of the restaurant. For folks sitting on the counter, there is a chance of spillage and even the higher likelihood of coming out smelling like broth, but there are certainly worse things in life. This is the perfect solo dining meal, but also worthy of a date who is okay with close quarter eating.

The food was always inconsistent over the years, but I find they've gotten better through the pandemic. I have always been a sucker for the nabeyaki udon + tempura combo, which comes with a side a bowl of rice. The soft udon noodles make for a nice contrast to the crunch of the assorted tempura. Their chige udon is a nice play between Korean stews (chigae) and udon and contains a good flavor'y mix of beef, kimchi, egg, and spinach. I also think the karaage (fried chicken) and maru-ten (fish cake + tempura) udon are worthy of consideration.

Then there are the standout dishes that aren't udon based at all, which is where I give them the additional thumbs up. Their curry sets (croquette or cutlet) are super tasty and I am a big time sucker for their negi-tori don (fatty tuna over rice); which is so good I wish there was more of it. The gyoza and takoyaki (octopus balls) are solid, but certainly don't trump the main dishes whatsoever.

Last I checked, they were cash only. Indoor dining service has resumed so that it's not exclusively a takeout joint. Service is friendly and they don't rush folks even when there is a wait. I would avoid bringing large groups of any kind here and would recommend ordering both a rice and noodle bowl for the best of both worlds.

____________
(#1) R.I.P. Village Yochoko, Angel's Share, Ramen Setagaya
(#2) St. Marks, East Village.

Delicious, well priced, fast, and lovely service! I came here on a snowy night when all of my usual spots in the LES had 1hr+ waitlists. It's the perfect place for a cozy casual meal in East Village!

Pros:
Surprisingly wide variety of vegetarian/vegan options, affordable, great value for money, fast, great service!

Cons:
Not the most amazing meal/udon I've had in NYC. But pretty amazing for the price!

Kitsune Udon:
I was impressed by how flavorful the soup was even though it was a veggie broth, a lot of other places don't prioritize vegetable broths so they often end up lacking in flavor. But the vegetable broths were just as delicious as the fish broth- in it's sweet, savory, and light goodness. Kitsune was delicious and plentiful. Udon was cooked- soft but still bouncy and thick.

Spicy Tuna Don Set
Udon: I really did not except to get a full sized udon but it was just as big as the kitsune udon. Classic no frills udon that tasted just like the cheap udons I bought in Japan. Great value!
Spicy Tuna Don: hearty and full. The spicy tuna has a good kick but isn't melt your mouth spicy. It doesn't have a spicy tuna sauce, which I would have loved for extra creaminess, but still delicious.

Overall: great value- a perfect cheap eats that feels authentically Japanese. Our waitress was also so kind, cheerful, and attentive. Will definitely be coming back!

Best thing about this cozy nook in cranny spot- can't beat the prices for a neighborhood like St Marks. Quick meal for $10. Cash only. Service was commendable- one staff member doing it all for the 3-4 tables and bar seats. Not much seating and not much room inside. Definitely get what you expect out of a small humble udon spot.

The menu includes udon with different toppings, sets of udon paired with tempura, rice bowls, appetizers, etc. Prices are under $15 for most sets and items. Food came in large portions but the items we ordered were very mediocre.

@ tempura set (~$15) - includes a plain hot udon, assorted tempura (2 shrimp, and 4 vege in this case I remember green pepper, sweet potato/carrot?, kabocha squash), white rice, and dipping sauce. Hot udon tastes like standard packaged udon acceptable light dashi broth and soft smooth udon noodles. Tempura was terrible, anemic shrimp wrapped in thick uneven batter, veggies falling out of batter, dipping sauce is really really watered down. Rice was fine.

@ veggie spring roll set (~$15) - hot udon with 4 springs rolls, rice, and dipping sauce. Udon same as the tempura set, standard. I don't like spring rolls, especially bad ones like these. Pale color, barely crispy, questionable filling.

tl;dr cheap meal by neighborhood standards, extremely limited seating, cash only, food is sorta okay if you like packaged frozen udon, just don't get the tempura or spring rolls

The food here is my definition of comfort food. One of my top favorite restaurants that I always return to. I've been a frequent customer for this place for at least a decade now.

I'm assuming there's been a change in management because of the updated store name (used to be Udon West) and some changes in their menu. Since reopening, prices have increased (but still worth the  price!) and I noticed they don't serve fish cake with their udon anymore. Despite all that, their food tastes the same as I remember.

I usually opt for their udon sets because it's the most worth it. I usually go for the spicy tuna set, kalbi set, or takoyaki set. I love the texture of their udon and I love the simplicity of their soup.

If you're ever in the area craving for some udon, this is the spot!
i love this place so much for the value and good food. i'm overjoyed that it's back. please never leave again, nyc loves you

I have been going to this restaurant for almost 10 years.

Why go? This is one of the best places to get Gyu don in NYC for a reasonable price (less than $10). You can order Gyu Don in many places in NYC but nobody makes the simmered beef over rice dish perfectly like Udon St Marks does. You can also try the many Udon dishes they have or better yet get a COMBO dish like Udon + Gyu don or Katsu Curry + Udon.

What to note: It's cash only. On weekends it can get very busy and there is not alot of table seating. There's counter like seating and then 3 tables in the back, no more than ~15-20 people in the entire restaurant (including staff).

The food is served very quick and the service is exactly what you would expect for a no frills Japanese restaurant. Truly a Japanese experience in NYC if you miss Tokyo/Osaka fast-food like restaurants.

This spot is a cash only spot with limited indoor seating and has outdoor seating in the middle of the populated St Marks Place. Because it is cash only, the prices are spectacular. They also offer a lot of combo options which is great for those who are indecisive and cannot decide what to eat. Just get both! It is also great bang for you buck.

I got the curry and udon set which included a very generous portions of curry and rice with a bowl of savory udon. Both were very tasty. The curry is more on the watery side but that is actually perfect to mix in with the rice. The udon is a very good portion size for those who want a udon fix but also a bigger main dish. The soup for the udon is very flavorful

I'm surprised this place doesn't have a 4+ star rating!

The menu options, including the sets, are a bang for your buck. I was eyeing the curry options and croquette options but ended up getting the hamburg set which came with rice and udon. For the udon you have a choice of cold or hot udon. I tried the cold udon it was SO delicious. I expected it to be tasteless because there wasn't any protein topping on it but boy was I wrong. It was very refreshing because of the coolness of the soup. There were small veggie toppings (I think) that added to the texture. The hamburg was yummy as well. The ice berg lettuce that came with the hamburg really completed it. I think the rice might be sushi rice because it was all clumped together. I couldn't finish all the rice and hamburg, which goes to show this is worth it

The service was average, nothing bad to say. The waitress served us water in small plastic cups. I think she refilled it maybe once or twice. There were a few instances where I needed water but I couldn't find the waitress. But, it's all good.

They have a very clean bathroom. They have a few tables and then a bar table. For the bar table they have a hook underneath so customers can hang their belongings there. This is a cash only place.

Great price for great food!! The udon is super chewy and is paired with a great fish stock broth! Perfect for a cold day

Cash only!
Affordable udon sets! Very tasty and delicious. Highly recommend asking for the spicy seasoning for the udon to get a boost of flavor and spice. Cash only!

I personally felt the udon was standard tasting. The rice dish was a bit too moist. The squid tempera was too soggy. The brocolli with tempura was still crisp.

The takoyaki was really good though. I would come back for the takoyaki alone. It was ball-shaped, hot and filled with zesty octopus.

Remember to bring cash.

Great place to stop in for a hearty lunch. I used to come here a lot pre-covid for lunch, and I still enjoyed it since I visited recently. There are still a bunch of seats at the counter where you can watch the chefs make the food which is always fun. My favorite part about this udon spot are their combination sets. I am the type of person who likes side dishes and having variety with my meal. Makes me feel like I'm getting more bang for my buck.

So they have a bunch of different rice dishes that come with a bowl of hot or cold udon. My go to combo is always either spicy tuna over rice or negitoro (fatty tuna w/ scallion) over rice. The tuna dishes come with ginger, wasabi and soy sauce and you can also choose which udon comes with it (default is plain; it'll cost a few extra dollars). I usually enjoy their sansai (mountain veggies) or shrimp tempura.

Also this place is cash only!

A warm and cozy noodle house located in Lower East Side, St. Marks Place. Great place to sit in and enjoy a warm Udon noodle soup to unwind from a long day at work!

After coming here on a Thursday night with a few others and being seated promptly, I ordered a Karaage Udon. It was absolutely fantastic - the chicken was juicy, soup was savory but not too salty, and the udon noodles were splendidly boiled with softness that could not possibly go without appreciation from the tongue.

10/10 - expect a return from me again.

I always pass this place when I go to st marks but my friend actually invited me to come here so I came with her. I remember it being called udon west back in the day. I'm not a huge fan of udon but the udon here is delicious. It's CASH ONLY! No cards accepted at all. The service isn't so bad the lady with the long pony tail hair is really nice, really helpful when it came to helping me choose what to eat that day. It's a comfort food spot for sure something good to just nimble on. Prices are not too bad, I personally think it's worth it. Very limited indoor/outdoor seating. They have a good combo section for you to choose from. I didn't choose the combo but my friend did and she been here before so she never gets disappointed. Give this spot a try at least once.

Perfect lovely place for a lunch by one's self. I've had some more high end udons such as Tsurontontan, Raku, and hanon. However, I find myself returning to Udon St. Marks. While the broth is not as complex as a $20 bowl, and the noodles slightly softer and less bouncy, you simply can not beat the value of a bowl of udon here. The noodles are thick and the broth is slightly sweet and drinkable.

Truly the item I come here for is the fish cake tempura. I don't know how they make it so good. It is so satisfying and chewy and savory. If I'm feeling really fancy, I may get the maru-ten udon, which already comes with a generous 4 triangles of the delicious aforementioned fish cake, and add a potato croquette- perfectly crispy, served very hot and just greasy enough.

I do find that the croquette is much better when you request they bring it on a separate plate. I think it's a little weird when they put it on top of your soup and it gets very soggy very fast.

Cash only restaurant with a more of a hole in the wall vibe. We were seated immediately on a Friday dinner time. Ordered curry & rice to share, udon x tempura set and udon x chicken katsu set. The rice in general felt over cooked and dense :(. The curry was delicious, the tempura was perfectly light and crispy, and the chicken katsu also was light and crispy on the outside (without being super hard/rough in texture) and tender and soft on the inside. The udon was less impressive but still was good - just expected a wow worthy udon as the restaurant is named after their dish. That being said, it's a quick place to grab a bite (I recommend dining indoors as outdoors is so loud with people smoking outside) with affordable pricing on their combo sets (priced around $15-17). It's not a relaxing cute date spot though FYI!

This spot never disappoints! The combo sets are such a great deal! I always get the spicy tuna Don set which comes with a bowl of warm udon and a big bowl of spicy tuna over rice for $14.95. The udon is bouncy and chewy and the spicy tuna don is fresh and satisfies my sushi/fish cravings! Service is great, and place is clean. I never had an issue with anything here. Definitely a go-to spot when you don't know where to eat.
Sweet Japanese restaurant-albeit very small-that hits the spot if you are in the mood for Katsu. $16 a dish. 5/5 stars as a lunch spot.

You don't come here for good service you come here for delicious udon. I've been a customer since my high school days back when they were "Udon West". My go to is always the kalbi set, sometimes I add karaage. It's bar seating with two tables in the back for larger groups. When you come in you better have your entire party with you or you won't be seated, the lady that's normally there is abrupt and no nonsense. You don't come here to socialize, once you're done eating a bill is immediately placed next to you so you can leave. Udon St Marks holds a spot in my heart because sometimes you just want a hearty bowl of udon! Also, even though they raised the prices they're still very affordable.

I used to frequent this spot often during my undergraduate years pre covid.  Before covid, they only had 2 tables and most people sat at the bar. Now they have outdoor seating due to covid. However, many people smoke near the restaurant, so if you do not like the smell of cigarettes I do not recommend the outdoor seating. I highly recommend any of the tempura dishes that they offer. The batter they use for tempura is much thicker and savory than the batter that is used in tempura at sushi restaurants. I had the ika tempura set which comes with squid tempura over rice and a bowl of udon. I also added the fish cake and shrimp tempura to the udon. The udon has a very tasty broth and a generous portion of noodles and scallion. The rice dish came with a lot of fried squid and one fried broccoli over very soft and tasty rice.

Overall- Great place for an affordable and very tasty meal. 5/5 would recommend.

This is a small hole in the wall and it's so good! Second time we've been here. Ordered the negi toro set, which comes with udon and a good serving of negi toro over rice. We also ordered sides of shrimp tempura and fried chicken. Everything was fresh, cooked right and prepared in front of us since we sat the bar. Clean bathroom, cash only, but there's an atm out front. Awesome spot good service, spy on food, come and visit. Wont disappoint

Incredible value at this place but keep in mind it's cash only. I recommend getting a combo, you end up with two meals worth of food for around $15. Also keep in mind you can't split this combo with another person if you dine in, since there is a minimum amount to spend (around $7 if I recall correctly).
I ordered the gyudon combo and my friend ordered the tuna combo. The udon itself was solid, and the gyudon was still good the next day. Would recommend for quick service, large portions and tasty udon!

Udon cooked perfectly with a tame soup base that doesn't over or under whelm. Good service and the price is right. Oh, and it's BYOB so feel free to run across the street, grab some drinks and bring it over.

Super small little udon restaurant on St Mark's. They have a bar area with about a dozen? maybe less seats and like 2 or 3 tables. So it would be hard for a large group to be seated here. Also hard to be seated at lunch or dinner hour.

But this place is popular for a reason! They have super cheap prices for a gold amount of food. In my opinion, the set meals at the back of the menu are the most worth it! I got the gyu don set for $11.25. Honestly its enough for two people if you are not too hungry.  It came with a bowl of rice with stewed beef on top, which was super delicious. And also a bowl of udon. I cant tell if the udon is fresh since I do see that it comes in block form, and they throw it in and boil it, but it tastes pretty good to me.

Water is self service in front of the bar area and they have little hooks underneath the bar area for you to put your coats or bags. Would love to come here during off hours !

The lady helping us was very nice and friendly.
Got a nabeyaki udon and it was very tasty. It was also my first time trying this kind of dish. Very interesting. It is undo noodles cooked with vegetables like spinach and shiitake mushroom and meat like chicken and an egg in a clay pot. One thing a little off putting to me is that one of the two mushrooms I had was very sour. Not sure if it was supposed to taste like that. I was concerned i might get sick from that but apparently i was totally fine. So I guess maybe it is just how they cooked the mushrooms.

What a great place to relax after work or school. The menu is diverse and you have many options to choose from. HIGHLY HIGHLY HIGHLY recommend the set menu on the back of the menu. You will not be disappointed. The Yakiniku don is delicious and the fried chicken appetizer is juicy and comes with mayo and side salad. The Udon is springy and warm your stomach on a cold day in New York and the pippin hot tempura will be sure to sear your tongue so BE CAREFUL.
TIP: THEY ONLY TAKE CASH SO BE PREPARED

As a regular customer, I've always loved this place! With affordable prices and delicious Japanese food, this has always been my favorite places to dine at on a budget. I remember when this was called "Udon West". Every time I go, I usually order the Kara-Age Udon or Niku Udon! If you're on a budget and looking for Japanese food, I highly recommend Udon St. Marks!

One of my favorite udon places in nyc! I love to get the shrimp tempura udon or the simmered beef udon. Highly recommend the simmered beef because the beef is thinly sliced, tender, and marinated so well!

The price isn't that expensive - very affordable and great value!

The only thing is that the place is very small and the seating is only by the bar and two small tables in the back. So when it's busy, the wait can be a bit long and the wait area is very small as well.

Also this place is cash only

Totally my comfort food spot. Great variety of Udons, authentic and generous portions for Curry and rice dishes. I crave this place at least once a week. The prices are reasonable and the food is solid.

It's a quick service in and out comfort food restaurant. It's not fancy, not great for dates, but great for a quick comfort food hit. Totally reminds me of the Udon houses in Japan where you can drop in for a quick meal.

The owner is a cool Japanese guy. He was the cook before but I believe he bought the place during pandemic. He works his butt off and I'm all about supporting the hustle.

Came here yesterday because I was craving udon and something soupy since the weather turned colder. This was always on my list but I never got a chance to go.

I got a seat at the bar and got the combo: curry set with udon $9.50. I added extra toppings (each listed different price depending on item). I added simmered beef $4.20+ seasoned tofu (kitsune) $3.

Both were yummy. I finished everything as it was delish. Udon was soft, chewy and tender; very slurp worthy. I enjoyed the kitsune very much.

There is a water station in middle, tables in the back and bar seating available only. Therr are hooks for your jacket/bags under the bar table.

****CASH ONLY****

Pre-Covid i would eat at Udon West pretty often. I love their spicy tuna don and my bother loves the squid calamari. However, due to Covid, we were skeptical about going to restaurants with such enclosed spaces. We decided to order take out from them for the first time. Unfortunately it's just not the same. My spicy tuna don basically cooked from the steam of the hot rice so the texture was really off. And the udon noodles were not separated from the soup base so by it time we got home he noodles were really soggy. The flavors were still there but the texture is just not right. I guess i just have to wait out the pandemic to eat it in stores again.

This place is perfect if you're looking for a quick, bang for your buck meal!
But it really is nothing special.

You can order sets to get appetizers with udon noodles or rice. I ordered the regular Udon noodles with Karaage on the side set. I paid around $10 for the meal!

The noodles were the star of the show. Chewy, soft, and full of flavor from the broth. However, the broth made me really thirsty!

The karaage smelled super delicious coming in piping hot. But after taking a bite, it was more on the dry and hard side.

The meal came quickly and made me full. It wasn't the best but I would go back to try their other appetizers and rice options!

My friends recommended this place, so I've got to try on Friday. Been there with a group of 5 around 2PM , we got seated right away and it wasn't too cold to sit their outside seats.

Tried every appetizer that they have on the menu, Takoyaki, Gyosa, Tenpura, Kara-Ake. Everything was delicious and came fast. Their Combo Sets is a MUST!! I ordered Spicy Tunda Don Set, it came with small bowl of Udon, and rice with Fatty Spicy Tuna. It was amazinggggggggg!!!! I am not a big fan of Udon, but I love Udon here. My friends got their own combo set and they love their food too.

Service is also excellent. My server is sweet and very attentive. Will definitely come back and will def bring more people here. :)

CASH ONLY!

I stumbled upon this place sifting through the many options to eat. It did not disappoint. First of all it's cash only (there is an ATM) right outside the restaurant. It's a little lower than street level but the signage is easily visible.
The inside reminded me of being somewhere in Tokyo: small, simple and unpretentious. I was seated quickly. The menu offers many iterations of udon....some veggie options were available. I opted for a simple udon set that came accompanied by spicy tuna negitoro. Despite the fact that the thought of udon lured me in here the negitoro was the winner. Smooth, fatty melt in your mouth goodness on top of a bed of rice...yum. All this plus a Sapporo was around $18. I couldn't finish my udon as the portions are generous.

Note: Cash Only

Quick, delicious, simple Japanese noodle or rice restaurant.  I happen to be craving noodles and it was one of those NY days where it was raining and gloomy.

You tell the person how many people in your party.  Good for small groups.  There are a few tables in the back.  We sat on high bar stools by the wooden counter.  There are hooks under the bar to hang your items.  You get your own water from a dispenser on the left side.

The noodles in a warm broth hits the spot - kare-age (fried chicken) it is!  My friend ordered kari-age (shrimp and vegetable tempura) plus egg which cost a dollar more.

There is 1 restroom in the back.

I've been coming here for over 8 years and this place keeps getting better and better when it comes to food. Their spicy beef kimchi and spinach soup is the best and no other ramen place/soup compares. Their food is made fresh right in front of you as you can see the chefs do their magic. They have curries, simmered meats over rice (we had beef) and the meat is just soft and fresh and full of flavor. They only take cash and the place is always packed. This place is in st marks place and parking is a problem here.

*CASH ONLY*

Udon West is a small, authentic, and robust Japanese restaurant that is beaming with life and energy. We took a peek at the menu and we were amazed at all the food Udon West provides! I loved how each item had its own picture, as each restaurant's menu should. I ended up going with the fish cake tempura udon, as it was something I haven't heard of, let alone had before!

Within 2 minutes, our food comes out! My food is hot hot hot, so I have to wait a few minutes before I could start eating. Once I finally got a good sip of the broth, it was so savory! Its heat also warmed me up on this cold day, making it the perfect dish to eat. The fish cake tempura covering fell off quickly once I tried to pick it up with my chopsticks. I tried the fish cake tempura and it was like a wave of salt hit me! I had to drink four small cups of water in order to wash the salt dow. However, I did enjoy its squishy and chewy consistency. The udon noodles were also quite soft and thick, which I also enjoyed!

What a pleasure it was to come to Udon West! Quick service, great food, and affordable prices. What more could someone ask for?

Love these underground spots in NY. This place is REALLY small, like typical Japanese udon places. They have about 10-12 spots at the counter and just three small tables in the back. We were a party of five so two of us sat at a table and three at the counter. We only waited about eight minutes to sit. There are two guys cooking and one guy taking the orders.

I ordered the niku udon with an egg and some takoyaki for the three of us to share. Couldn't really tell if the takoyaki was made in house or frozen but it did taste fresh. A little too doughy but it was still good.
Udon broth was really good and flavorful. A little disappointed because the noodles were very chewy and soft. My friends also agreed but it was still a legit bowl of udon!

If you're in the area looking for udon, check them out!

CASH ONLY.

My favourite dish here is the Chigenabe Udon ($13.50). It's beef, kimchee, egg, spinach and udon in a spicy broth. Usually I have leftovers so I make some rice at home and have it with the broth.

They offer a variety of dishes for great deals and it's actually good quality. It always feesl like you're eating during Happy Hour or having a Lunch Special because the prices are so cheap.

Perfect for students and those on a budget. The only downside is the restaurant is not very big so usually there's a long line. They have the bar area which seats about 8-10 people and then 4-6 tables in the back area.

Cash only here.

Came for drunchies on a Friday late night and we were immediately seated at the bar.

I ordered the niku udon plus extra tempura. The tempura had a white pasty look to it instead of a nice golden brown. Objectively, tastes about the same, but it certainly didn't look as appetizing.

The udon was soft and chewy, very enjoyable to eat. The meat was salty and balanced out well with the broth and noodles. Tempura in the broth was soft and mushy.

Satisfying late night meal. Warm, tasty broth great for a winter night.

Udon West is a go to when you want a hot meal on a cold day. It hits the spot when it's winter and soup season is upon us. The udon or curry is hot, fresh, and affordable. The space is mostly counterspace with a small table in the back. The service is quick and seats fill up fast, but, luckily, I've never had to wait too long.

On my last visit, I ordered a shrimp tempura udon. The broth was light and perfectly savory. The tempura was airy and crispy atop. They placed the shrimps slightly dipped into the broth, which was fine. The udon was softer than I would have preferred, but they're usually firmer with a good bite. Overall, a satisfying lunch.

Cash Only
This place is so bomb for delivery.. but it sucks if you walk in. Pretty dingy inside and the staff is not very accommodating. I LOVE the udon though.
Lovely small business run by a passionate owner who is out here making everything FRESH! Got the lettuce wrap and enjoyed every bite. I gotta go back for one of their smoothies or juices.

Love this place.

For someone that doesnt eat enough fruits and greens, what's the best option? To drink it of course!

So far I have tried the Oh Kale Yeah and I enjoyed it. My husband refused to get one thinking he would hate it and feel disgusted seeing how healthy everything is. He surprised himself when he took a sip from my cup.

It brought interest to one of my friends who ended up trying their Tropical Splash (he normally detests healthy things but of course, he loved his drink!)

I also got a salad during the last few weeks of my pregnancy. Knowing that I was pregnant , the lovely owner took special care in cleaning all the veggies. He also double checked with me to make sure there wasn't anything I couldn't eat. As for the salad dressing, I asked for ranch but he had also recommended their self made dressing (I don't remember what it was but it was red). It was delicious!! I would have never tried it if he hadn't asked me to. No regrets whatsoever!

Yes I have gone back and yes I will keep going back (for as long as my wallet allows me to)

This place has very quickly become our go to for an easy, affordable and healthy dinner. Their acai bowl and chipotle chicken sandwich are our go tos. The avo chicken wrap is also delicious. There is usually only one person working so order ahead or be prepared to wait a bit during rush times (worth it though!). The staff is always so welcoming and kind- we love it here!

It's a pretty cool place to grab a smoothie.. it was delicious. However the prices are not in sync with portion amount.. I get it's a brand new place and has only been there for 9 months but you get more with sugar than salt and my smoothie was almost 10 bucks .. that's salty!

I've been to Urban Juicery a couple times and I've been very impressed.  My smoothies were perfectly made and quite delicious.  Just as impressive was the gentleman behind the counter.
