Friday 8:30 pm and half the food stalls stopped serving, WTF? The we missed out on Hainan jones (hainan chucken), Yum Yubu's yubu, Daisy's Dream's nasi lemak, etc.
On the bright side Mr Fried rice lived up to its name, rice was tasty with good eok hei but the stingray was too bony for my liking.  Prawnaholic's chow kuey teow also had good wok hei & well seasoned, i wish it can be more dry though.  We got the teh tarik from the Indian food stall and it was solid.  
Based on our limited experience the food was adequate & way overpriced. See attached video for better visuals.

youtu.be/Qe-HUSg9Rsg?si=…

This is a pricier food court as almost all the food options are about the same costly price but the variety and incredible homecooked feeling for meals is unmatched. I love that we can try super authentic cuisines without feeling like you have to travel halfway across the world for it.

There are so many options to try here, a little something for everyone. I've tried Dim Sum Darling, Kopifellas, Daisy's Dream Kitchen, Lady Wong. This review is for Daisy's Dream Kitchen as I can't find the Yelp page for it. I was excited to try their curry chicken but it was just okay. Ordered the chicken wings and it was good at first with a great crunch but as we started digging into it, found some weird chunks of extremely hard stuff...I can't even describe what it was but it could break your teeth. Just uncomfortable to eat. The flavor was also starting to taste like something that was left out too long. Just...odd. I enjoyed the chicken curry at Dim Sum Darling more.

My family and I LOVE this food court (aka hawker center) with all our hearts and all our tummies. Can't believe there is such authentic and delicious Singapore food here in NYC. Wow. We have so many favorites but our 2 absolute musts are:
- Daisy's Dream Kitchen (the Nasi Lemak, Otak, etc are amazing!) and
- Lady Wong's desserts - can't believe we can get such fabulous kuihs (ie cakes) here in NYC. Wow again.

Surprisingly large space with so many options! Can't wait to go back and try all the other restaurants / menus

We got:
- the spicy szechuan mala beehoon from White Restaurant 9/10: got medium spice but it wasnt spicy at alllll so i would recommend you go up if you want spice. The squid was very bouncy and delicious and the noodles were so flavorful.
- empres chicken noodle from Dim Sum Darling 8/10: the curry flavors were excellent but didn't quite hit the spot like the beehoon
- goodies from Lady Wong 10/10: so delicious! The mango tart thing in particular is really good

We've been waiting to hit Urban Hawker since it opened last year, and it DID NOT disappoint. Neither my BF nor I had ever eaten Singaporean food, so we could easily have gotten overwhelmed by all the choices here, but I have an old friend who's lived in Singapore for years and he gave me a laundry list of things to try, so we could divide and conquer.

BF got an iced Kopi (coffee with condensed milk), which he slurped down in mere moments (I gathered it was darned tasty). And we were off! We got Hainanese chicken rice from Hainan Jones, Black Pepper Crab from Wok & Staple, and a flight of dumplings from Dim Sum Darling.

Hainan Jones chicken was just heavenly and I could eat it every day. The broth-soaked rice was perfection, the poached chicken sublimely spiced and tender. Fabulous.

Wok & Staple's offering of black pepper crab was MASSIVE (sweet Dungeness goodness) and came with a bibs and rubber gloves. This was no fooling around. This is a dish you have to work for, but it's OH so worth the effort. The sweet crabmeat balanced with the spicy black pepper perfectly and it was magnificent (albeit a bit messy).

The sleeper hit were the dumplings from Dim Sum Darling. The flight comes with 7 chef's choice dumplings served on a bed of otherworldly rice topped with ground pork (the pork is optional). Easily the best dumplings I've ever had (so good that we got two more orders when a friend joined us spontaneously). My mouth is watering just thinking about them.

We loved everything about this space and can't wait to go back to try more!

Overexposure and COVID have both seen fit to end the food hall craze in NYC, for the most part. Still, Urban Hawker is here doing its thing in a cool space offering interesting eats from at least a dozen stalls.

On our most recent visit our party of four all got different things from three different stalls. The food wasn't expensive, and owing to our being there early in the day it was not crowded. My food was nothing to write home about, but I sampled some of the other food at our table and found things to like.

It's hard to write reviews of places with so many food stalls. Like, mine was just ok, but you might visit and have something outstanding. The purpose of a spot like this is to have a little bit of an adventure, maybe get out of the office and stretch your legs or get a blast of AC on a hot day. On those points this place scores high.

Love the variety of restaurants this food hall has! I was very impressed with the menus vendors had to offer. It was very authentic and similar to what you would find in Singapore (ex. nonya cuisine, malay dishes, drinks station). I tried the char kuay teow and iced honey lemon drink. Both were good although the noodles were on the oily side. I would defintitely go back to try more things. There is plenty of seating to eat there as well and you should be mindful to clear your own dishes.
Lots of fun selection and a bar to grab a brew while you eat some southeast Asian food. The best part was just exploring everything. It's all a bit on the pricier side.

Really good food court in an area that deeply needs it. Head there early or be prepared to fight for a table... as you can imagine, this zip code is inundated with tourists 24/7. We got some braised pork belly from Tradisyon (solid) and a couple of desserts from Lady Wong (also solid). Not sure if everything is authentic, as I'd need to pay this place several visits before getting an idea. Seats are plenty during off-peak hours, but more would be needed after 6p and on weekends, considering the amount of vendors available. Here they are:

Kopifellas (Singapore's Traditional Coffee, Boba Tea and Toast).
Ashes Burnnit! (Singapore's Burgers & Roti John's).
Hainan Jones (Singapore Hainanese Chicken Rice).
Lady Wong (pastry, cakes, kuih).
Prawnaholic Collections.
Dim Sum Darling.
White Restaurant.
Jakarta Munch.
Tradisyon.
Mr. Fried Rice.
Smokin Joe.
Wok & Staple (by Dragon Phoenix).
The Sling Bar.
Daisy's Dream.
Yum Yubu.
Pady d'NYC (Singapore Authentic Malay Cuisine).
Best Singapore Indian Cuisine.

Go hungry and have fun!
nice space to meet for a drink and enjoy singapore street food. Not extremely over priced.

I have traveled to Singapore & Malaysia before and I can say that the foods sold here were the closest in taste to what we had there. I would say the foods sold here were probably the best Singaporean/Malaysian I have eaten in NYC so far & there isn't that much Singaporean or Malaysian shops in NYC (comparing it to other asian cuisines like Chinese, Japanese, etc). Authentic Singaporean foods is even rarer.

We finally came to Urban Hawker 2 days ago with a very hungry stomach. We ordered to share: 1) Daisy's Dream Laksa noodle, 2) Ashesburnit Roti John sandwich, 3) White beehoon's signature white beehoon noodle, 4) Lady Wong's ondeh ondeh roll & kuihs, 5) Kopifellas kopi and teh.

Daisy's Dream Laksa Noodles - WOW! Super delicious! The broth was not that coconutty, a bit on the sour/vinegar side but still very delicious & savory. We chose half thin and thick noodles - great contrasting  texture. The fish balls, dried tofu, shrimps & boiled egg complemented well with this entree. I haven't found a decent laksa that replicated the one I ate at Singapore & Malaysia, but this one was the closest. I truly enjoyed this and I would come back to eat this again!

Ashesburnit Roti John - WOW! Amazing flavors - cheesy, savory, meaty, etc. It was a party in my mouth. The bread is on the soft mushy side which I liked. My sister didn't like the bread texture. I would reorder this!

White beehoon's signature white beehoon noodles - I am amazed with this item. It doesn't look special but it was superrr delicious! This entree was packed with taste and the beehoon noodles were not mushy and there were a lot of noodles! The shrimp was al dente and the veggie was crunchy and yummy. Broth was nice and savory. My sister loved this item the most. I liked it but the laksa was more exciting to me. We ordered the combo set, which comes with 1 appetizer (we chose seafood gyoza) and 1 drink (Yeo's chrysanthemum. The seafood gyoza was crunchy and tasty & the Yeo's drink was alright (not a big fan of Yeo's as it is a bit watered down. I prefer Vita's chrysanthemum drink more).

Lady Wong's ondeh ondeh roll & kuihs - I looove lady wong's desserts.  We have tried their desserts at the other location in Soho. The ondeh ondeh roll was like a pandan coconut roll - super delicious and creamy! I tried all their kuihs and I keep getting their pandan coconut & talam pandan with coconut caramel kuih. I am not a fan of their rainbow kuih as it looks nice but doesn't taste anything special.

Kopifellas kopi (coffee) & teh (tea). We ordered iced Kopi O & iced Teh O (both with condensed milk). Both were very delicious and tasted as good as the ones we consumed in Singapore and Malaysia.

This is not the typical hawker center you find in Singapore or Malaysia, so you can not compare the urban hawker to it. Hawker centers are typically located within residential/housing complexes, so prices are much more affordable for the locals. This one is located near Times Square area (tourist area) so prices will be much higher. Despite the fact that the price of the foods are much more expensive here, the quality of the foods was there. I would come back to try their other foods, esp the stingray fried rice (I miss the sambal stingray I had in Singapore to this day).

Amazing spot for some authentic Singaporean eats *was authenticated by my Sinaporean bf*. Recommended to us by a friend, and we came here to eat every other day during our time in NY bc it was so good and convenient!! Lots of stalls and options to choose from, my favorite was the Laksa noodles (lovely combo of thick noodles, fish balls, shrimps, and flavorful coconut soup base). I also really wanted to try the chilli crab there!! but so did everyone else so they were already sold out by the time we went - make sure to get them early if you go!

It's such a warm bustling environment to be in. If you enjoy Singaporean/Asian food, would recommend you check out this spot!!

Nestled in between 6th and 7th ave is Ubran Hawker - a Singaporean concept food hall where you can try a myriad of Singaporean dishes for a decent price. The night I went, many kiosks were closed but I got to try what I wanted, the chili crabs! I believe there's only one kiosk that serves it and not sure if the crab is market price but it was $55 per crab in August.

I've been wanting to check out the urban hawker for ages! Finally, got a chance to swing by and buy a few of my favorite dishes to go.
The place had such a cute vibe, some beautiful artwork and plenty of seating. Didn't get to try this but there was a sleek sling bar on one side too.

As for the food, I didn't have enough time to stay there so I bought these items to go. I had the chicken rice (roasted) set - it was so good wish there was more chicken in the serving. The carrot cake (Chai tow kway) - my fav dish during my visit in Singapore- this was on their limited menu (hope they make it on their main) but it def hit the spot. The murtabuk was unexpectedly good - first time trying it (highly recommend while it's hot and crunchy). Lastly, I got the chicken lumpia they were mini but perfect.

Can't wait to go back and try more things

What a hidden gem about 5 minutes walking distance from the theater where the Wicked Broadway musical is performed! Are you craving some Southeast Asian cuisine? Look no further and run (don't walk) over! Lots of vendors where you can satisfy your fried rice, noodle, etc. cravings. There is even one bar inside (I recommend the tequila + lycee drank!). It got pretty packed around 7pm, so I suggest coming in a little earlier. Also, prob best to come in earlier if you are eyeing some pastries near the front. They run out fast! While not quite Singapore-- it will do for now while in NYC. Bring a friend or a big group, and share share share! Great vibes. Good food. A little steep but that's the price of happiness in this concrete jungle.

Finally tried this place, good location and close to theatre district. Place is nice and had a variety of food vendors and they also have a bar inside. I liked that there was a lot of seating area and it was spacious enough. My food was prepared fast and didn't wait too long. I decided to order the Singapore pineapple fried rice (came with nuts and shrimp!) this was so good and portion size was good. For appetizer I ordered a small side order of fried chicken which was really tasty and for dessert I ordered a lychee rose type of custard. The place for dessert had cool and interesting flavors. I have to come back and try more of the other foods.

As a person who grew up eating a lot of Singaporean and Malaysian food, I'm so glad I got a chance to check out Urban Hawker! Yes it's definitely on the pricier side, esp in contrast to actual hawker food stalls, but I think the prices are comparable to the NYC food scene.
I was impressed by the nyonya laksa which was very rich with its coconut based curry and lemongrass flavors. While I wish it was more spicy, I enjoyed the al dente rice noodles and the generous serving of tofu puffs and fish cakes. I do wish they gave more than 3 pieces of shrimp for an additional cost of $3. The sambal wasn't as spicy I had hoped, and a little on the sweeter size, but I do appreciate the abundance of shallots and preserved veggie taste.
Took a bite of my friend's chicken rice and the meat was pretty tender/flavorful. I also got kuik from Lady Wong which was pretty solid with the authentic pandan flavors!
I didn't get a chance to try everything but they have a kopitam like stall with all your kopi and milo needs! I can't wait to come back and check out the stalls serving chili crab and other pork rice dishes. In addition to more traditional Singaporean/Malaysian, they also have stalls serving Filipino and Indian food. On the day I visited, they were doing a promo for Singapore National Day so I got a nice $5 coupon. The entire venue was clean and spacious.

Passed the hyped up food court in which I've been hearing about it from my friends. Walked around the place and passed by all the vendors. Then, I place an order of the Chicken Cutlet over Curry Rice at Smokin Joe.

* This is solely the review for Smokin Joe.

The booth specializes in Hainanese Curry Rice & Singaporean Grill. The total of my meal comes out to be $17.81. I get that it's Midtown but $17.81 for food coming from a food court.....that's just way too overpriced for me. Not just this booth either, but every restaurant's entree is at least $15-19.

Food courts are supposed to be cheaper than regular restaurants. What's the point of having food priced at $15-19 and then you want to call it a food court?  To me, it's nothing but a tourist trap. Plus, the food comes out lukewarm and not hot like it should be.

The taste is decent but there's way too little curry with the rice to be called curry over rice. I don't think the food is freshly made either....more like pre-made because I placed my order at 5:14pm hence the receipt. The food is ready at 5:21pm. Last thing I know, you need at least 15-20 mins to freshly fry the chicken cutlet. And, there's no way cutlet of any kind can be finished with cooking in 7 mins.

Like I'm saying, the food isn't freshly made which defeats the purpose of eating/dining at an eatery/restaurant. The curry is more towards sweet than spicy which is okay if you tend to like sweet curry. Don't think I'll ever be returning. In fact, this is my first time and possibly my last time eating at Urban Hawker. The curry taste is very similar to the chicken cutlet with curry from K-Town's Food Gallery 32. Except the portion size at Food Gallery 32 is larger and $2-3 cheaper than Smokin Joe from Urban Hawker. In other words, I would rather pay & eat at FG32 than UH. Sorry.Not.Sorry!

One other thing, I think they ought to install AC because it's so stuffy in there. My back is sweaty and I'm already wearing a tee.

A lovely Asian-cuisine focused food court with an assortment of food and desserts to choose from! I enjoyed the Hainanese chicken and Lady Wong desserts. I even took some to go to enjoy the next day. There are lots of places to order from so there's sure to be something for everyone!

Atmosphere is casual.

A great place for a casual date or hangout that will surely satisfy anyone's tastebuds.

Good food hall for Singaporean food. It was quite busy when I came, but luckily I was able to find a table. The number of food options here can be overwhelming, with about 15-20 different vendors. I heard good things about Hainan Jones so I decided to eat there.

The Hainanese chicken rice at Hainan Jones was phenomenal. I got the signature set, which came with a side of soup broth and veggies. Everything was full of flavor. My boyfriend tried some and wanted to order it for himself. Unfortunately, they sold out and closed before he could do so. This was about 7PM on a Sunday. He ending up getting the Hainanese curry rice at Smokin' Joe and enjoyed it. Next time, I would like to check out other vendors.

The history and execution behind this concept is quite interesting. Anthony Bourdain had a dream of bringing the Asian street market to the city of New York and it is definitely an Asian food court. There's a variety of different Asian cuisines here with a limited dessert option.   Surprisingly, there were a lot of seats and somehow we got lucky and found a table for six. If you're vegetarian, there are lots of delicious options for you to try. Go with friends so you can sample the different restaurants available. It's a unique experience.

Came around 12:30pm on a Sunday and needless to say it was pretty busy but can still find seats if you wait a bit. Love the atmosphere, it's slightly dim but the neon lights really give the place a nice vibe to it.

I don't remember the exact dishes we got but we did get foods from Yum Yubu, Prawnaholic Collections, and the Jakarta place. Decent meals and filling, definitely would come back to try other dishes because there's so many diverse asian dishes here.

You may have better SE Asian options in Chinatown or Flushing. A lot of not great reviews here are variations of this. But you're not in Chinatown or Flushing - you're in Midtown.

The selection of SE Asian / Singaporean foods here is impressive. I tried to get the more authentic Singaporean dishes, and they were delicious.

This was one of Anthony Bourdain's projects, and a worthy one. RIP Tony.

You will love urban hawker . It is a Singapore food hall initially but it is greater than that
Not only does it have many food stalls to choose from it also holds a large bar named Sling. I visited last Saturday and ate at mr fried rice.
I missed the lion dance for Chinese New Year but it was cool.
Food prices range between $10-$25 an entree. There is plenty of seating and eager staff keeps the tables clean.
Oh the first stall is a boba coffee tea vender.

Ok now for me fried rice . This stall obviously serves everything with fried rice . I got the salmon and my friend date had the stingray.
I forgot to ask for no egg but I could hardly taste it. Thank goodness. It was delicious.
I washed it down with a yeo chrysanthemum tea
Thanks for reading
The bathrooms are on the lower level

What a great and interesting concept.  This place gets its name from the Hawkers market in Singapore.  Most of the restaurants there are Singapore restaurants.  
The place was packed with happy eaters.  
Wish they had this where we lived!  
Street and lot parking.  Free WiFi.

A nice reprise from the touristy spots in Midtown. Everyone flocks to the Hainan Chicken Rice place but I nearly got whiplash when I saw the Crispy Pata (Fried Pork Knuckles) at Tradisyon. OMG, I was in hog-heaven.

Pictures do not give this place or this dish justice. The entire dish is fried nice and crispy all around! I recommend eating there so you don't risk any inch of sogginess. To make myself feel a smidge better, I ordered the Rambutan Pineapple Salad. LOL I loved both dishes.

Meanwhile, my parents went for Hainan Jones. They thought the chicken was "pretty good" but the rice was soggy and lacked flavor. They've definitely had better.

We all wrapped up our time at Urban Hawker with drinks from Kopifellas. Being huge HK style milk tea fans, we really appreciated that the tea is brewed in the traditional tea socks. So we all had cups of Teh. The perfect way to end our time here.

Food 7/10
A pretty cool spot with plenty of different options. Convenient if you work in one of the buildings nearby for a solid meal. Quite pricy for what it is, as it's basically a hawker center. We ordered the Hainanese chicken and the laksa, both were alright, but not very authentic. The coffee was sweet because of the cream, so that was quite good and refreshing. My favorite was the dessert spot, as the ube mochi was a great combination of what I love: ube and mochi. Fun to experience once but probably won't be returning.

Atmosphere 7/10
An elevated food center, cool interior space with a good number of seating.

Service 8/10
Fast.

Mega packed and busy on a Friday night. It was hard to find a seat. Vendors took a while to get us our food. I got a nasi lemak and laksa noodles. Both were underwhelming. The nasi lemak was really plain. The only thing that was flavorful was the dried anchovies. The laksa was also non traditional. It was just spicy and not very tasty. I got a instant stomachache from something I ate here. The bathrooms were unisex and had long lines.

I also ordered two kuih from Lady Wong. The rose flavored one and the coconut flavored one was decent. They messed up my order. I paid for two but they only gave me one piece so I had to walk back to get my second piece.

All in all, way too overpriced and meh.

So after visiting Singapore recently, I wondered to myself why aren't hawker stands a thing in the US? I was pleasantly surprised to learn about Urban Hawker and made it a point to visit.
Overall, there's a good representation of traditional Singaporean dishes such as black pepper crab, fish balls, and Singaporean coffee. And the flavors are spot on.... The black pepper crab is just as good as over there, and I'd definitely be back to try the chili crab. However, the one thing I didn't see was sugar cane water, which was my go-to drink in a good warm Singaporean day.
While I appreciate the interior, it feels more like Singapore meets Chelsea Market, and less like a hawker center. While the decor is lovely and probably makes the center a bit more approachable for someone who has never visited Singapore, it did make me miss the feel of Singapore's centers.
The prices are New York prices.... But I wouldn't expect anything less. That being said, service is quick ... even the black pepper crab. And the staff even made a point of stopping over by our table to see if we were enjoying our meal, which was an unexpected touch.
While it's not the same as Singapore... it's 18 hours closer and definitely worth a stop!

This is essentially a more clean hawker 'center' in midtown with a variety of food businesses home to Singapore. There's a lot of seating from standing tables to tables with 6 seats. It gets really business though so come early for seating.

There's curry, fried rice, hainanese fried rice, Malaysian dessert, chili crab, and so much more! My friend and I got the original beehoon from the White Restaurant and curry katsu from the Smokin Joe stall. The beehoon was sooo good. It has an eggy base with hints of seafood (mainly from the shrimp). I seriously have not had beehoon in nyc and this is so good. I've had this in Singapore in a hawker center and seriously this just taste the same. SOOO GOOD. It's light and less heavy compared to the curry.

The curry katsu from Smokin Joe was so juicy. The katsu was not dry and the curry sauce was made to perfection. Topped off with the runny egg, I can't name a better combination. Seriously get this if you like heavier flavors.

There's also a bathroom downstairs if you need it!

It's located between 6th and 7th Ave. You can enter from either W 51st St or W 50th St. This was a nice food court collection of small restaurants serving iconic Singapore flavors. Some of the food that these different restaurants offer are Malay, Peranakan, Chinese, and Indian. I was definitely not disappointed with the variety from which to choose! It's always nice to have so many good options gathered in one place.

As of early November, here's the list of restaurants that are occupying a stall here at that urban hawker:
Mr. Fried Rice - Wok-fried rice
Padi D' NYC - Malay street food
Daisy's Dream - Laksa, Nasi Lemak, and more
Lady Wong - Southeast Asian pastries
Tradisyon - Filipino comfort food
White Restaurant - Creators of White bee hoon
Smokin' Joe - Hainanese Western fare
Kopifellas - Modern Singapore coffee
Yum Yubu - Rice-filled tofu pockets
Jakarta Munch - Indonesian rice and salad bowls
Wok & Staple - Creator of the iconic chili crab
Mamak's Corner - Singapore Indian food
Ashes Burnnit - Inventive Singapore burgers
Prawnaholic Collections - Prawn noodles
Hainan Jones - Hainanese chicken rice
The Sling Bar - Singapore-inspired cocktails

This food court brings you to Singapore as it has various food vendors that you typically find there. Among others are Indonesian (Jakarta Munch), Malaysian, Indian food,. Don't forget to stop by at Lady Wong pastries for Asian inspired desserts

Relatively new food court right off of 6th ave. It's mostly Singapore style cuisine and there are probably a dozen or so stores/vendors inside.
There's plenty of seating but it can get busy here especially during meal times.
I was here on a Sunday evening and it was pretty crowded. Seating was available without a wait but we had to walk around to find an open table.
You can get your meal from one place of multiple places. Most of them hand out the buzzers to let you know when you're order is ready.
I'll definitely be back to try every place in here.
Food courts like this are popular overseas so I'm glad they are starting to make an appearance here.

This place is overhyped. My good friend Anna and I came here yesterday with a high expectation only to find the food to be just average and overpriced. I ordered the wok fried Hokkien prawn noodle and I didn't enjoy it. I'm FJ and I know a good Hokkien prawn noodle when I come across one. I really wanted the fried oyster omelet but it is way overpriced... it's $18 and with tax and credit card surcharge, it was $20.29...  fried oyster omelets are way cheaper in Chinatown.

The food court was pack... we ended up across the street at the public plaza where they have lots of public seating.

Really cute food court full of good, singaporean eats! I only tried the white restaurant (which was really good), but all the other places looked good too. Food here is expensive, because NYC, but it's worth a try. Gets pretty busy around lunch time, and it was hard to find a table.

"Use revolving door." What in the ableist BS caused management to think it's remotely okay to install accessible doors that only open from the inside? Wheelchair users cannot use a revolving door. We go places by ourselves. It's not only ridiculous that I can't let myself into this brand new establishment in 2022, but it's actually an ADA violation.

Letting people use the stationary doors would also bring more ventilation into this overcrowded place, which is sorely needed as we are still in a pandemic. The line for Hainan Jones at 12:30 on a Monday looked to be 50 people deep with everyone tightly packed in and very few wearing masks. A few stalls closer to the 51st street side were oddly closed for the day. Did not feel safe at all so left quickly without ordering.

This is definitely a great spot to pick up lunch if you work in Midtown. However, I like to stop here for Partners Coffee! If you need a caffeine boost, their seasonal drinks are always worth a try. I will eventually order out from one of the other booths here!

great place to eat lunch if in midtown manhattan, with a variety of cuisines, all for reasonable prices.   It will get pretty crowded during peak lunchtime.  Wasn't crazy about the number of bathrooms, and there was no place at all to fill up your reusable water container with filtered water.

This place is next to my office, but I never went inside or really knew much about it.  It's a large space with several different food and drink vendors. When one of my colleagues left, we had a going away drink for him. We stayed in the front at Seamore's but to my riposte, I noticed there was a Roberta's in the back. I've always wanted to try that place, and in the near future, I'll be able to.

The space is here is ample, and in the summer the outdoor area is jam packed. I would say this is the perfect place for lunch or an after work drink.

This food hall is located beneath plenty of midtown high-rise offices and is geared towards the lunch crowd, even if it's ostensibly open until 9pm on weekdays (it's closed on the weekends).

When I stopped by during the lunch hour, things were quite busy everywhere, with folks squeezing past each other to reach the innermost parts of the food hall on the ground level. There were lines at many outlets, but these moved along methodically; in fact, the key bottleneck on the ground level is the fact that folks don't have a space to wait except standing in the middle in everyone else's way.

In total, there are about 15 outlets spanning a variety of cuisines and dishes, whether ramen, seafood, pizze, Korean fried chicken, salads, or sushi, to name a few. Many outlets appeared to be fulfilling Doordash (or other delivery) orders in addition to in-person ones. I found that prices weren't outrageous at most outlets, and I was particularly impressed with the second-floor loft, which is not only a group-friendly environment but also offers benches that overlook all the action down below.
Eh, not my favorite spot. There's very little seating, the options are mediocre, and the one place I got food from was a letdown.

Was excited to try out this food hall but disappointed in the quality and food offered here. If you like Asian fusion food then this might be worth a shot, but if you're looking for authentic then I'd say skip. It's cute inside but small, and the bao spot does give big portions.

I am currently eating a bowl from 21 Grains. I almost broke a tooth on the first bite. Turns out half the rice is either undercooked or got completely dried out (see pic). Guys... this place is named after the grain. Really? I can hardly eat my lunch but don't have time to go back out.

Bowl chosen advertised "softened broccoli rabe" and a squirt of Sriracha. There is a bit of roasted regular broccoli, and zero sauce of any kind.

Really disappointed.

Two stars because the piece of plain roasted salmon is fine.

My daughter had a chorizo burrito at the Mexican place. My wife had sushi at the Japanese place. And I had some food at the Indian restaurant. The burrito was good and my wife's dish was also good. My Indian food was just ok. Great selection in general. Not sure I will go back. We went there for the variety but it was average.

Do not order from Mysttik Masala here. Inaccurate food listings, rude staff, order took over 30 minutes and was not as listed. They claim to offer "chana saag", which is actually extremely spicy chana masala with a few spinach leaves on top. Completely inedible! Do not go here!
A food spot with many options ranging from small bites to meals and açaí bowls to Asian cuisine to Italian. Good lunch spot with outdoor and indoor seating.

Too loud no one can hear your order and it's always wrong. Tried 3 times 3 different places and the food was always overpriced and disappointing.

Urbanspace Vanderbilt and Lexington are good.
This is like an upscale food court. So many great choice.  Good place for a group.  Teenagers loved it. Fun concept.  We'll be back.

Great concept with small food vendors. The space is comfortably laid out with ample seating, both upstairs and down. It's warehouse like, so the noise is a little overwhelming. However there is a little bit of everything here, which would be great for groups.

I had a Happy Lobster roll with vinegar slaw. Delicious! And a nice size portion for a lobster roll. My husband really enjoyed his burger and fries from Edzo's. And we couldn't miss some incredible donuts from Stan's. The croissant donut is simply dreamy - sugar coated with custard layered in - perfection!

It's a cute food hall but kind of overpriced. I left hungry. [CONEY SHACK]

I got the short rib hotdog - the flavors were good but it was REALLY messy so make sure to grab a fork/spoon, and a ton of napkins in advance. It wasn't the flavor I was personally expecting, but still good. I paid about $14 for the hotdog that didn't really even fill me up which annoyed me.
My friend got one of their roti wraps which was maybe $12? and it looked like the $1 quesadilla from taco bell - it was pathetically small. Decent tasting but very small.

Seating is kind of nice and open but also a bit awkward. Hoping to come back soon to try more and take it to go.
Ok spot to grab a quick bite. Couple of them around the city. Selection is decent and the prices at the food vendors are good.
Half the spots are closed at dinner time and the ones that stay open stop serving food at 8 pm.

We went here hearing how cool Urbanspace is. But we didn't realize that over half the restaurants would be closed at dinner time. We tried Plant Junkie, Roberta's and Kuro-obi and found all of them just okay or worse. It was probably the worst meal we had during our Manhattan trip. Oh well, you can't win them all.

Wow , Urbanspace has now opened their new food hall with over a dozen vendors some of which are not found at there other locations.

The layout is similar to Urbanspace Lex which also has a mezzanine level. It's is in the back side of the AXA Building and has entrances on 52th Street and on Avenue 6 1/2, yes 6 1/2 look it up it a pedestrian walkway running across several blocks and had outside seating during the summer months. Their is also an interesting mural that spreads out the name 'named 'Urbanspace W52' across the width of the food hall.

The vendor list is as followings;

Black Iron Burger               Classic American Burgers

Cafe Patoor                        Brazilian Brigadeiro cake, breads

Call Me Pasta                     Customizable pasta bar

City Tamale                        Mexican food gluten-free!

Coney Shack                     Hot Dogs, Tacos with an Asian twist

Dorado                              Mexican street food

Eisenberg's                        Deli sandwiches Egg Cream

Go Fish Sushibox              Sushi rolls Shasimi

LoLo's Chichen Shack       Customizable Chicken bowls

Partner's Coffee                Cafe

Pita Yeero                          Greek street food

Plant Junkie                       Vegan

Robertas                            Wood fired Pizza

Sustainable Seafood         Seafood

Tomo Tomo                       Ramen

Don't wait for reviews, just go and try them out for yourself their has to be a least 3 or 4 that you will like.

Eisenberg's - get it together. I ordered a corned beef on rye with mustard. Simple order. They made me a Reuben. I caught this when they handed  it to me and reiterated my order, corned beef on rye with mustard. I get back to my desk and noticed my sandwich smelled a little off. I lift up the bread and they basically made a Reuben without the Russian dressing. So I go back and ask for the correct order, corned beef on rye with  mustard and get asked if I want cheese and if I wanted sauerkraut. I finally get the right order and the sandwich was just not good. I don't think they seasoned the corned beef. It was very bland, almost like they just boiled the beef with no seasoning. I would avoid this place until they figure it out.

Day 2 - tried Margherita pizza at Roberta's. Ordered the small which is the size of a paper plate for $13+ with tax. Not impressed, lacked taste. You're better off going to one of the pizza food trucks in the area.

I'll keep trying with Urbanspace, so far other than the convenience of the location there's nothing special about it.

Long gone are the days of the under $10 lunch.

Day 3 - Lolo's Chicken Shack - ordered Lime Chicken with brown rice and potatoes and green sauce. My order came to $14.70. Wasn't terrible nor was it something I would order again. Not really much taste to it. The best thing I've had so far at Urbanspace but for  the price I expect more.

I'm not really sure how many more vendors I will try at this rate, nothing has really been worth writing home about.

I've noticed a 5 star review - looks like it's more about the concept, and a 4 star review similar to it. Are these people somehow connected to Urbanspace or Yelp employees? Asking for a friend :)

I will be collectively reviewing places as I try it!

Lolo's chicken shack (1/5). What a weird concept. You get hot rice and chicken on top of cold salad. They should make the sides warm. I got the yellow rice and lentil base which came with no lentil but rather raisins. It was really dry. Then I got the lime chicken which was basically boiled chicken with no flavor that was boiled so much that there's zero moisture in the chicken. The chilled broccoli salad which is cold boiled broccoli. The coco curry sauce which was good but you'd need 4x the amount to make up for the dryness. And the jicama salad on the side which was fine.

Tomo Tomo: (5/5). I got the house special ramen with an extra egg and added on karaage to make it a combo. It came with a good amt of karaage so that was definitely good value for the extra $2.50. All the ramen comes with 2 pieces of pork belly (guessing except the veggie ramen), bamboo shoots, spinach, and scallions. They should make that more clear so the cashier isn't explaining it 2x per minute. Everything tasted great. The broth is really rich/thick and there isn't that much of it - I might have preferred a lighter broth. I came at 1:20pm and even though they say they have only 50 quantities of the house special, I was able to get it. The egg was cooked BEAUTIFULLY. Pork belly was very tender and thick as well.

Pita Yeerp (3.5/5). I got the bowl (salad + grape leaves + pita) with sides of marinated beans + french fries, got a mix of the lamb and chicken, topped with spicy feta. All came out to $13 something for a TON of food. They also had spanokopita and soup that I'd like to try next time but the cashier rushed everything so I couldn't order it in time. The fries were meh (kinda stale), the beans were fine, the salad was like a cole slaw that was fine, the meat was fine and I couldn't really tell the difference between them, grape leaves were fine, spicy feta was fine. I took issue with the fact that you are mixing hot + cold (the spicy feta was really cold and made the meat cold) so I microwaved everything (incl the salad).

Call me Pasta - bland rigatoni with little meat sauce...
And they don't include cheese on the side (unless they forgot)

Not worth $13!!!...and a tip for doing what extra for me???

Tip subsidizes the owner!!!...

Bought lunch at City Tamale on a Saturday afternoon. Ordered the 2 tamale combo with rice and beans. Added a small cup of soup ($5)!!!
Awfully dry tamales. Wasn't even wrapped in husks in the takeout container. Soup was served in a 4 oz. container. Did mention it was $5??? Threw away $20 of garbage.
Avoid at all costs.

This review is for Eisenberg.
Ever since Pastrami Queen @ 49st closed I've been trying to find a decent pastrami sandwich. Was hoping this place would have it since they're a deli sandwich place, but I wouldn't come back. The sandwich is worst than Juniors @ 49st (a tourist trap). Eisenberg's Pastrami is tough, burnt and over cooked. It's as if they're serving pastrami about to go bad since they're double cooking it for reheat.

Also this place is stupidly set up. The space from the counter to the rope barrier is very narrow, only enough space for 1 person. Once you place your order the common courtesy is to step farthest down the counter so the next person can order. The stupidity is the the person handing out the completed orders stands right next to the cashier/order taker. So they just call out your name and place the bag right at the counter near the cashier and none of the staffs bothers to hand your order directly to you even when they see where your standing. You can only hope that other nice customers will pass your order down to you. This is also how I know this place doesn't care besides serving bad food.

I'll still go back to Urbanspace 52 to what the other stalls have to offer.

This place was great! It was described to me as an upscale food court.  I loved the food choices, there's something for everyone and considering it is in the middle of the tourist section of NYC the prices were pretty fair.  They had a ramen place, a sushi place, burger, vegetarian, taco, and much more. There was even a bar for those that wished to partake. Most of the seating was upstairs and it was a little noisy up there but it was lunchtime and crowded, but no so crowded we couldn't find a place to sit. I would go back.

Urban Space at West 52nd Street is a great addition to the fast casual midtown west lunch/dinner options. I went at an off peak time in the afternoon and found the food hall to be fairly full and lively. They have a wide array of vendors serving a great variety of foods (including tacos, sushi, burgers, pizza, vegetarian foods.) I went to Cafe Patoro and loved the cheesy bread that they served; so excited to go back and try all the options.

This review is for Eisenbergs at Urbanspace 52. Went to the urban space today. Decided to get a corned beef and pastrami combo reuben. Let's just say I won't be back for this sandwich. Very soggy and not much meat and half the meat was fat!  Pastrami was more a brown color than red.  My recommendation is skip the sandwich. Now need to find something else for lunch.

This is more a review for the pasta place inside this UrbanSpace - "Call Me Pasta". I had the cacio e pepe, and it was authentic, al dente, and delicious. They seem to serve real Italian sized portions, so some Americans might be disappointed that it's not the heaping bowl that like an Olive Gatden would serve. I haven't been to the other spots in this food hall yet, but would definitely go back for pasta.

I waited until I'd tried a few places to rate and overall I've enjoyed the food at this location. Pita Yeero was really delicious - the pork gyro was very tender, and you could tell their gigantes are made in house and marianted in a really sweet and delicious tomato sauce. They also have a honey mustard option, which I rarely see in Greek places in the States, and I really appreciate.

Tomo Tomo's tonkatsu broth is super thick, and while I don't think I can get it every day for fear of falling asleep at my desk, it was so satisfying, especially today when the temperature is so cold out. The marinated egg had a perfectly drippy yolk, the noodles had the right amount of bite, and the chashu pork was firm, but came apart easily when added to the broth.

Finally, the Sushi station (I forget the name of it) - the salmon bowl I got was okay. The fish itself was fresh and very tender, but the rice was a bit too dense, and to be honest, the prices were a bit high.

Across the board, I'd say the prices do tend to fall on the higher end, and ultimately some of the stations at this location will be worth it more than the others.

Used to work next door and was waiting for this to open after Bobby Flay's restaurant closed a few years ago.  And yesterday we got the chance having scored tx to watch the taping of the Steven Colbert show.  I went straight for the Greek food, namely Pita Yeero.  Had the grain bowl with 2 meats, hummus, spicy fava beans, brown rice, beans, grape leaves, hummus and pita.  A large portion for $12 and very tasty.  Chatted with the owner about Greece and he gave us free spinach pies.  Hubby had their bakalva for dessert and loved it.  He also opted for Roberta's pizza.  Had an individual pizza with cheese, sausage and honey with a very thin crust.  Said it was delish.  A welcome additional to the 5 star restaurants around the Rockefeller Center area.

This place is a logistical nightmare. First thing I was greeted with was a single revolving door to get in, with a line of people waiting ....I should have taken that as a sign. Inside, there is absolutely NO system of management for the lines. They sprawl out to the point that you have no idea what stall a line is for, or where they end. I understand that a food hall in this area will be packed, especially since we've all been lacking lunch options for so long, but they really either didn't expect or properly plan for the demand.

An incredibly cute, very cool cafe in DUMBO! The staff are kind and welcoming which really comes through in the ambience and atmosphere they created with the furniture, books, and music. I'll be coming back and I will be telling all of my friends too!

Minimalist bookstore and cafe - unexpected oasis for working and reading  because there's so much construction and noise in this area of Dumbo. They have an art gallery in the front of the cafe with rotating exhibits. Delicious, warm Japanese meals for dine-in or takeaway. Not cheap as inflation rises, but generous portions- and worth it if you're going to spend some hours working or reading. I ordered the gyudon, which is tender and perfect with the rice.

Loved being surrounded by culture and design books. I'll be back to try other items on the menu.

I got their cold brew and it was...really sour....and my friend got like a brown sugar matcha and it was too sweet..the coffee shop has a cool artistic vibe with couches and alittle shopping corner...but something about the place felt like it was fully furnished, the cafe area was in a dark corner and it just didn't feel like a well established place. Unique vibe with art gallery touches but the drinks were kinda bad and I just wouldn't come back again. The barista was very nice though

They have an extremely poor system in giving out their food orders. I placed an order on the QR code that doesn't require an app and it says to wait until they call your name. My food was probably ready for a good 40 minutes but no one said anything. Went up to the register and the lady told me it was ready on the app so...where was it? It was hiding on the side behind the counter. I never received a ready notification anywhere. Anyways, that system is pretty shitty as they'll sometimes call names out and then won't.

As such, food was mediocre. Gyudon was about $18 after tax. It had a lot of rice and onion and was just overall really mushy. Might have been the fact that it was just sitting there but I grade things as I receive them. The matcha latte was ok but cost me about $8 for the smallest serving which is fine depending on the quality of matcha used. I heard their coffee is supposedly good but never got the chance to try it.

Good work space with wifi and environment but gets extremely busy during lunch. Not sure if I would come by here again in the future since it seems to be a hot mess.

A great spot to do work or spend an afternoon in! The location around the area has some cute spots but is mostly under constructions as of now, but doesn't impact the ambiance of this place. There are many outlets located around the area along with couches and desks to work. It's fairly quiet in the weekday mornings so you can definitely come by and take calls, but it does pick up in the afternoon and gets quite busy.

The coffee is decent- matcha is not the best in my opinion. Would definitely get the food here though as it tastes super homemade and authentic. The noodles and the bulgogi both make for a great afternoon lunch.

Would definitely come back to do work or just catch up with someone!

I was so excited to try this place because of the gallery and atmosphere. The matcha was one of the worst matchas I've ever had, and I strive to taste ceremonial grade, high-quality matchas. It was also the most expensive I've ever paid for a matcha (which is not out of the ordinary as a LA native and frequent New Yorker). But for it to be really gross, watery, and $8.44 (with reg milk) is really disappointing. They have a menu with what looks like many options of great matcha, but my "matcha cream" looked nothing like the pictures. It looked like a cheap donut shop matcha. Not to mention the energy in there was odd upon walking in and the employees weren't very welcoming nor seemed happy to be there.

I've gone here a few times for lunch. I love their hojicha and combo soba. Their gyudon has a bit too much rice for me, and that's saying something as a rice lover. Their Inari sushi is pretty good and comes with some fresh and pickled vegetables. Similar with their onigiri (I had the spicy tuna). My friend had their chicken curry and didn't like it as much as the gyudon,  but I've yet to try it myself.

Eager to try other drinks and food next time.

The environment is very nice, cute, fun, and quiet. The staff are sweet and hospitable.

Be sure to ask for a receipt upfront if you need it; the default is to not give one, which is fine for many people these days--but not all!

Usagi NY is a cute little Japanese cafe with a little art gallery in the front and small tea and poke shop in the back. They have many authentic Japanese teas, drinks, and snacks available for purchase and have a comfy sitting area for you to sip and eat just behind the art gallery. They have plenty of books to pore over while eating your food/drink. If you have any questions about the items on the menu, the person working the register at the tea shop is very knowledgeable! Usagi is the perfect pit stop if you've just finished crossing the Brooklyn Bridge!

Pretty overpriced, nothing was that great but the space is beautiful and the design books are on point. The food was fine, too sweet though which is disappointing. Matcha too watered down. Biggest turnoff was the cashier girl. Like, your serving tea and bowls of noodles, you're not that special. Not sure how someone like this even makes it through life. Def don't recommend tipping her service, esp bc it's all overpriced anyway.

I've been trying for a while but finally made it to @usaginy on a Friday afternoon. Was planning on working there but the wifi couldn't connect to my Macbook or iPhone so that failed I really liked the idea of art + books + cafe. Reminds me a lot of the stationery and book stores back in Tokyo (thinking Iidabashi area specifically)! The drink is definitely pricey but since you can sit for a while I think it makes sense. I didn't love my drink that much, felt like the matcha got watered down by the ice, and kuromitsu jelly were diced up too tiny for me to really enjoy it. Would be down to try maybe just the regular matcha or matcha latte next time though!

Cute cafe and modern furniture. The matcha cream was good, but the matcha could've been stronger. Love the atmosphere and selection of Japanese pastries, savory foods, and other Japanese drinks. The front half sells books and other cute things. Will be back to try the food.

I really wanted to like this place because the idea of a place that's cafe, art gallery, and a bookstore was really appealing. However I'm a bit disappointed with their food. I ordered inari sushi set and a onigiri in tuna mayo flavor. I find the onigiri extremely expensive at $7 but I ordered it anyways hoping the quality is superior. Unfortunately the quality of onigiri was poor and especially the rice was mushy and the tuna mayo flavor was very blend. Inari had a good flavor but again the most important ingredient, rice, was very mushy.

Super aesthetic, peaceful and beautiful place. A bookstore and gallery disguised as a stunning cafe :) very specious, lots of cute and unique seats, adorable tea sets and stationary for sale!

Got the beef bowl and it tastes like bulgogi/ ! Delicious. The iced latte is also really good! My sister says it's really hard to find GOOD coffee in nyc and she's so happy to have found another treasure!

Lots of books around if you've finished your work and need something to fill the time here. WiFi is also fast!!!

Staff are kind! Just love everything about this place. 11/10 recommend.

The mizudashi ($5) for 16 oz was underwhelming and dare I say overpriced. Maybe I am not sophisticated enough in the taste bud department to differentiate between this and other iced coffees. I will come back to try the food. The space is very meditative and nice and I saw a lot of people studying and doing other work.

A one of a kind experience here! The art gallery with books and a Japanese cafe? That's literally perfection. The vibe is so unique and special it's like a gem in NYC. A perfect study spot. Their cafe items are pretty good- a bit pricey than most but I feel it's not too bad. Some of the iced drinks are not the best if I have to be honest such as the iced hot chocolate but I liked their other iced drinks like the Hojicha latte. Something like that would normally make me take away a star but i just can't give this place anything less than a 5/5. Only other thing is that the hours are so short :( but other than that I love this place so so much it's probably one of my favorite lounge spots ever.
Very sub par hojicha latte hastily done. They no longer put much care in the teas they do. Sad

Super cozy environment with great bookstore and cafe. The drinks are very good and the prices are great. I got the matcha drink and the flavor was wonderful with just the right amount of sweetness. Decent amount of seating place as well. The places closes at 4, unfortunately, but I would love to come back soon to try out their food!

I love their hojicha latte but the service here isn't good. The barista here is rude and makes sure she lets you know she's not having a good day. I just want to start my day with one of the best hojicha lattes but I don't want to soak in that negative energy lol

Usagi is unique to say the least.

It's part book store, part art space, and part coffee shop with some food options.

They have a bunch of different drip coffee options (at a cool $4), and like about a hundred different coffee brewing tools.

The food is refrigerated and includes bento boxes form Obento, and pies from Four & Twenty.

I ordered a Saikyo miso salmon bento box (a bit on the pricier side for lunch at $15 + tax), but it was a lot of food an pretty tasty. I took it back to the office, so I was also able to pop it in the microwave real quick. The salmon was sizeable, and it came with pickles veggies, egg dessert, and preserved plum sticky rice.

Would definitely come back for coffee and maybe a chirashi/poke bowl.

Location: right at Dumbo, Usagi NY is like a coffee- gallery. Place is full of artistic books and the place is great to get pics.
Their is a small sitting area where you can sip your coffee while reading.

Drinks: the owner seems to be Japanese.  I totally could be wrong but all drinks have signatures of japanese style. I basically tried eveyghing. And I particular love the matcha flavor.

Price: it's dumbo. What do you expect ?!

Service: nice.

Overall: absolutely a good place to visit if you are in dumbo

What a beautiful space.  
You walk through a beautiful gallery space that's all clean lines and abstract art to get to their beautiful counter that is bedecked with all sorts of interesting coffee/tea contraptions and paraphernalia but still somehow manages to feel uncluttered.  If you like matcha, you have to try their matcha latte.  You can personalize sweetness and milk type, I always get soy and unsweetened, and it only comes in one size.  Its a little pricey at around $6 but I really feel like it's just another piece of art being offered up here.  Yes, I'm a matcha snob, deal with it.  Oh, and I hear the coffee is really good too, and I believe it.

How can I not give this beautiful oasis 5 stars? 10 stars for ambiance and 4 stars for the hojicha pie I had, so ... still rounds up to 5.

One of my visiting friends suggested that we check out Usagi, and I was delighted when I walked in. Usagi is a bookstore, art gallery, cafe, and home goods shop perfectly blended into one. I love the architecture and space, carefully designed by a Japanese architect (read about him at Usagi!). The lounge spaces are comfortable, minimalistic yet eclectic, and thoughtfully put together. I wish I had had an opportunity to try the Japanese food they had, but I had lunch plans elsewhere. I got a hojicha pie slice to share (sourced from an outside bakery) and I liked the filling a lot, though I thought the crust could be better.

Overall, I'd definitely come back to chill, catch up with friends, or even do some work in a serene space.
Really good Kyoto cold brew! The place is a gallery and a coffee shop so it's really nice and has lots of seating! The employees are also really kind! I spilled my drink and they replaced it for me.

Having delicious Japanese food in a library. That sums it up.

A gem in Brooklyn's DUMBO neighborhood (near the Brooklyn Bridge). Usagi is a Japanese art gallery, bookstore, and cafe. We stumbled upon this place while exploring the DUMBO area. Everything is so neat, clean and in modernist white lines. There is a library feel to it (behind the gallery where the cafe is). They sell cold bento boxes (though they can reheat it at the customer's request), Japanese snacks and drinks along with tea and coffee. The seating area is extremely comfortable. The atmosphere is generally pleasant, subdued (not library level hush hush but quiet), and relaxed. Love their thoughtful decor and all the books on the shelf that you can read while sipping tea or having a bento box.

What a soothing, delicious spot. The matcha latte was the best I've had! Slightly sweetened with honey, it didn't have the grassy taste of other matchas, or the powdery taste. In fact, you can watch them make it with such detail and care, no wonder it's so good. The space itself is mostly straight, sleek and wood, full of design books, a gift shop, a cafe and even an art gallery. You really feel like you've found an oasis here, and I can't wait to come back and try their lunch bento boxes available on a weekday.

5 stars!!!!!!

Cafe Usagi
NY BK DUMBO
4pm 27th May 2016
Five Stars

Located a block from DUMBO Boulders, I found this hidden cafe in an art gallery using the Cups App. (Use Promo Code: 25pn5 for $10 Credit). I had their Mizudashi Cold Brew Coffee. It was floral, with a long lingering after taste that sticks to your teeth. The coffee came in a clear corn-made compostable plastic cup with a customized label and crescent shaped ice. The gallery was quite cool. They have a couple high top tables and a lounge with sofas. They also serve some Japanese bento box type food.

Wouldn't have stumbled upon this cafe if Brooklyn Roasting Company wasn't so crowded, but I am so glad I did. This will now be my go to cafe whenever I'm in this area. The atmosphere is so chill and like the Danish would say "hygge".

I was so happy to see hojicha latte on their menu because there's only a handful of places that I know in NYC that has it. Their hojicha latte is probably the best one I've had in a while. The tea flavor is strong, but not over steeped. The milk was froth to the right consistency making the latte very smooth. They use actual tea leaves instead of powder and I believe the tea they use is from Ippodo which you can purchase in the store.

I also ordered a matcha custard pie which is from Four and Twenty Blackbirds (my favorite pie shop). The pie tasted the same, but I will skip it next time because Usagi charges much more than the pie shop itself.

Love Usagi! The interior is japanese modern minimalistic and makes for great pictures. The atmosphere is very calming, clean white and wood everywhere. There's a great collection of lovely books and gifts, I could seriously spend so much here. The cafe - super cute, and the drinks are really good quality! I've tried the matcha latte with soy milk (one of the best matcha drinks I've ever tried) and the hojicha iced tea is really nice too with a lot of flavor.
The only reason I've knocked off one star: the cafe service was quite slow, on ordering two drinks I received one after 5 minutes and the next 5 minutes later, and the barista seemed quite confused, even though there was only me and one other person before me to make drinks for. Maybe she was new, anyway I will definitely keep coming despite this, just would have been 5 stars if service was a bit quicker :)

This is such a cute place we bumped into!
I love their interior.
Perks they have a bathroom and WiFi!
Their matcha pie was delicious but pricey about $7.50 for one pie!
They have cozy couches and outlets there so that's good.
Would come back to try their matcha latte or brownie because love matcha!!!

Located in Dumbo :)

I love this place.
perfect!! here is very near by dumbo.
macha latte was so good! and staff was very kind!

I am impressed, Usagi NY was really outstanding. Usagi NY is a hidden treasure. Only quality. Everything I've tried so far has been terrific. The workers were great, I didn't have any problems, everything went without problems with my order and service. Usagi NY, I cannot say enough great things about this gem.

They make an incredible matcha latte!! I ordered the iced matcha latte through the CUPS app, and it was so good I almost regretted not paying full price.

The barista whisked the matcha on the spot literally before my eyes, and when I asked for "lightly sweetened" she added just the right amount--enough to give depth and a touch of sweetness but not so much that it was saccharine. I could really taste the matcha with the milk. It was perfect!

I've been to CHALAIT a few times, and their iced matcha doesn't compare at all. It's also hard to find an iced matcha latte that's not pre-made, so I really appreciated the care Usagi NY took into making theirs.

The space is also beautiful (art gallery and cafe rolled into one), and they serve bento boxes, which I hope to come back for! Plus free wifi :)

Very cute Japanese coffee shop/library with a variety of coffee and tea. I got the hojicha latte (described to me as a roasted green tea latte by the barista-- it was listed as the house favorite). It had a nutty flavor and I think the tea flavor was kind of diluted down..mine mostly tasted like milk. I'm gonna try the matcha latte if I return.

The interior is white with wooden tables (high tops with backless stools and couch-style seating against the wall with sliding lower coffee tables). Free wifi so it is a nice place to get some work done, though there aren't many outlets for those that need to charge up.

Drinks range in price from around $3-$7. They offer pour over, espresso, latte, and others. For $0.50 extra, you can get almond or soy milk.

Overall 3.5 stars but hardly any outlets and blah tea so I rounded down. Great clean fairly quiet place to get work done though

Such an adorable and unique spot in Dumbo. This place is an art gallery/shop/cafe. The gallery is small and free to walk around. The gift shop is also small, with tea products from Ippodo tea, books, and gadgets for the home. The cafe is small - there wasn't any seating available so we sat by the window in the shop. The cafe offers lots of tea and coffee options - including matcha from Ippodo. They have pie from Four and Twenty Blackbirds. I was hoping to find the matcha pie but they were sold out, so I tried hojicha pie instead. They have a selection of sold bento boxes, udon, and onigiri. I ordered the seaweed udon - it was so savory and delicious. Noodles were great and soup was perfect for a cold day. I would definitely come back here to get more udon.

Amazing macha tea and drinks (hot chocolate is NOT too sweet). There are some couches and small tables to work at. The cafe itself is back behind a gallery (which changes month to month). I think the place is a bit too bougie IMO but that's Dumbo for ya.

BONUS: They sell pie here from Four and Twenty Blackbirds. They almost always have slices of matcha pi (very delicious) and I've seen Hojicha pi (roasted green tea) as well.

I WANT TO LIVE HERE! This place is such a gem, a bookstore slash gallery slash cafe filled with everything I would ever want in my life- coffee, matcha desserts, adorable bento boxes, and tons of random artsy probably impractical gadgets and papers I would one way want to fill my home with. If I lived closer, I definitely would be here like every day. My friend and I stumbled upon it just in time before closing after doing some work at BRC right across the street so we just got a slice of matcha pie (they get them from Four and Twenty Blackbirds- a bomb.com pie shop btw) and coffee.

Matcha Pie- decadent and creamy matcha filling- kind of reminds me of ROYCE's matcha chocolate. The crust was mehhhh.. kind of stale and cardboard-y but i think it might've been because we came so close to closing!

A cafe au fait with cafe au lait.

The space is kept in beautiful and simple classic Japanese/Scandinavian design. Very comfortable furniture. Good free WiFi and doesn't seem busy.

And the pourover coffee - one of the best I have had! Highly recommended and I will be back. The Japanese foods and matcha look legit too, haven't tried them yet though.

Also, thumbs up for serving the takeaway coffee in 100% compostable containers - including the lid. Keep it up! :)

UPDATE September 2016:

Updating to add that this place makes the best cafe au lait I've ever had. It's a sad truth that many otherwise decent cafes think that cafe au lait is espresso-based. It is not! This cafe gets it. You might say that this is a cafe au fait with cafe au lait.

It's a nice/modernly decorated bookstore/cafe that's designed by a famous architect. It houses seasonal exhibitions and sells drinks and light food in the back area. The place is not small but not that big either. If you want a quiet/relaxed area to sip and quietly talk in Dumbo, this place may be it.

From outside, you wouldn't have expected this place to have a cafe and lounge area. But that's because the front has a small art exhibition of interesting designs with old Mac computers, neverending mini mazes, hairy cubes and so on. After walking past the art exhibition you will find this small hidden lounge and coffee bar.

On a Sunday, it seemed quiet in here, which is perfect for people who are studying or just want to do work outside of the typical coffee shops that are crowded and noisy. Usagi is big on Matcha here so I went ahead and ordered the iced matcha latte unsweetened. I normally get unsweetened when I order from Starbucks, but here you can taste the difference in their matcha that it tastes more raw and not sweet. I ended up asking for a small portion of sweetener.

The staff in here is really nice. Besides just the coffee shop, they also sell t-shirts and other goods branded with DUMBO and some in house brands that they manufacturer and partner with such as wallets, stationary goods, t-shirts, tapestrys. They also sell small lunch boxes in Japanese style for those on the go.

If I lived closer and wanted a quiet place outside of my apartment to study, I would definitely visit here for studying and getting work done!

If you've ever wished for an art-gallery/bookstore/library/cafe/coffee-shop, this is the perfect spot. The music is usually quiet and acoustic (unlike many NYC coffee shops) so it is the perfect spot for getting some work done. The wifi is also more reliable than most places and there is always an open seat.

$$: The coffee is on the pricier end ($6-8 for a latte) although the tea selection is very good. 10% discount if you bring your own cup/container!

Note that the books are only for purchase - not for reading! So maybe not quite a library.
awesome amazing food and the staff is so nice, great place to work from and very clean. Fast wifi and great coffee, they close early so keep that in mind when checking this out

I bookmarked Usagi months ago because I was intrigued with their matcha lattes.  I finally visited Usagi today with my bf and I wish I visited months ago!  

The matcha latte was so smooth and creamy.  No grainy matcha powder flowing in the drink.  I got it with soymilk, and the soymilk did not overpower the matcha flavor.  It was like drinking melted matcha ice cream.  I was actually surprised in the size of the drink - it was about 8oz, smaller than Starbucks Tall size for reference.  In this case, quality is way more important than quantity!

The cafe's location is very out of the way, but I did enjoy the views of the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges and the old cobblestone streets while walking over to the cafe.  

The cafe itself was very comfortable. I really like the art installations in the front and the overall coziness of the cafe's seating area.

You've probably seen other reviewers stating this is a perfect place for studying/drooling out/simply chilling and enjoy your coffee. Not on Monday mornings shall I say! There's barely any guest, not to mention the to-stay ones. Unless you know the people there already, which shouldn't be hard considering they are all super nice.

On the day I went there wasn't too much stuff being exhibited in the front. They were busy tidying up, but that doesn't change the barista lady's delightful smile. She took some time with my cafe au lait which was definitely worth it, and she even apologized for not having bento boxes ready the time I showed up! They really know how to capture your heart.

If it wasn't for the fact that no one was chilling at the lounges, I would've had a million reasons to stay in. Their seats look so comfortable I could stay there for hours without leaving. It is close enough to both my place and my school so I can definitely see myself becoming a regular.

This place was so cute! I am in love with the bookstore cafe concept because it combines two of my great loves! Very close to the Brooklyn Bridge yet not very crowded or touristy. Most of patrons seemed to be from around the area and looking for a calm and quiet place to read or to grab a cold drink. Not the largest selections of books and iced tea was great for a hot day (as all cold drinks are) but not especially memorable. However, if you're a book nerd like me it's very worth a visit!

My mind is at peace after visiting this cafe randomly on a Monday afternoon. The most delicious matcha latte in NYC is pretty much right here. A combination of art studio/bookstore/stationaries/coffee shop/little snacking area.

I love how the place isn't noisy like other cafes around the neighborhood and that they serve a selection of food items at the coffee booth with poke at a limited time between 12-3pm I believe.

While you're waiting for your drink you get to look around and have this odd Japanese vibe going through your body wanting to touch all the cute little items they have on display and hopping to own a couple of products for yourself!

Overall, great cafe and atmosphere. Will be returning every so often!

This place is amazing and super aesthetic! It combines a store, art gallery, and cafe into one. They have a unique and excellently curated selection of books, and other home/office goods and gifts. The space is spacious, and has plenty of room to sit and work as well (free wifi!). Ordered a tasty mizudashi cold brew and took up a seat by the window while taking a break from walking around. Great place to stop while exploring the Dumbo neighborhood!
My daughter and my cat loves this place. Superb matcha lattes and insanely beautiful retail offerings. My favorite Cafe in the neighborhood and I've been here since 1998!

Pour over coffee
takes time but is worth it. Be
careful it is hot.

Iced matcha tea is
refreshing, the caffeine will
hit you hard, steady.

Poke bento looks
cute and tastes like it was made
with painstaking love.

My favorite cafe in the five boroughs. Super zen environment, peace and light and quiet. Amazing mugicha, hojicha, matcha lattes that I haven't found anywhere else. Delicious tea biscuits and other food offerings. Inspiring architecture and design books and other goods that add to the ambiance. Comfy seating and an art gallery in the space. What more do you need?
Amazing service and products!! On top of being an amazing looking space, the cafe is just as awesome! I can't wait to return. My matcha was perfect! I can tell it is high quality!!

Flavorful and delicious fish!

I haven't stumbled upon lots of poke places in Manhattan (maybe because I haven't specifically searched for them), but this one was delicious! The kani salad was a bit too much mayo for me but the portion was pretty sizeable. The bowl was the highlight. I created my own bowl and the fish was plentiful and tasted fresh.

Service was nothing stand out. You order your bowl using the menu and they make it in the back. That's the inconvenient part because you can't really see the options laid in front of you, which is different from most poke places I've eaten at.

The store is on the smaller side, but has 2 tables in the back and window seats near the door.

Very basic. Didn't love one of my proteins as string noodles. It's all healthy and well stocked. I'm super full. But it didn't really have much crazy flavor as it could. The proteins meh. The avocado was nice but hard to mash up and wasn't easy to divide.

Nice service inside. Not much seating.

Once you order you get your food in less than 5 minutes.... Which was awesome considering I was craving a poke bowl.

Then you get to the good part......but not so much... it was a bowl with way too much rice, a squirt of sauce, and no exaggeration 8-10 tiny pieces of each fish ...  for a large ($18) 100% not worth it.

Such a bummer...

Uptown Poke is a great lunch spot. It's clean, cute, and preposterously fast (our bowls came out literally seconds after ordering).

Most importantly, the poké bowls are delicious. I opted for the West Side (when in Rome...). It delivered exactly what I was looking for. I felt fresher after eating it. The tuna was tender and flavorful, the veggies were crisp, the sauces and crunchy tempura came together in heavenly flavor and texture harmony.

The matcha bubble tea was also delicious, not overly sweet. Much like my tasty salmon, I am hooked.

There was not a ton of seating but my wife and I had no issues securing seats by a sunny window on a Sunday afternoon.
Good, reasonably priced, healthy takeaway.  It's become a staple in our take out rotation.

One of the better poke places in Manhattan. A two protein bowl costs around $18 but they load your bowl with toppings. I love the build your own bowl option but the specialty bowls seem good as well. I almost wish they gave a bit more rice but it's a great deal for the amount of fish you get. I would pass on the bubble tea. I got the taro milk tea, which was pretty foamy (for some reason) and the boba wasn't sweet or soft at all. I would definitely come back for the poke bowl, especially if I were on the UWS!

I love this place. It is consistently fresh and the portions are generous. They offer sauce on the side so that I can add the amount I want. The staff is friendly and they often add little smileys and hearts on my bag when I order takeout. They clearly care about their restaurant and it shows in the quality of the food and service.
Under ripe avocado was used to make the poke bowl and sushi burrito ordered tonight. The sushi burrito was more of a hand roll with thick, tough, chewy nori.

Very impressed! I'm typically disappointed in poke bowls here in NYC since I've had the best of the best on the islands. But I decided to give Uptown Poke a shot since it had such great Yelp reviews-- so glad I did!

Ordered the "build your own bowl" in a large ($16) with the following combination of ingredients:

Tuna, Kani, White Rice, Diced Mango, Cucumber, Pickled Ginger, Shiitake Mushroom, Jalapeño, Wasabi Sauce, Spicy Mayo, Fried Garlic Crisps & Scallions.

What a crazy bunch of flavors that worked so well!!! I'm very impressed in the quality of tuna. No fibrous weird bits, it smelled incredible and melted in my mouth. Originally obsessed.

I ordered the Salmon Sunrise bowl here, and absolutely loved it! The small size is already really filling and kept me going the rest of the afternoon. The salmon, tuna, and crab were fresh and flavorful, and there was a perfect balance of rice, edamame, and seaweed. The avocado serving was very generous! The tempura crunch and spicy mayo really complemented the bowl well, and the lemon garnish brought out the rest of the flavors. Can't wait to be back to try some of their other bowls!

It's located right by Central Park, so I brought my meal over to a park bench on this warm summer day.

Such great poke! I had been craving poke for a while and Uptown Poke hit the spot.

I would suggest getting one of their signature bowls if you're trying to save a little money $$. Most of them come with two (or even three) types of protein, which if you were building your own bowl, would be a lot more expensive. If you build your own bowl, one protein is $14.99 while two proteins is $17.99. Most of the signature bowls are $14.99 so it's definitely a steal in my opinion.

I ordered the Salmon Sunrise bowl, which looked like one of their more popular options. It comes with salmon, tuna, kani, FREE avocado, edamame, and lemon. It is a HEFTY bowl! It also comes drizzled with sweet sauce and spicy mayo. I asked to swap the rice base for mixed greens to feel a little healthier. The mixed greens really make the bowl feel light! All of the ingredients were also insanely fresh, and the sauces mixed so well together. I do think they put a little too much sweet sauce in comparison to the spicy mayo. It almost seemed like 75/25 sweet sauce to spicy mayo when I would have preferred an even 50/50. Other than that, I have absolutely no complaints! I'm not in this area too often, but if I ever am, I'll definitely be popping back in.

I love the quality of their ingredients!
I order from them quite often! Never disappointed.
They're always nice and show signs of appreciation for the costumers every time,like in the picture

I was seriously craving a Poke bowl and this place is in my neighborhood. We ordered a large Yellowtail Supreme bowl and a regular sized West Side. The order was prepared and ready super quick.

When we got home it was a bit hard to tell which order was which because the tops were smothered in sauces and the large one wasn't immediately obvious (still not sure what the difference between large and regular is). I might just be very spoiled by Chelsea Markets Fish Market bowls, but this bowl was so wet and sloppy I couldn't eat it.
